NatureServe G RANK REASONS: Widespread; abundant tree species of the eastern and midwestern United States; often becoming the dominant or co-dominant tree in the forest canopy over large areas; particularly in the Appalachians and the Midwest.
NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: AL(SNR); AR(SNR); CT(SNR); DC(SNA); DE(S4); GA(S3); IA(S5); IL(SNR); IN(S5); KS(SNR); KY(S5); LA(SNR); MA(SNR); MD(SNR); ME(S5); MI(SNR); MN(SNR); MO(SNR); MS(SNR); NC(S5); ND(SH); NE(SNR); NH(SNR); NJ(SNR); NY(S5); OH(SNR); OK(SNR); PA(S5); RI(SNR); SC(S
Red List rationale: Acer saccharum is endemic to eastern North America, with a wide range from New Brunswick and New England in the north east to Minnesota and Missouri in the west. The population is likely to be large due to its wide range. The species may be at risk from Asian Longhorned Beetle but the loss of individuals to this pest if not currently known. There is also concern about the impact of acid rain and climate change to tree health and species range; this requires monitoring and research. The species is assessed as Least Concern. Although the species is potentially threatened by different factors the species range is still wide and individuals are important to the maple syrup industry so there is a vested interest in protecting the species.
Red List habitat: Acer sacchrum is a large tree species that can grow up to 40 m in height. The species is found in mixed- hard wood and conifer forests where it is often the dominant or codominant species. It can be found in moist lowland woods but also grows well in dry rocky highlands. It occurs in a variety of habitats including canyons, valleys, ravines and alongside streams (Nesom 2006). The species grows best in deep, moist, well drained soil; it cannot grow in flooded soils (Tirmenstein 1991). The species is susceptible to fire so the species expansion has only occurred over the last 650 years due to fire suppression. Acer sacchrum bears seed from between 30 to 40 years of age and seed is viable for up to five year but the seed bank normally only persists for one year. It can also reproduce through vegetative means (Nesom 2006). The species can grow well in shade, but sunny sites are preferred (Tirmenstein 1991). It can survive up to 500 years. The species is able to hybridise with other Acer spp. that share its range such as A. barabtum, A. leucoderme and A. nigrum (Nesom 2006). The tree is browsed by deer, moose, snow hares and squirrels (Tirmenstein 1991).
Red List threats:
Acer saccharum is a host to many pests and diseases, which although not a threat to the species do increase its risk of mortality from adverse weather conditions and reduce species productivity (Tirmenstein 1991, Gilman and Watson 1993). The pest of greatest concern is the Asian Longhorned Beetle (Anoplophora glabripennis) as Acer saccharum is one of the preferred hosts within North America (Dodds and Orwig 2011). This pest has established populations across parts of the species range (Minnesota to Maine) (Townsend Peterson et al. 2004). This causes death to urban trees but mortality is lower in native forest (Dodds and Orwig 2011). The current and future impact of this pest on the species is not known and should be investigated.

In the future the species may be threatened by climate change which may reduce the amount of suitable habitat for the species, resulting in a distribution change or potentially increased species mortality (Potter and Hargrove 2013, Iverson et al. 2008). The species is already being affected by climate change as conditions are becoming wetter which the species is less tolerant of (Bishop et al. 2015). The species is also becoming increasing susceptible to freeze-thaw injury (Gilman and Watson 1993) and also scorching. Acer saccharum is susceptible to fire but these have been suppressed over the last six centuries (Nesom 2006). Recently, Acer saccharum has been reported to be in decline over some parts of the range. The cause of which is uncertain but increased occurrence of acid rain producing unfavourable, acidic soil conditions is currently the most widely support hypothesis (Bishop et al. 2015). This reduces seedling recruitment and can make mature trees more susceptible to pests, diseases and rots (Tirmenstein 1991).
Red List population: There is no population information for this species but population is assumed to be large due to the species wide range. It is in the top three most common tree species in 12 states within its range. The population is potentially at risk of decline as a result of climate change. A study by Potter and Hargrove (2013) suggested a decline of 36.79% in suitable habitat area (km2) over the next 50 years based on climate modelling and emissions data. Iverson et al. (2008) also proposed a reduction in species abundance of up to 50% due to climate change and Yaussay et al. (2013) reported mortality risk for the species increased by 100% based on the most extreme climate models, in some states over the next 100 years. These changes could qualify the species from Vulnerable to Critically Endangered under criterion A3. However, we do not know the extent to which dispersal capacity, effect of/on associated species, generation time and other ecological factors were considered when generating the models. These factors would need full consideration to accurately assess population decline; therefore true population decline is not known.
Red List range: Acer saccharum is native to eastern North America. In Canada it is found in southern areas of Ontario and Quebec but the species is widespread in New Brunswick. From Canada the species is found south to Tennessee with outlier populations in Georgia, and South and North Carolina. From here the species is found in Apalachian mountains and all states north to New England (Tirmenstein 1991). The species western boundary is Kansas-Missouri border, also in two small sites in North and South Dakota and in Minnesota (Little 1976).
Red List use trade: Acer sacchrum is the predominant source of maple syrup, produced from the tapping of its sap. The species is used for its timber as it is tough and durable. It is used to make furniture, panelling, flooring, veneer and a variety of commercial goods (Tirmenstein 1991). The species has the potential to be used to revegetate disturbed due to the ease of propagation from seed (Tirmenstein 1991). It is planted as an ornamental species too (Nesom 2006).
Red List conservation actions: Acer saccharum is found in over 190 ex situ collections from across the globe (BGCI 2017). The species is considered Least Concern by Gibbs and Chen (2009) and not threatened by NatureServe (2009). The species decline noted by Bishop et al. (2015) should be further researched on a wider scale and range change in response to climate change should be monitored. This is particularly important for the outlier populations in Georgia, North and South Carolina and North and South Dakota. The impact of Asian Longhorned Beetle on species health should be further investigated.

NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: AL(SNR); AR(SNR); FL(SNR); GA(S5); IL(SNR); LA(SNR); MO(SNR); MS(SNR); NC(S5); OK(SNR); SC(SNR); TN(SNR); TX(SNR); VA(S4)
Red List rationale: Acer floridanum is a large tree species. It is endemic to the southern states of the United States of America. The taxon has recently become a species, after being previously considered Acer saccharum subsp. floridanum so information on the species is limited. Acer floridanum is assessed as Least Concern. The species has a wide native distribution and population is assumed to be large but this needs clarification. It is also currently unthreatened but in the future it may be negatively impacted by climate change and infestation by the Asian Longhorned Beetle. This situation should be monitored.
Red List habitat: Acer floridanum is a large tree species that can grow up to 18 m in height (Gilman et al. 2015). The species is tolerant of drought and can grow in most soil types. It also performs well in both shaded and sun exposed locations (Gilman et al. 2015). The species is found in mesic, calcareous woodlands (Ward 2004). The species is part of the Acer saccharum complex so resides in similar mixed, deciduous woodland (Ward 2004). The species reproduces through seeds which mature in the mid summer (Virginia Tech 2016).
Red List threats: Acer floridanum is not currently under threat however it is susceptible to a variety of pests and diseases (Gilman et al. 2015). Also, in the future the species may be threatened by habitat loss and decline as a result of climate change (Iverson et al. 2008, Pottter et al. 2013). Acer spp. are also the preferred host of the Asian Longhorned Beetle in North America, this is pest was previously found in Illinois but otherwise is established north of Acer floridanums range (CABI 2017) and may become a threat to the species if it were to spread south in the future. It would increase the species risk of mortality.
Red List population: There is limited population information for Acer floridanum. The native range of the species is wide so population is likely to be large and NatureServe considers the species secure in Georgia, North Carolina and Virginia (NatureServe 2009). Information on other states is not known but the species appears to be least abundant in Texas (USDA 2017). Acer floridanum populations may be subject to decline in the future as a result of climate change. A study by Potter et al. (2013) has suggested decline in suitable habitat (km2) for tree species (including other Acer spp.) with which A. floridanum shares its range. This change could occur over the next 50 years and the predictions are based on climate modelling and emissions data. These changes could qualify the species for a threatened category under criterion A3 however, we do not know the extent to which dispersal capacity, effect of/on associated species, generation time and other ecological factors were considered when generating the models. These factors would need full consideration and the species would need to be independently studied to accurately assess population change. Due to the species more southerly range their may be the potential for habitat expansion northwards.
Red List range: Acer floridanum is endemic to the United States of America where it is found in southern states. It is found as far west as the Texas-Louisiana border and Oklahoma and as far North as Missouri, Kentucky and Virginia. The species extent of occurrence (EOO) exceeds the criteria for a threatened category under Criterion B.
Red List use trade: Acer floridanum is used for its timber and as an ornamental species (Gilman et al. 2015).
Red List conservation actions: Acer floridanum is found in at least 24 ex situ collections (BGCI 2017). The species is probably found in U.S. National Parks across its range. It is recommended that a population survey is taken to clarify the species abundance across its range. Monitoring should also occur to ensure the species security against climate change and Asian Longhorned Beetle.

NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: AL(SNR); AR(S2S3); DC(SNA); FL(SNR); GA(S5); LA(S2S3); MS(S1); NC(S3S4); OK(SNR); SC(SNR); TN(S3); TX(SNR)
Red List rationale: Acer leucoderme is a small tree or shrub. It is native to the southern states of United States from Texas east to West Virginia. The species has a wide native range and population is assumed to be large. In the future Acer leucoderme may be adversely affected by climate change and the Asian Longhorned Beetle, presently there are minor concerns of habitat loss. The species is assessed as Least Concern. It is recommended the species be monitored for decline and a population survey conducted to ensure that the population is large.
Red List habitat: Acer leucoderme is a small tree or multi-stemmed shrub, growing up to 9 m in height (Gilman et al. 2015). The species can grow in most soil types and is drought tolerant (Gilman et al. 2015). It is an understory tree found in mixed deciduous woodland (NCSU 2017). The species can grow on river bank, ravines and cliffs (A Tree A Day 2015). In Alabama the species forms mesic communities with other Acer spp. and Quercus spp. (Rickerson et al. 2004).
Red List threats: In the future the species may experience decline as a result of climate change (Potter et al. 2013, Iverson et al. 2008). Acers are also the preferred host of the Asian Longhorned Beetle which is found north of the range of Acer leucoderme but if the pest were to spread A. leucoderme would be susceptible and greater risk of mortality. There are reports the species is at low risk from land-use conversion, habitat fragmentation and changes to forest management practices (Southern Appalachian Species Viability Project 2002).
Red List population: There is limited population information on this species. The population appears fairly patchy across its native distribution and is most abundant within Alabama, Georgia, North and South Carolina (Little 1976) even so population is still assumed to be large due to the wide range of the species. Acer leucoderme populations may be subject to decline in the future as a result of climate change. A study by Potter et al. (2013) has suggested -92.5% change in suitable habitat (km2) over the next 50 years for based on climate modelling and emissions data. These changes could qualify the species for a threatened category under criterion A3, if the suggested change was related to decline in habitat. However, we do not know the extent to which dispersal capacity, effect of/on associated species, generation time and other ecological factors were considered when generating the models. These factors would need full consideration to accurately assess population decline or potential habitat expansion as the species has a more southerly range and may be be able to more northwards.
Red List range: Acer leucoderme is native to North America, specifically the United States where it is found in southern states. The species is found in a few sites in Texas, Oklahoma, Tennessee and Florida. It is found over wider ranges in Louisiana, Arkansas, Mississippi, Alabama, Georgia, South Carolina and North Carolina (Little 1976). The species has a large extent of occurrence (EOO) that exceeds the thresholds of a threatened category under Criterion B.
Red List use trade: Acer leucoderme is commonly used as an ornamental species. The species was originally considered a subspecies of Acer saccharum which is used as a timber species, it is therefore likely Acer leucoderme is also used for timber.
Red List conservation actions: There are at least 22 ex situ collections of Acer leucoderme (BGCI 2017). The species is considered not threatened within the United States (NatureServe 2009). It is recommended that a population survey takes place to ensure the species is as widespread as the species native range might suggest. Monitoring of the species for the potential impact of climate change, habitat loss and the Asian Longhorned Beetle should also be considered.

Red List rationale: Acer nigrum is a large tree species found in the midwestern and eastern United States and in eastern Canada. The species is assessed here as Least Concern. It has large native range and its population is assumed to be large. Acer nigrum is not currently threatened however in the future the species may experience decline as a result of climate change and the resulting loss of suitable habitat. The species may also be adversely impacted by Asian Longhorned Beetle if this pest becomes further established. The extent to which Acer nigrum will be effected by these two threats is not known; this should be investigated and populations monitored.
Red List habitat: Acer nigrum is a large, tree growing up to 34 m tall but average height varies from state to state. The species is slow growing and can live for up to 200 years (Gabriel 2017). The species prefers a moist environment and is very frost hardy. It can survive freezing temperatures as low as -120Â°C. Over its range the species grows well in a variety of soil types and is most often found on lower slopes, except in Indiana when the species is more often found in the highlands. It is found in closed, mixed mesophytic climax forests where it can become dominant among other hardwood species (Gabriel 2017). It occupies a similar range to Sugar Maple (Acer saccharum), which it can often be found in association with. Acer saccharum sometimes out competes A. nigrum in higher latitudes but A. nigrum is able to tolerate flooding and drought to a greater extent (Zuzek et al. 2016). Acer nigrum seed is wind dispersed. The species is browsed by deer and the seeds are eaten by birds (Gabriel 2017).
Red List threats: The species is threatened by hybridisation with A. succharum. Acers are the preferred host of the Asian Longhorned Beetle (Anoplophora glabripennis) within North America (Nowak et al. 2011). The impact this invasive species is having on Acer nigrum populations has not yet been fully investigated but the pest is known to occur within the species range and infestation can result in increased mortality (Townsend- Peterson et al. 2004). Hence it is considered a potential threat. In the future the species may be threatened by climate change which may reduce the amount of suitable habitat for the species, resulting in a distribution change or potentially increased species mortality (Potter and Hargrove 2013, Iverson et al. 2008). The species is also likely to suffer from a range of fungi, bacteria and insect pest and diseases as seen in other North American acers. There is no explicit reports of this and these pests are not considered a major threat to the population however they can damage and cause death to individuals.
Red List population: Acer nigrum has a large population that is assumed to be stable. The species is more populous within its eastern range than in its western range (Gabriel 2017). In some states it is wide ranging while in others it is found in small pockets for example in Massachusetts stands of 100 individuals are common (NHESP 2012). Population although currently considered stable may decline as a result of climate change. A study by Potter and Hargrove (2013) suggested a decline of 86.7% in suitable habitat area (km2) over the next 50 years based on climate modelling and emissions data. Iverson et al. (2008) also reported that A. pensylvanicum abundance could decline by 50% as a result of climate change within its US range. These changes could qualify the species as Critically Endangered under criterion A3 however we do not know the the extent to which dispersal capacity, effect of/on associated species, generation time and other ecological factors were considered when generating the models. These factors would need full consideration to accurately assess population decline; therefore true future population decline is not known.
Red List range: Acer nigrum is endemic to North America. In Canada the species is found in Quebec and Ontario. The species is also found in the midwestern United States; from Minnesota, Iowa and Missouri in the west through Kentucky and north to Vermont; occurring in the majority of states in between (Little 1976, USDA 2017). The species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) and area of occupancy (AOO) that far exceeds the criteria for a threatened category.
Red List use trade: Acer nigrum sap is widely tapped to produce syrup (Gabriel 2017). The species is also used for its timber which is in turn used to produce flooring, veneer, musical instruments, baseball bats and a variety of household items. It can also be used to produce paper (Meier 2015). The species is also planted as an ornamental.
Red List conservation actions: There are at least 28 ex situ collections of the species across the globe (BGCI 2017). The species is considered not threatened by Nature Serve (NatureServe 2009) and by Gibbs et al. 2009. The species should be monitored to assess its response to climate change and the impact of the Asian Longhorned Beetle on the species should be investigated.

NatureServe taxon aligned: synonymized with 	Acer saccharum ssp. schneckii (141648)

Red List rationale: The species is widespread and while it is declining in parts of its range, it is not thought that the overall population decline is likely to meet 30% over the past or future three generations. Therefore the species is assessed as Least Concern.
Red List habitat: An aquatic emergent and wetland plant, reported as an alpine to subalpine plant. Found in low meadows and by streams in the Rocky Mountains.
Red List threats: The threats to the species are unknown.
Red List population: According to NatureServe the species global status is 'Apparently Secure / Secure' (G4/5), with the population in Saskatchewan classed as 'Critically Imperiled' and in Alberta as 'Imperilled'. According to the Canadian Endangered Species Conservation Council (CESCC) the population in Canada is classed as 'Sensitive'.
Red List range: The species is found in the Rocky Mountains in south-western Canada and western United States of America.
Red List use trade: Identified as a plant of economic importance, used as human food.
Red List conservation actions: No conservation actions for the species are known. More information would be useful on the species population status and threats across its range.

Red List rationale: Allium schoenoprasum is a widespread species that is suspected to be stable through much of its range and is also present with reproducing populations in protected areas in Europe, Russia, North America and China. It is also conserved ex situ, however, some areas within the species' range may be under-represented in germplasm collections and so further collection and back-up storage of germplasm material is recommended. Due to this species' threatened status in some regions, national level monitoring is also recommended (Kell et al. 2013).
Red List habitat:
In Europe A. schoenoprasum subsp. schoenoprasum grows along river banks and in wet meadows, while A. schoenoprasum subsp. alpinum occurs in alpine grasslands, on rocky ledges, in crevices and dry places with little soil (Kell et al. 2013).

In the UK, this species occurs in a range of lowland habitat types but is most commonly found on thin soils over limestone, serpentine and igneous rocks . It is also known to grow in rank grass on deeper soils and within crevices in riverside bedrock (Preston et al. 2002). In Finland the species is found in agricultural habitats, rocky areas and shores (Kell et al. 2013).

Within the Canadian prairie provinces this species occurs in wet meadows, rocky or gravely mountain slopes, on stream banks and the lake shores of Alberta, Saskatchewan, and Manitoba. It has a similar habitat type in Russia, where it prefers damp meadows in river valleys, alpine meadows, lake shores and riverbanks, stony slopes, and tundra (Chukhina 2009).
Red List threats: In Finland, Allium schoenoprasum subsp. alpinum is threatened by habitat destruction through tourism and has been classified as Near Threatened (almost meeting VU D2). This species is also known to have been threatened in the Netherlands by the modification of river dunes (Mennema et al. 1985). Threats across the rest of this species' range remain unknown.
Red List population: Allium schoenoprasum has a stable population trend in Slovakia and is noted as common where it is found in Germany and Norway (Kell et al. 2013). In the United States this species Critically Imperiled in Colorado, New Hampshire and Vermont, Imperiled in Michigan and Minnesota and Apparently Secure in Montana and Wyoming (NatureServe 2013). In Canada it is reported to be Imperiled in Saskatchewan and Nova Scotia and Apparently Secure in Yukon, Manitoba and Ontario; it is not ranked throughout the rest of its North American Range (NatureServe 2013). Further research is needed to gather information about the population size and trend throughout the rest of this species' range, however given the widespread nature of this species global population is suspected to be stable.
Red List range:
Allium schoenoprasum is native to many parts of northern, middle, east, southeastern and southwestern Europe, as well as temperate Asia, Canada, the USA, India and Pakistan (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2010).

As identified by Kell et al. (2013), information on the distribution of this species is available for the following countries:
  • Czech Republic: A. schoenoprasum subsp. alpinum is known in three localities in national parks and A. schoenoprasum subsp. schoenoprasum is widespread along the Elbe and Vltava Rivers.
  • Finland: occurs in the whole country but most frequently in the south. A. schoenoprasum subsp. schoenoprasum occurs in the south with one known occurrence in central-northern Finland. A. schoenoprasum subsp. alpinum occurs in the northern-most part of the country.
  • France: widespread, occurs in over half of the country's 100 departments, but is marginally less widespread in the north (Association Tela Botanica 2000â2010).
  • Iberia: A. schoenoprasum ssp. orosiae from western Pyrennes and ssp. A. schoenoprasum subsp. latiorifolium from Sierra De Guadarrama.
  • Ireland: limited distribution, occurring in only seven localities (Preston et al. 2002). However, according to Preston et al. (2002), it is only native in two of these localities (in the west).
  • Netherlands: distributed along the large rivers (Mennema et al. 1985).
  • Norway: A. schoenoprasum subsp. schoenoprasum occurs in the south and A. schoenoprasum subsp. alpinum in the north.
  • Portugal: occurs in the northwest.
  • Slovakia: A. schoenoprasum subsp. alpinum is scattered in mountain regions in northern and northwestern parts of the country (DostÃ¡l and Äervenka 1992).
  • UK: patchy distribution throughout England and parts of Scotland, but has only be recorded in one locality in Northern Ireland (Preston et al. 2002). However, according to Preston et al. (2002), it is only native in a few localities in the west (mainly Cornwall and Wales) and the northeast.
Choi and Oh (2011) believe that existing records of this species in Korea are the result of a misidentification of herbarium specimens, verified to be Allium maximowiczii, and therefore propose the exclusion of A. schoenoprasum from Korean Allium lists as it is not native to this country (Choi et al. 2004).
Red List use trade:
Allium schoenoprasum, commonly known as Chives, is a widely cultivated species. In Europe the young leaves are appreciated as an early vitamin source in the spring and are used as a condiment for salads and sauces (Rabinowitch and Currah 2002, Kell et al. 2013).

A. schoenoprasum subsp. alpinum and A. schoenoprasum subsp. schoenoprasum are primary wild relatives of and potential gene donors to Chives. The species is also a tertiary wild relative of and potential gene donor to a number of other crops in the Allium group, including Onion A. cepa L., Welsh Onion A. fistulosum L., Leek A. porrum L. and Garlic A. sativum L (Friesen et al. 2006, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013, Kell et al. 2013). It is also documented to be a cold-tolerant species by Chukhina (2009).
Red List conservation actions:
According to Kell et al. (2013), knowledge of this species' national threat status in Europe is as follows:
  • Czech Republic, Poland and Slovakia: A. schoenoprasum subsp. alpinum is classified as Vulnerable.
  • Finland: A. schoenoprasum subsp. alpinum is classified as Near Threatened, while A. schoenoprasum subsp. schoenoprasum is classified as Least Concern.
  • Denmark: this species is classified as Data Deficient (Wind and Pihl 2010).
In France this species is protected in the region of Bretagne in the west (Association Tela Botanica 2000â2010).

This species is documented to be present in the following protected areas (Information Center for the Environment (ICE) 2013): 
  • Russia â Barguzinskiy Biosphere Reserve, Bassegi Zapovednik (abundant with reproducing population), Katunsky Biosphere Reserve (abundant with reproducing population), Kavkazskiy Biosphere Reserve (abundant with reproducing population), Kronotskiy Biosphere Reserve, Magadansky Zapovednik (uncommon), Ostrov Vrangelya (Wrangel Island) Zapovednik (common with reproducing population), Pechoro-Ilychskiy Biosphere Reserve (common), Sayano-Shushenskiy Biosphere Reserve (rare with reproducing population) and Taimyrsky Biosphere Reserve (rare with reproducing population). 
  • China â Changbai Mountain Nature Reserve
  • Belarus â Belovezhskaya Pushcha Biosphere Reserve
  • Poland â Puszcza Kampinoska 
  • Czech Republic â Palava Protected Landscape Area and Trebon Basin Protected Landscape Area
  • Germany â Berchtesgaden Alps (rare), Flusslandschaft Elbe Biosphere Reserve, Schorfheide-Chorin, and Waddensea of Lower Saxony 
  • United States of America â Frederick Law Olmsted National Historic Site, MA (uncommon with reproducing population); Glacier National Park and Biosphere Reserve, MT (reproducing population present); Grand Portage National Monument, MN (non reproducing population present); Indiana Dunes National Lakeshore, IN; Isle Royale Biosphere Reserve, MI (uncommon with reproducing population); Kobuk Valley National Park, AK; Noatak Biosphere Reserve, AK; Noatak National Preserve, AK; Sleeping Bear Dunes National Lakeshore, MI (non-reproducing population present) and Yellowstone Biosphere Reserve, ID, MT, WY (reproducing population present)
  • Canada â Niagara Escarpment Biosphere Reserve and Woodland Caribou Provincial Wilderness Park (rare but reproducing population)

EURISCO reports 174 germplasm accessions held in European genebanks, 76 of which are reported to be of wild or weedy origin. Of the wild accessions, 73 originate from within Europe. The majority of these wild accessions originate from Sweden (40) (EURISCO Catalogue 2010).

Twenty-six accessions are held in the National Plant Germplasm System (NPGS), six of which are of wild origin and a further three of which are backed up at a second site (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2014). Furthermore, 74 accessions (38,300 seeds) are duplicated and conserved ex situ in the Svalbard Global Seed Vault, originating from two gene banks (SGSV Data Portal 2013).

According to Botanical Garden Conservation International (BGCI 2013), this species has at least 145 living collections in botanical gardens worldwide, although the origin and location of the collection are not detailed in this resource (garden locations are undisclosed to protect rare and valuable plant species).

NatureServe G RANK REASONS: Allium validum is common in California; scattered in northern Nevada; and occurs north to Washington. Previously thought to occur in southern British Columbia; but voucher evidence for these reports has not been found. It is also known from western Idaho.

Red List rationale: This species is classed as Least Concern as it is considered to be common in California and has a wide range, however, it is scarce or scattered in other states and could become threatened if its Californian populations decline.
Red List habitat: This species occurs in montane swampy meadows (Flora of North America Editorial Committee, eds. 2006), springs and boggy lake edges (Calflora, 2015).
Red List threats: Livestock grazing, mining, and timber harvesting are all described as threats to this taxon (Calflora, 2015; NatureServe, 2015)
Red List population: There is no information available on population trends in this species, however it is considered to be common in California and scattered in Nevada (Calflora, 2015).
Red List range: This species is endemic to North America where it occurs from British Columbia south to California and east to Idaho and Nevada (Flora of North America Editorial Committee, eds. 2006). It is reported as rare in south-central and southeastern British Columbia, but according to BC CDC data, vouchers for these reports could not be located (E-Flora BC, 2015)
Red List conservation actions: This species is described as common in California (Calflora) and imperilled in Idaho (NatureServe, 2015).

Red List rationale: This species has been assigned a conservation status of Least Concern because of its large, stable population and broad geographic range with no major threats.
Red List habitat: Water Hickory is a large tree that occurs in forested swamps, river banks, bayous, river flood plains, and temporarily flooded bottom-lands (Flora of North America 2018, Godfrey and Wooten 1981).
Red List threats: There are no major threats affecting or likely to affect this species in the near future. This taxon is ranked G5 - Secure by NatureServe (NatureServe 2018).
Red List population: The known population is stable.
Red List range: Water Hickory (Carya aquatica) occurs throughout the southern United States including southern Illinois and southern Indiana. It is bounded in the west by Texas, Arkansas, southeast Missouri and eastern Oklahoma (Ladybird Johnson Wildflower Center 2018).
Red List use trade: The primary use of Water Hickory is as firewood (Burns and Honkala 1990).
Red List conservation actions: At this time there are no conservation actions in place for Water Hickory (Carya aquatica) because it is a common species across the southern area of the United States (NatureServe 2018). This species is found in 27 ex situ collections (BGCI 2018).

Red List rationale: This species is assessed as Least Concern because of the large, stable known population which is found across an extensive range, with no major threats.
Red List habitat: Carya cordiformis is a large tree (Coladonato 1992). It is found on forested river flood plains, well-drained hillsides, and limestone glades (eFloras 2008).
Red List threats: There are no major threats affecting or likely to affect Carya cordiformis in the near future.
Red List population: The known population is stable.
Red List range: Carya cordiformis occurs in every United States state east of the hundredth meridian, excluding North Dakota and South Dakota and includes the Canadian provinces of Ontario and Quebec (Plants Database 2018). It is most common from southern New England west to Iowa and from southern Michigan south to Kentucky (Coladonato 1992).
Red List use trade: The hardwood of Bitternut Hickory is used for making tools, tool handles furniture, panelling, dowels and ladders. Bitternut Hickory is also desirable for charcoal and fuel wood. Other uses include bars, crates, pallets, and flooring. Smoke from the wood of Bitternut Hickory is used to give hams and bacon a "hickory smoked" flavour. The deep lateral roots of Bitternut Hickory make it a valuable species for watershed protection (Coladonato 1992).
Red List conservation actions: At this time there are no conservation actions in place because this is a common species in its Atlantic and Gulf coastal plain habitats, in the extreme southeastern United States (NatureServe 2018). Furthermore, this taxon is ranked G5 - secure by NatureServe (NatureServe 2018). This species is found in 118 ex situ collections (BGCI 2018).

NatureServe G RANK REASONS: Apparently not uncommon; but range is restricted.
NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: FL(SNR)
Red List rationale: This species is endemic to Florida, USA. The species has a wide geographic range which exceeds the criteria for a threatened category under criterion B. There are not major threats to the species. It is globally assessed as Least Concern.
Red List habitat: This species can grow as a tree to 25 m tall but it is more commonly a large shrub. It grows on sandy ridges of sand-pine scrub.
Red List threats: There are no major threats reported for this species.
Red List population: The population size for this species has not been quantified. Nature Serve states that the population is stable.
Red List range: This species is native to Florida, USA only. Using the current herbarium record the species has an estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of 42,842 km<sup>2</sup>.
Red List use trade: This species has ornamental value.
Red List conservation actions: This specie is assessed as G4 on NatureServe (2018). It is present in at least three ex situ collections (BGCI 2018).

Red List rationale: Pignut Hickory (Carya glabra) is here assessed as Least Concern because of the large stable populations known and the species extensive range and no major threats.
Red List habitat: Pignut Hickory is a large tree that codominates certain upland hardwood forests of eastern North America. Common co-dominants include White Oak (Quercus alba) and Northern Red Oak (Q. rubra). Over its extensive range, Pignut Hickory inhabits many community types such as the edge of bayous, deep flood plains, well-drained sandy soils, rolling hills and slopes, dry rocky soils, or thin soils on edge of granite outcrops (Tirmenstein 1991, Flora of North America 2018).
Red List threats: There are no major threats affecting or likely to affect Carya glabra in the near future.
Red List population: The known population is stable.
Red List range: Carya glabra is native to North America. This species is found from southwest New Hampshire, west to southern Ontario and central Michigan, then southwest to Illinois, west to Iowa, south to Texas, east to Florida, and then north along the Atlantic Ocean to southwest New Hampshire (Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center 2018, VASCAN 2018, USDA 2018, Flora of North America 2018).
Red List use trade: Pignut Hickory wood is heavy, hard, strong, tough, and flexible. Sporting goods, agricultural implements, and tool handles are made from the wood of Pignut Hickory as well as specialty products such as shuttle blocks, mallets, and mauls. Pignut Hickory is also used as a shade tree throughout much of its range (Tirmenstein 1991).
Red List conservation actions: At this time there are no conservation actions in place because Carya glabra is a common species. This taxon is ranked G5 - secure by NatureServe (NatureServe 2018). The species is found in 86 ex situ collections (BGCI 2018).

Red List rationale: The Pecan tree is large and native to both the United States of America and Mexico. The species has a large geographic range with an extent of occurrence (EOO) that exceeds 3 million km<sup>2</sup>. The species is abundant and is also, planted for pecan production (agriculture). There are no major threats to the species and it is assessed as not threatened in both countries in the range. The species is globally assessed as Least Concern. Monitoring is needed to check the species response to climate change.
Red List habitat: Pecan trees can grow to be between 30 and 45 m in height (Coladonato 1992). The species grows on rich, well drained, alluvial soils often near river bottoms but not in localities experiencing prolonged flooding (Anderson 2006). It is a subclimax species that is shade intolerant and occurs in mixed deciduous woodland, in association with many other North American tree species (Coladonato 1992).
Red List threats: This species can be affected by some minor pests and diseases (Anderson 2006). In the future, the species is potentially at risk from decline and habitat shifting as a result of climate change (Potter et al. 2017).
Red List population:
The population of this species is assumed to be large and stable due to the wide distribution, large herbarium record and lack of reported threats.

This species is ranked in 'vulnerability class C - high vulnerability, potential persistence' in response to modelled climate change by Potter et al. (2017). Therefore, in the future the population may be subject to decline in the wake of climate change.
Red List range: This species is native to the United States of America and Mexico. In the USA the species is present in southwestern and southern states, from Illinois at the north of the range to Texas and Mississippi in the south (Stone 1997). In Mexico, the species is equally as widespread, being present from Chihuahua and Coahuila to Veracruz and Oaxaca (VillaseÃ±or 2016). This species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 2,363,995 km<sup>2</sup>. The species is cultivated outside of its native range for pecans.
Red List use trade: This species is most widely used and cultivated for pecan nuts, which gives the species its common name. These nuts are used in cooking, often to make deserts. Oil produced from the nut can be further used for cooking or cosmetics (Anderson 2006). The tree itself can also be harvested for timber used in the production of flooring, furniture, panelling and agricultural implements. The tree can be planted in agricultural land for shade and as a food source for livestock. Native Americans also use this plant medicinally, to treat ringworm and tuberculosis.
Red List conservation actions: This species is present in at least 91 botanic gardens (BGCI 2018) and is cultivated widely. This species is assessed as G5- Secure for the USA, in NatureServe (2018) and Least Concern in Mexican Cloud Forest (GonzÃ¡lez-Espinosa et al. 2011).

Red List rationale: Shellbark Hickory (Carya laciniosa) is here assessed as Least Concern because it has a large, stable population which is found across an extensive geographic range with no major threats.
Red List habitat: Shellbark Hickory is a large tree that usually occurs on deep bottom-land soils of rivers and creeks but can less commonly occur on dry, sandy soils and open cedar glades in northern portions of its range. It is a minor component of the bur oak forest and in the South, of the swamp chestnut oak-cherrybark oak forest. It usually occurs in mixtures with various other bottom-land species. Shellbark Hickory prefers bottom-lands and is not as widely distributed as the Shagbark (USDA, NRCS 2018).
Red List threats: There are no major threats affecting or likely to affect Carya laciniosa in the near future.
Red List population: The known population is stable.
Red List range: Shellbark Hickory grows primarily in the Ohio and upper Mississippi River valleys, but the total range is wider, from New England west to southeastern Iowa and to Texas, Oklahoma, Tennessee and Kentucky with isolated populations in southern Arkansas, east Texas, Mississippi, Alabama, and northern Georgia (USDA, NRCS 2018).
Red List use trade: The wood of Shellbark Hickory is hard, heavy, strong, and very flexible, making it a favoured wood for tool handles. It is also desired for furniture, cabinets, and veneer. It is also prized as fuelwood and charcoal (USDA, NRCS 2018).
Red List conservation actions: At this time there are no conservation actions in place for Carya laciniosa because it is a common species and has an extensive geographic range. This taxon is ranked G5 - secure by NatureServe (NatureServe 2018). This species is found in 76 ex situ collections (BGCI 2018).

NatureServe G RANK REASONS: Range is wide but spotty. Not common anywhere in range.
NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: AL(S3); AR(SNR); GA(S1); LA(S4); MS(S3S4); NC(S1); OK(S2S3); SC(S2); TX(SNR)
Red List rationale: Carya myristiciformis is native to the United States and Mexico. The species is widespread and population is considered to be large. In Mexico there is risk to the species due to agricultural activity pressure on habitat and growing threat from illegal logging and fires. Despite this, in the United States, where the majority of the population resides, the habitat and the species is not under threat. This species is globally assessed as Least Concern.
Red List habitat:
Nutmeg Hickory (Carya myristiciformis) is a large tree. It grows on rich moist soils of river bottom-lands, woodlands, bluffs, and hillsides, often on calcareous prairie soils and marl ridges. Nutmeg Hickory is sometimes considered a wetland tree. It is not dominant in any forest cover type in the United States and is only a minor associate in the forest type: Swamp Chestnut Oak-Cherrybark Oak. In this forest type Nutmeg Hickory is associated with Shagbark (C. ovata), Shellbark (C. laciniosa), Mockernut (C. tomentosa) and Bitternut (C. cordiformis) Hickories, White Ash (Fraxinus americana), Shumard Oak (Quercus shumardii) and Black Tupelo (Nyssa sylvatica) (Godfrey and Wooten 1981, Burns and Honkara 1990).

In Mexico, the habitat of the species is under severe threat due to agricultural activities, illegal logging and fires (M. S. Samain pers. comm. 2018).
Red List threats: In Mexico, the remaining localities are threatened by fires and illegal logging. There is also loss of native habitat in some sites due to agricultural activities and expansion. The species is not threatened within its range in the United States.
Red List population: Within Mexico the subpopulation is experiencing decline from threats including, illegal logging, fire and with a few sites affected by agricultural expansion. Within the United States the subpopulations are considered stable.
Red List range: This species is native to North America, particularly the Gulf states of the United States. There is a single population of Carya myristiciformis in North Carolina and there are a few scattered populations in eastern South Carolina, central Alabama and Mississippi, northern Louisiana, southern Arkansas, eastern Texas, and northeastern Mexico (Burns and Honkala 1990, VillaseÃ±or 2016). In Mexico the number of localities of the species is declining (M. S. Samain pers. comm. 2018). The species is abundant only near Selma, Alabama, and in southern Arkansas (Burns and Honkala 1990).
Red List use trade: Carya myristiciformis is too uncommon over most of its range to be of major economic importance. The wood of this hickory is not separated from the wood of other hickories despite its inferior quality (Burns and Honkara 1990).
Red List conservation actions: At this time there are no conservation actions in place. Carya myristiciformis is an uncommon species that is difficult to identify due to the diversity of hickories in the environments where nutmeg hickory occurs. This taxon is ranked G4 - apparently secure by NatureServe (NatureServe 2018). This species is found in 20 ex situ collections (BGCI 2018). In Mexico some individuals are found in the National Park Cumbres de Monterrey.

AL(SNR); AR(SNR); CT(SNR); DC(SNR); DE(SNR); GA(SNR); IA(SNR); IL(SNR); IN(SNR); KS(SNR); KY(SNR); LA(SNR); MA(SNR); MD(SNR); ME(SNR); MI(SNR); MN(SNR); MO(SNR); MS(SNR); NC(SNR); NE(SNR); NH(SNR); NJ(SNR); NY(SNR); OH(SNR); OK(SNR); PA(SNR); RI(SNR); SC(
Red List rationale: Carya ovata is here assessed as Least Concern. Known populations are stable and large and the range of the species is broad. The species is not subject to any major threats.
Red List habitat: Shagbark Hickory is a large tree that is most commonly associated with upland slopes in the north of its range, whereas in its southern United States range it is found within river bottoms and coves. It also grows, less commonly, on the lower slopes of wooded bluffs, in ravines, valleys, and at the edges of swamps. It has an ability to grow in a wide variety of habitats. Shagbark Hickory generally occurs as scattered individuals or in small groups, but rarely forms pure stands (Tirmenstein 1991). In certain floodplain communities, Carya ovata grows as a co-dominant with Black Oak (Quercus velutinus), Green Ash (Fraxinus pennsylvanica) and Northern Red Oak (Quercus rubra) (Tirmenstein 1991).
Red List threats: There are no major threats affecting or likely to affect Shagbark Hickory in the near future.
Red List population: The known population is stable.
Red List range: Shagbark Hickory (Carya ovata) occurs throughout eastern North America where it is native to the United States, Canada and Mexico. Despite this it is absent in from the southeastern and Gulf coastal plains and the lower Mississippi Delta. It is found from southeastern Nebraska and Minnesota eastward through Ontario and Quebec to Maine, and extends southward to Georgia, Alabama, Mississippi, Louisiana and eastern Texas. Disjunct populations have been reported in the mountains of northeastern and central Mexico (VillaseÃ±or 2016).
Red List use trade: The wood of Shagbark Hickory is aesthetically pleasing. It is useful to the production of wheels and spokes and to make furniture, flooring, tool handles, dowels, ladders, and sporting goods (Tirmenstein 1991)<span lang="EN-US">. Shagbark Hickory is also an excellent fuelwood. Furthermore, the wood imparts a hickory-smoked flavor to foods and is often used to make charcoal (Tirmenstein 1991).
Red List conservation actions: At this time there are no conservation actions in place because Carya ovata populations are stable and have a very expansive range. This taxon is ranked G5 - secure by NatureServe (NatureServe 2018). This species is found in 140 ex situ collections (BGCI 2018).

NatureServe G RANK REASONS: Fairly widespread in the United States; frequent; except toward edges of its range.
NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: AL(SNR); AR(S1); DE(S4); FL(SNR); GA(SNR); IL(S1); IN(S1); KY(S4); LA(S2); MA(SNR); MD(S5); MO(S2S3); MS(SNR); NC(S4); NJ(S4); SC(SNR); TN(SNR); VA(S4)
Red List rationale: Carya pallida is a wide spread tree species native to the United States. This large tree has an expansive native range, a stable population and has no major threats. It is assessed as Least Concern.
Red List habitat: Carya pallida is a large tree species, growing to 29 m in height (Stone 1997). The species grows on well-drained sandy or rocky soils, along rolling hills and dry woods.
Red List threats: There are no major threats to this species.
Red List population: Overall, population is considered to be large and stable. On the edges of its range the species is less frequent (NatureServe 2018).
Red List range: This species is endemic to the United States. It occurs in southern states, primarily being found east of the Mississippi river on coastal plains (Nelson et al. 2014). The species occurs at low elevations below 500 m asl and has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of over 860,000 km2.
Red List use trade: The seeds of this tree are edible and the bark has some medicinal use (Moerman 1998). The wood can be utilised for tool handles (Sargent 1965).
Red List conservation actions: This species occurs in at least 16 ex situ collections (BGCI 2018). The species is assessed as G5- Secure by NatureServe (2018).

NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: AL(SNR); AR(SNR); GA(SNR); IL(S2S3); IN(SH); KS(S2); LA(SNR); MO(SNR); MS(SNR); OK(SNR); TN(SNR); TX(SNR); WV(SNR)
Red List rationale: Black Hickory is endemic to the United States of America where it occurs in the south west of the country. It has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 603,839 km<sup>2</sup>. There are no major threats to the species. It is globally assessed as Least Concern.
Red List habitat: This large tree can grow to 41 meters in height. It grows on well-drained sandy soils on hillsides and some flat lands (Stone 1997).
Red List threats: The species should be monitored for the impact of climate change which may become a threat in the future (Potter et al. 2017). It may also be at risk from genetic intogression with other native Carya spp. which this species can hybridise with.
Red List population:
There is no explicit population information for this species but NatureServe (2018) states the species is 'apparently secure', with local rarity in Kansas, Illinois, and Indiana, so population is assumed to be stable.

In the future the population may be at risk from the impacts of climate change. In their 2017 study, Potter et al. categorised the species in 'Vulnerability class C- High vulnerability, with potential persistence.'
Red List range: This species is endemic to the United States of America. It grows in southern and southwestern states including; Arkansas, Illinois, Kansas, Louisiana, Mississippi, Missouri, Oklahoma and Texas (Stone 1997). It has an extent of occurrence (EOO) 603,839 km<sup>2</sup>.
Red List use trade: This species is used for fuelwood. The seed are also edible.
Red List conservation actions: This species is reported from 12 ex situ collections (BGCI 2018). It is also assessed as G4- Apparently Secure for NatureServe (2018) and locally endangered by the state government of Indiana (USDA 2018). Monitoring the species in the wake of global warming and climate change would be valuable as it has been identified as potentially vulnerable to these changes.

Red List rationale: Mockernut Hickory (Carya tomentosa) is here assessed as Least Concern. The species has a large, stable population which is found across an extensive range. There are also no major threats to the species.
Red List habitat: Carya tomentosa is a large tree that grows on rocky hills and slopes and less frequently on alluvial bottomlands. It grows best on dry sites with deep fertile soils. This species grows alongside other species of hickory (Carya spp.) and also oaks (Quercus spp.). It is also commonly associated with Eastern Hop Hornbeam (Ostrya virginiana), Sweet Birch (Betula lenta), Flowering Dogwood (Cornus florida) and Fraxinus americana (Coladonato 1992). The species is shade intolerant and is often a climax tree species. It exhibits reproduction through seed but is also a prolific sprouter (Coladonato 1992).
Red List threats: There are no threats affecting or likely to affect Carya tomentosa in the near future.
Red List population: The known population is stable. The species is most abundant in Virginia, North Carolina and Florida and in the lower Mississippi Valley (Stone 1997).
Red List range: Carya tomentosa is found throughout the eastern United States to the Midwest and southern Gulf states (Stone 1997). This species occurs at elevations to 900 m asl.
Red List use trade: The majority of the timber produced by this species is used to manufacture tool handles. It can also be used to produce agricultural implements, dowels, sports equipment, poles and furniture. Wood may also be used for lumber, pulpwood, charcoal, and fuelwood. The species also has use in the culinary industry; sawdust and woodchips are used to smoke meats while the Mockernut Hickory kernels are edible, though rarely eaten. The species is also planted for watershed protection (Coladonato 1992).
Red List conservation actions: This species is found in 66 ex situ collections (BGCI 2018). There are no conservation actions needed across the range at present.

NatureServe G RANK REASONS: Widespread; abundant as young shoots; but now seldom reaching reproductive maturity due to an introduced fungus; the chestnut blight.
NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: AL(SNR); CT(SNR); DC(S1S2); DE(S4); FL(SX); GA(S3); IA(SNA); IL(SX); IN(S1); KY(S1?); MA(SNR); MD(S2S3); ME(S4); MI(S1S2); MO(SNR); MS(S1); NC(S4); NH(SNR); NJ(S4); NY(S5); OH(S3); PA(S5); RI(SNR); SC(SNR); TN(S2S3); VA(S4); VT(SNR); WI(SNR); WV(S4)
Red List rationale: Castanea dentata is a North American tree species that formerly dominated eastern forests in the US and was of great importance to rural livelihoods. The species is here assessed as Critically Endangered due to the large and rapid declines (90-99%) in population size over the last three generations (or less) due to Chestnut Blight disease. Castanea dentata remains under threat from this disease which continues to limit the population growth leaving sprouting from stumps as the main known individuals of the species. Major efforts are underway to conserve the species. Future research needs to establish a better understanding of the disease and potential ways to induce resistance in the population. Ex situ conservation will be essential in preventing this species becoming extinct.
Red List habitat: This tree was formerly one of the most important, largest, and most abundant forest trees in the mountains of eastern North America, found in the Eastern hardwood forest. Subpopulations are small and persist in localities through sprouting from stumps, before possibly flowering and fruiting, and then dying back again from blight. Flowering occurs between June and July. The species was previously common in rich deciduous and mixed forests, particularly with oak, but now persists in isolated and fragmented populations (eFloras 1997).
Red List threats: Castanea dentata has been severely affected by Chestnut Clight, a bark fungal disease that probably entered the U.S. from Japan in the late 1890s. Chestnut Blight is not just associated with shoot dieback; it kills twigs and branches of any size. It is caused by a fungus, Cryphonectria parasitica (=Endothia parasitica). By 1950, 99.9% of American Chestnuts were reduced to either dead stumps or stumps with adventitious sprouts arising from the roots surrounding them. Many of these stumps persist today and are still sending up diseased sprouts (Missouri Botanical Garden 2018).
Red List population: The known population is in decline due to Chestnut Blight. Chestnut Blight, introduced in the 1800s, reduced the population of American Chestnuts to 0.01% of its original size by 1950 (Missouri Botanical Garden 2018). The population was estimated to historically consist of 4.2 billion trees. In 2016, the estimated stems is approximately 10% of the estimated pre-blight population, however, 84% of these stems are <2.5 cm dbh (Dalgleish et al. 2015). The blight does not affect the roots of the species, so the blight did not cause the extinction of C. dentata, however, it did effectively extirpate the species from the canopy, causing it to be functionally extinct (Dalgleish et al. 2015). The generation length of this long lived tree is thought to be over 100 years, so the reduction has taken place in the last two generations, and it is assumed that the population was stable prior to the introduction of blight.
Red List range: This species is found from southern Ontario, east to Maine, south to Georgia and Florida, west to Mississippi and Louisiana, and north to Missouri and Illinois. The highest population was known in the southern Appalachian Mountains until Chestnut Blight decimated population numbers. However, distribution may have spread from pre-blight distributions, due to human location.
Red List use trade:
The sweet seed of this tree can be used as food, both raw or cooked. It can be dried, ground into powder and then added to cereals when making bread, cakes etc. A delicious oil can be extracted from the seed by crushing the nuts, boiling them in water and then skimming off the oil as it comes to the surface. It can be used as a topping for various puddings. The roasted nut can be used as a coffee substitute and a chocolate substitute can also be made from it (Plants for a Future 2018).

The bark is an exceptionally good source of tannin and the dried leaves contain 9% tannin as well as the wood and seed husks containing significant levels of tannin with the husks containing between 10â13% tannin. A brown dye can be obtained from the bark as well.

The wood is soft and not that strong, light, liable to warp, but very durable with it weighing approximately 28 lb per cubic foot. It is used for making cheap furniture, fence posts and for construction (Plants for a Future 2018). It was of major significance to rural economies in the past.
Red List conservation actions: Chinese Chestnut has been crossed with American Chestnut to try to create a more resistant population to Chestnut Blight. They are then back crossing the American Chestnuts with aim to create a disease resistant American Chestnut hybrid, that is genetically 99% American Chestnut (Missouri Botanical Garden 2018). There has also been attempts to control the blight with biocontrol and genetic engineering (Jacobs et al. 2013). Due to these efforts restoration is now underway. This species is found in 73 ex situ collections (BGCI 2018). It is listed as G4 Apparently Secure by NatureServe (NatureServe 2017), and Endangered in Canada (COSEWIC 2005).

NatureServe G RANK REASONS: Widespread species; varietal form restricted to narrow range largely within the Ozark Highlands; where threatened by chestnut blight.

Red List rationale: The species is widespread and while it is possibly declining in parts of its range, it is not thought that any global population decline is likely to meet (or be close to meeting) the threshold for Vulnerable. Therefore the species is assessed as Least Concern.
Red List habitat: The species grows in fens (calcium-rich <span id="gloss1" class="gloss">wetlands), marshes, meadows and fields, shores of rivers or lakes and wetland margins (New England Wild Flower Society 2011-2015).
Red List threats: There is no information on the threats to this species.
Red List population: The species is classed as globally 'Secure' by NatureServe (2014), however the populations in some states in the USA are classed as 'Critically Imperiled', 'Imperiled' or 'Vulnerable'. The Canadian Endangered Species Conservation Council (CESCC 2011+) also class the species as 'Secure' (for Canada only).
Red List range: The species is widespread across Canada, northern, central and western USA, Greenland and Eurasia (NatureServe 2014; Klinkenberg 2014).
Red List use trade: This herb was used by the Chippewa and Ojibwa to treat dysentery and stomach  cramps, and a tea of the leaves was used as a tea by Alaskan natives  before imported tea became available (New England Wild Flower Society 2011-2015).
Red List conservation actions: No conservation actions for the species are known. More information would be useful on the species' population status and threats across its range.

Red List rationale: There are no known threats that are or will adversely affect Corylus americana in the foreseeable future. Climate change will extirpate it at its westernmost distribution. This will be offset with its northern range limits expanding further north in Manitoba, Ontario, Quebec and east into the maritime provinces in Canada. In the southern Appalachian Mountains it will move up in elevation. It is assessed as Least Concern.
Red List habitat:
Shrubs growing to about four metres tall, strongly rhizomatous and forming colonial thickets. It occurs in moist to dry woodlands, savannas, prairies and sandy thickets, forest openings and borders, roadsides, fields, hedgerows, railroad right-of-ways, fence rows and other ruderal areas. It grows in a number of soil types but does best in rich, moist soils  It is generally encountered in open habitats but may also be found growing in deep shade. This species flowers in March to May before leaf emergence and fruits in late summer. 

It is documented as occurring in the following Society of American Foresters cover types: 1 (Jack pine), 5 (Balsam fir) ,12 (Black spruce), 13 (Black spruce - tamarack), 14 (Northern pin oak), 15 (Red pine), 16 (Aspen), 17 (Pin cherry), 18 (Paper birch), 20 (White pine - northern red oak - red maple), 21 (Eastern white pine), 22 (White pine - hemlock), 23 (Eastern hemlock), 24 (Hemlock - yellow birch), 25 (Sugar maple - beech - yellow birch), 26 (Sugar maple - basswood), 27 (Sugar maple), 30 (Red spruce - yellow birch), 31 (Red spruce - sugar maple - beech), 32 (Red spruce), 35 (Paper birch - red spruce - balsam fir), 39 (Black ash - American elm - red maple), 40 (Post oak - blackjack oak), 42 (Bur oak), 43 (Bear oak), 44 (Chestnut oak), 51 (White pine - chestnut oak), 52 (White oak - black oak - northern red oak), 53 (White oak), 55 (Northern red oak), 57 (Yellow-poplar), 58 (Yellow-poplar - eastern hemlock), 59 (Yellow-poplar - white oak - northern red oak), 60 (Beech - sugar maple), 62 (Silver maple - American elm), 76 (Shortleaf pine - oak), 78 (Virginia pine - oak), 108 (Red maple) and 110 (Black oak).

Corylus americana is a weedy species, sometimes considered a pest in carefully managed forests.
Red List threats: There are no known current threats to the species.  However, future effects of climate change will most likely increase the upper elevation limit of 750 m asl and lead to its distribution being shifted east and north. NatureServe ranks this species as globally secure. This species is not affected by any serious pests. Several canker-forming fungi may result in girdling or breakage of stems. Mildew may defoliate plants and fungi may destroy nuts.
Red List population: A very common species throughout its range. However, there are no hard data on population numbers due to it being common and not an important timber species.
Red List range: The species has an extensive distribution in eastern North America. In Canada it is known from the provinces of Manitoba, Ontario and Quebec. It may be extirpated from Quebec. It is reported as occurring in the province of Saskatchewan, Canada, however this has been considered doubtful. In the United States America it occurs from Maine west to North Dakota, south through eastern South Dakota, Nebraska, Kansas and Oklahoma in the west, east across the north portions of Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama and Georgia, not occurring in the Gulf Coastal Plain, and north into New England.
Red List use trade:
There is limited trade of the species. It has been cultivated as an ornamental since 1798. It is also commercially cultivated for nut production, the sweet nuts may be eaten raw or ground and made into a cake like bread. It is sometimes used in wildlife habitat improvement projects. The USDA Plant Material Center in Elsberry, Missouri, USA has released Sun Harvest Germplasm Corylus americana. This release was developed for windbreaks and wildlife food and habitat. The nuts of this species, which have a higher nutritional value than acorns and beechnuts, also are eaten by squirrels, foxes, deer, northern bobwhite, ruffed grouse, turkey, woodpeckers, pheasants and deer. The leaves, twigs and catkins are browsed by rabbits, deer and moose. The make catkins are a winter food for turkey and ruffed grouse. The dense, low growth  habit provides cover and nesting sites for many wildlife species. 

Native Americans used Corylus americana medicinally for hives, biliousness, diarrhoea, cramps, hay fever, childbirth, haemorrhages, prenatal strength and teething, to induce vomiting and to heal cuts
Red List conservation actions: There are no reported conservation actions in place or necessary for this species.

NatureServe CANADIAN PROVINCES AND S RAN: AB(S5); BC(S5); MB(S5); NB(S5); NF(S4); NS(S5); ON(S5); PE(S5); QC(S5); SK(S4)
Red List rationale: Corylus cornuta is a North American shrub. It has a wide distribution and there are no known threats. It is therefore assessed as Least Concern.
Red List habitat: A shrub up to 3 m tall, it is found in thickets, open woods and landscapes disturbed by fire and logging. It is moderately shade tolerant. Beaked Hazel is an early successional species but can also be found in forests that are in later stages of succession. Populations decline with the recruitment of more shade tolerant species as the canopy closes. It prefers neutral to acidic soil, wet-mesic to dry-mesic and does not grow well on fine-textured clays or wet soils such as peats.
Red List threats: There are no range wide threats reported for this species.
Red List population: A very common species across most of its range. However, there is no hard data on  population numbers due to it being common and not an important  commercial species. This species is listed as Globally Secure by NatureServe, however, populations in Ohio are Possible Extirpated, those in Delaware are Critically Imperiled, those in Wyoming are imperiled and those in Louisiana Newfoundland and Maryland are Vulnerable.
Red List range: This species is found in Canada and the United States.
Red List use trade:
This species is commercially grown for the edible nuts. They can be roasted, candied or added to other foods, they can also be made into oil or ground into flour. This tree is also used in wildlife habitat plantings to provide cover and nuts, which are eaten by squirrels, deer, grouse and pheasant.

C. cornuta was used medicinally by Native Americans as an emetic, for teething, to expel worms, to heal cuts, and as an astringent. The wood was used to make bows, tools, fish traps and baby carriers. Young, straight suckers used to make arrows, and peeled and twisted to make ropes. The roots and inner bark produce a blue dye when steeped in water.

This species has limited ornamental value and cultivars apparently have not been developed. 

This species is removed by growers of commercial, closely managed forests, primarily because of its aggressive colonial habit and corresponding competition with timber trees.
Red List conservation actions: There are no reported conservation actions in place for this species.

NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: AZ(SNR); CA(SNR); NM(SNR); TX(SNR)
Red List rationale: Cucurbita digitata is globally assessed as Least Concern â although it occurs at low density, it is common and widespread in northern Mexico and the United States of America. It occurs in a range of habitats, including some disturbed sites, and in several protected areas, which presents an opportunity to establish active in situ conservation actions to ensure its survival.
Red List habitat: This species occurs in hot, arid or semi-arid regions with sandy, gravelly and alluvial soils. In these desert regions, periods of drought of more than 20 months can be observed. It can grow in Larrea desert, often with Acacia, Cercidium and Yucca, grasslands with Atriplex, mesquite, juniper-scrub, tropical deciduous forests, and infrequently in oak savannas. It can be seen on canal banks, stream bottoms and sides, wash and arroyo banks, dry stream channels, alluvial plains, rocky slopes, disturbed sites and roadsides (Bemis and Whitaker 1969, Felger 2000, Lira and RodrÃ­guez-ArÃ©valo 2006, Lira et al. 2009, Nesom 2016).
Red List threats:
In some areas, urban sprawl and road construction are affecting this species, and in the southernmost reported distribution range, drought is are restricting its presence. The intensification of pesticides and herbicides use in extensive agriculture (scale larger than 5 ha) is also a major threat to this species (R. Bye and E. Linares pers. comm. 2018).
The cultivation of genetically modified squashes (Cucurbita pepo Virus Resistant, or C. pepoVR) in Mexico is a potential threat to other wild and domesticated Cucurbita species due to the risk of hybridisation between these species and C. pepoVR in the event it escapes its cultivation area. The risk for the members of the Group Digitata (C. digitata, C. cordata and C. palmata) is, however, low. This is because there is a deficient compatibility, differences in reproductive systems and floral phenology with C. pepo, besides the specificity of pollination bees (Bemis and Whitaker 1969, Arriaga et al. 2006, Lira et al. 2009).
Red List population: Subpopulations of Cucurbita digitata can be found throughout the year within its distribution range. It occurs at low densities in Mexico but is common, widespread and abundant in the United States of America, where it has been ranked as Secure (Lira and RodrÃ­guez-ArÃ©valo 2006, NatureServe 2015). The subpopulation status in Mexico is not known, but it has not been found during recent explorations in its southernmost reported range where droughts are more frequent.
Red List range: The native distribution of Cucurbita digitata comprises southwestern United States of America and northwestern Mexico (Lira and RodrÃ­guez-ArÃ©valo 2006, USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017). It is found at altitudes from 100 m asl, but more commonly between 300 to 1,500 m asl (Bemis and Whitaker 1969, Nesom 2016).
Red List use trade: It is a tertiary wild relative of, and potential gene donor to cushaw, fig leaf gourd, maxima pumpkin/squash, moschata pumkin/squash and pepo pumpkin/squash (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017). Along with the other species of the phylogenetic group Digitata (Cucurbita cordata and C. palmata), it has proved to be resistant to viruses affecting the cultivated taxa, such as cucumber mosaic virus (CMV) and tobacco ringspot virus (TRSV) (OECD 2012). Moreover, seeds of the species in this group have high content of oil and protein, qualities that can be of interest in future genetic improvement of the related crops (Bemis et al. 1967, Provvidenti et al. 1978, Lira et al. 2009). No local use has been reported.
Red List conservation actions: It occurs in some protected areas within its native range in Arizona, United States of America, namely Chiricahua National Monument, Coronado National Monument, Fort Bowie National Historic Site, Organ Pipe Cactus Biosphere Reserve and Tonto National Monument (Information Centre for the Environment 2017). It might occur in Parque Nacional Delta del RÃ­o Colorado in Mexico, although this needs to be confirmed. Ex situ conservation is limited. There are two accessions recorded in the Plant Genetic Resources Conservation Unit, Griffin, Georgia and in the Millennium Seed Bank Project, Seed Conservation Department, Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew (Genesys Global Portal on Plant Genetic Resources 2017, USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017).

Red List rationale: Cucurbita foetidissima is globally assessed as Least Concern as it is a common, widespread species in Mexico and the United States of America that occurs in a range of habitats, including disturbed habitats, and its population is thought to be stable. Its presence in several protected areas is an opportunity to establish active in situ management and monitoring to ensure its long-term survival.
Red List habitat: It grows in sandy fields, xerophytic shrublands, grasslands, mesquite scrub and pinyon-juniper floodplain woods, as well as on hills (including gypsum hills) and dunes, in rocky, calcareous clay loam soils. It is also very frequent in disturbed areas, roadsides, railroad banks and as a weed (Rzedowiski and Rzedowiski 2005, Lira and RodrÃ­guez-ArÃ©valo 2006, Nesom 2016).
Red List threats: Urban sprawl is reducing the suitable habitat for the species in some areas. The intensification of pesticides and herbicides use in extensive agriculture (scale larger than 5 ha) is also a major threat to this species (R. Bye and E. Linares pers. comm. 2018).
Red List population: This species is widespread and abundant throughout its range, so it has been ranked as globally secure (Lira and RodrÃ­guez-ArÃ©valo 2006, NatureServe 2015).
Red List range: Cucurbita foetidissima is a widespread species, growing from western and central United States of America (Utah, Colorado, Nebraska, Kansas, Missouri, California, Arizona, New Mexico, Oklahoma, Texas and Arkansas) to central Mexico (Baja California, Sonora, Chihuahua, Coahuila, Nuevo LeÃ³n, Tamaulipas, Sinaloa, Durango, Zacatecas, Aguascalientes, San Luis PotosÃ­, Jalisco, Guanajuato, Guerrero, Hidalgo, QuerÃ©taro and Estado de MÃ©xico). It grows at altitudes from 100 m to approximately 2,250 m asl (VillaseÃ±or and Espinosa 1998, Lira et al. 2002, Lira and RodrÃ­guez-ArÃ©valo 2006, USDA-NRCS 2016, USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017).
Red List use trade: It is a tertiary wild relative of, and potential gene donor to cushaw, fig leaf gourd, maxima pumpkin/squash, moschata pumkin/squash and pepo pumpkin/squash (Lira and Caballero 2002, Lira and RodrÃ­guez-ArÃ©valo 2006, USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017). It also has a variety of direct uses. Its leaves, fruits and roots are used as medicine and fodder, the fruit and roots are used as a soap substitute, and its seeds can be used as a beverage base (Lira and Caballero 2002). It is also a potential source of fuel (petroleum substitute), oil and starch (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017).
Red List conservation actions: This species occurs in several protected areas throughout its range. In the United States of America it is present in 29 protected areas in California, New Mexico, Arizona, Kansas, Texas, Colorado, Missouri and Utah. In Mexico, it occurs in the protected areas Area de ProtecciÃ³n de Flora y Fauna Cuatro CiÃ©negas, Biosphere Reserve Janos, Area de ProtecciÃ³n de Flora y Fauna Ocampo and Area de ProtecciÃ³n de Flora y Fauna MÃ©danos Samalayuca (Instituto Nacional de EcologÃ­a 1999, SEMARNAT-CONANP 2013a,b, 2015; Information Centre for the Environment 2016). There are 21 accessions conserved in the National Arid Land Plant Genetic Resources Unit, Parlier, California, 10 of which are also conserved by the National Centre for Genetic Resources Preservation, Fort Collins, Colorado. Additionally, two accessions are stored in the Leibniz Institute of Plant Genetics and Crop Plant Research, Germany, five in a genebank in the Czech Republic and five in the Millennium Seed Bank, Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew (Genesys Global Portal on Plant Genetic Resources 2016, USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017).
