Red List rationale: Cucurbita palmata is distributed in a relatively small area in Mexico and the United States of America but is globally assessed as Data Deficient as there is currently insufficient information on its population size and trend, and the extent and quality of its habitat.
Red List habitat: This perennial herb occurs in hot, arid or semi-arid regions with sandy, gravelly and alluvial soils. In these regions, periods of drought of more than 20 months can be observed. It can grow in a range of habitats, including tropical deciduous forests, rocky lake shores, washes, stream beds and overflow channels, lava beds, roadsides, waste places, alkali plains, creosote bush scrub, saltbush scrub, grassland-saltbush scrub, annual grasslands, mezquite desert, chaparral-desert scrub and upland desert scrub (Bemis and Whitaker 1969, Lira et al. 2009, Nesom 2016, Calflora 2017, USDA-NRCS 2017).
Red List threats: An increased fire regime (associated with climate change) could possibly affect the species but this has not been studied in detail. The cultivation of genetically modified squashes (Cucurbita pepo Virus Resistant, or C. pepoVR) in Mexico is a potential threat to other wild and domesticated Cucurbita species due to the risk of hybridisation between these species and C. pepoVR in the event it escapes its cultivation area. The risk for the members of the phylogenetic group Digitata (C. digitata, C. cordata and C. palmata) is, however, low. This is because there is a deficient compatibility, differences in reproductive systems and floral phenology with C. pepo, besides the specificity of pollination bees (Bemis and Whitaker 1969, Arriaga et al. 2006, Lira et al. 2009). The intensification of pesticides and herbicides use in extensive agriculture (scale larger than 5 ha) is also a major threat to this species (R. Bye and E. Linares pers. comm. 2018).
Red List population: Subpopulations of this species can be found throughout the year  within its distribution range. It is uncommon but not rare and has been ranked as Apparently Secure in the United  States of America. However, it was ranked as Critically                                    Imperiled in <span id="lblTaxonDesc">Utah, being at a very high risk of extinction in this state (Lira and RodrÃ­guez-ArÃ©valo 2006, NatureServe 2015).
Red List range: The native distribution of Cucurbita palmata comprises the southwestern United States of America and northern Mexico (Lira and RodrÃ­guez-ArÃ©valo 2006, Lira et al. 2009, USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017). It can be found in low arid plains at elevations from 10 to 1,340 m asl (Lira and RodrÃ­guez-ArÃ©valo 2006, Nesom 2016).
Red List use trade: It is a tertiary wild relative of, and potential gene donor to cushaw, fig leaf gourd, maxima pumpkin/squash, moschata pumkin/squash and pepo pumpkin/squash (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017). Along with the other species of the phylogenetic Group Digitata (Cucurbita cordata and C. digitata), it has proved to be resistant to viruses affecting the cultivated taxa, such as cucumber mosaic virus (CMV) and tobacco ringspot virus (TRSV) (OECD 2012). Moreover, seeds of the species in this group have high content of oil and protein, qualities that can be of interest in future genetic improvement of the related crops (Bemis et al. 1967, Provvidenti 1978, Lira et al. 2009). There are no reported local uses of this species.
Red List conservation actions: It occurs in some protected areas within its native range in Mexico, including the Biosphere Reserve Alto Golfo de California y Delta del RÃ­o Colorado (CONANP 2007). Genesys Global Portal on Plant Genetic Resources (2017) reports only five accessions held by the Leibniz Institute of Plant Genetics and Crop Plant Research. Germplasm collection and duplicated ex situ collection is a priority for this species.

Red List rationale: Daucus pusillus is widespread throughout its native region. This is a common species and occurs in a variety of habitats and over a range of altitudes and, within its very large extent of occurrence (EOO), of over 44 million km2, the area of occupancy (AOO) is also exceeds the values for a threatened category. Due to its extensive range in its native region and the absence of threats, the population is inferred to be large and stable.  This species is therefore assessed as Least Concern.
Red List habitat: This species is an annual with 50-100 cm tall stem, which grows in grasslands, dry sandy soils, rocky ground and disturbed areas, as well as along roadsides and railways (USDA, NRCS 2017). It occurs at elevations from sea level to 2,000 m asl. (Camadro et al. 2008, Hoagland et al. 2004).
Red List threats: There are no known threats to this species.
Red List population: The population size and trend for this species remains largely unknown, however this species has been recorded in numerous locations in the last few years, especially in the west coast of the U.S.A., as well as common and widespread in Texas (USDA, NRCS 2017).  With this limited evidence it is suspected that this species is stable across its global native range, though comprehensive survey work should be undertaken to confirm this.
Red List range: The native distribution of this species is northern and southern America (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017).
Red List use trade: This species is a wild relative of, and potential gene donor to the crop carrot. Native Americans <span class="copy">used this species as a talisman in gambling, and used the roots for food purposes. A poultice of the chewed plant would be applied to snakebites as a treatment (Moerman 1998).
Red List conservation actions:
The genus Daucus is listed in Annex I of the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture (ITPGRFA) which aims to guarantee sustainable agriculture and food security through the conservation and sustainable use of plant genetic resources for food and agriculture, as well as ensuring the fair and equitable sharing of the benefits arising out of their use (FAO 2009).

Genesys (2017) states there are forty seven germplasm accessions held between America, United Kingdom, Spain and Netherlands. Seed is also conserved in the Svalbard Global Seed Vault (four germplasm accession comprising 3400 seeds).  According to Botanic Gardens Conservation International (BGCI 2017) this species has twelve living collections in botanical gardens worldwide, although the size of the collections are not detailed in this resource.

This species' native distribution overlaps with several protected areas, inferred using GeoCAT (Bachman et al. 2011) and so passive conservation is presumed in this area. However, there is no evidence of active management or monitoring of this species.

Red List rationale: The species is widespread and while it is possibly declining in parts of its range, it is not thought that any global population decline is likely to meet (or be close to meeting) the threshold for Vulnerable. Therefore the species is assessed as Least Concern.
Red List habitat: There is no information on the habitats and ecology of this species.
Red List threats: The threats to the species are unknown.
Red List population: The species is classed as globally 'Secure' by NatureServe (2014), however the populations in some Provinces in Canada are classed as 'Imperiled' or 'Vulnerable'.
Red List range: The species is widespread across Canada, USA and Mexico. It has been introduced into Asia-Temperate and Europe (eMonocot Team 2015).
Red List use trade: There is no information on the use or trade of this species.
Red List conservation actions: No conservation actions for the species are known. More information would be useful on the species' population status and threats across its range.

AZ(SNR)
Red List rationale: Gossypium thurberi occurs at five locations within a restricted area of occupancy of less than 400 km2. There are about 5,000 mature individuals which occur in small patches of 15â30 individuals. The population is decreasing due to habitat loss and degradation related to mining and fracking activities and land use change for agriculture. Hence, the species qualifies for listing as Endangered under the criteria B2ab(i,ii,iii).
Red List habitat: This species grows in open, arid habitats on the banks of seasonal streams, in rocky canyons, on hillsides, on slopes in riparian areas, and in grasslands (Shreve and Wiggis 1964, Fryxell and Hill 2016, USDA Forest Service 2016). It temporarily benefits from the disturbance caused by the construction of new roads as it grows in the newly created soil mounds. However, these are not permanent sites for the species.
Red List threats: This species is affected by mining and fracking activities. There is also land use change for agriculture in the area that is reducing the extent and quality of its habitat.
Red List population: Gossypium thurberi occurs in small patches of 15 to 30 individuals. It has been ranked as apparently secure in Arizona, United States of America (NatureServe 2015). There are about 5,000 mature individuals, but the population is decreasing due to habitat loss.
Red List range: Gossypium thurberi has a very restricted distribution range. It is found in southwestern United States of America (Arizona) and in northern Mexico (Chihuahua and Sonora) at altitudes from 800 to 2,400 m asl (Wegier et al. 2009, Fryxell and Hill 2016, USDA, ARS National Genetic Resources Program 2016).
Red List use trade: It is a tertiary wild relative of, and potential gene donor to Cotton, Sea Island Cotton, Short-staple Cotton and Tree Cotton (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017). It is also used as ornamental plant (USDA, ARS National Genetic Resources Program 2013, Vincent et al. 2013, USDA Forest Service 2016).
Red List conservation actions: This species occurs in the protected area of Tonto National Monument, Arizona, United States of America. There are around 450 accessions in different cotton germplasm collections worldwide (Campbell et al. 2010). Twenty accessions are maintained by the Crop Germplasm Research (Cotton Collection), College Station, Texas (Information Centre for the Environment (ICE) 2000, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2016). Further ex situ conservation is recommended for this species.

NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: HI(S2)

NatureServe G RANK REASONS: The current known range is confined to Florida although historically the species was also found in south Georgia. Described as being frequent in central Florida by Wunderlin (1982).

NatureServe CANADIAN PROVINCES AND S RAN: AB(S4); BC(SNA); MB(S3); NB(SNA); NS(SNA); NT(SNA); ON(SNA); PE(SNA); QC(SNA); SK(S4)
Red List rationale: Helianthus annuus is a common, widespread species within its native range, adapted to several habitats and a wide range of environmental contitions, it is also extensively adventive. It also occurs in several protected areas and germplasm of this species is conserved in ex situ collections; it is therefore globally assessed as Least Concern.
Red List habitat: Wild populations can be found in river floodplains and stream banks (Lentz et al. 2008). It grows in well drained, heavy, clayey soils (Reiseberg et al. 1995) and can tolerate soil pH from 5.7 to more than 8 (Putnam et al. 1990). In Mexico, the species is found in wet to dry open areas, as well as on roadsides and other disturbed sites, along streams and irrigation channels as well as a crop weed (GÃ³mez and GonzÃ¡lez 1995). Wild populations in Mexico are found in dry scrubland (Lentz et al. 2008).
Red List threats: Helianthus annuus is potentially threatened by the decline of managed and wild colonies of invertebrate pollinators due to pathogens, pesticides, transgenic crops, invasive plant and pollinator species and habitat loss, leading to a low fecundity (limitation of seed production) (Kremen et al. 2002, Committee on the Status of Pollinators in North America 2007).
Red List population: This species is widespread in North America; it is common,  widespread and abundant, so is ranked as globally secure (NatureServe 2015).
Red List range: Helianthus annuus is a widespread species that is native to western areas of Canada, north, central and south of the United States, and northern Mexico as elevations between sea level and 3,000 m a.s.l.; it is also widely naturalized and cultivated, in some areas it is present as a weed or invasive species (Heiser et al. 1969, GÃ³mez and GonzÃ¡lez 1995, VillaseÃ±or and Espinosa 1998, Schilling 2006, Lentz et al. 2008, Pruski and Robinson 2015, USDA-NRCS 2016, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2016).
Red List use trade: Helianthus annuus is an attractive plant to pollinating bees for the collection of nectar and pollen (USDA 2015). The species is widely cultivated with many uses, having edible seeds, being processed as an oil or fat source for human consumption, as well as being used as animal fodder and as a possible alternative fuel source, it is also used as an ornamental plant (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2016). Wild H. annuus is considered a primary genetic relative of the cultivated Sunflower and so it has the potential for use as a gene donor for crop improvement (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resource Program 2016). H. annuus is also important in traditional native American cultures as a medicinal plant (Foster and Duke 2000, Vibrans 2009, BDMTM 2009).
Red List conservation actions: This species is recorded as present within at least 83 protected areas within its native range in the United States of America (Information Center for the Environment (ICE) 2016). In Mexico, it occurs in the protected areas Parque Nacional Cumbres de Monterrey, Nuevo LeÃ³n (CONANP 2006). There are at least 943 germplasm accessions of wild Helianthus annuus conserved in the North Central Regional PI Station, Iowa State University, with duplicates in the National Center for Genetic Resources Preservation, Fort Collins (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2016).

NatureServe G RANK REASONS: Colorado Plateau and Great Basin; widespread; but often in low numbers at particular sites.
NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: AZ(S2); NM(SNR); NV(S2); UT(S3)
Red List rationale:
This species is globally assessed as Vulnerable D1 because it was only found to occur in two localities after a survey in 2000 (Seiler 2007), a dramatic decrease from the 25 localities found in 1983 by Nabhan and Reichardt (1983), with one subpopulation containing 200 individuals and the other containing 250 (i.e. fewer than 1,000 mature individuals). As this species is thought to occur in only two localities, and such dramatic declines in subpopulations having been recorded, it is possible that these two localities are under threat and criterion D2 would then also apply. However, more information is required to confirm this.

Survey work should be undertaken for this species as an urgent priority to determine its extent of occurrence (EOO), area of occupancy (AOO) and whether or not there is continuing decline in population size as, with additional data, there is potential for this species to be classified as Endangered under criterion B (number of locations less than five and likely decline in EOO, AOO and number of subpopulations) and criterion C (number of mature individuals less than 2,500 and less than or equal to 250 mature individuals in each subpopulation).

Considering the potential for this species to be classified as Endangered with more data available, efforts to provide active conservation both in situ and ex situ are urgently required to secure this resource in the long-term. Surveys within protected areas that are thought to contain the species would also be beneficial to determine whether any parts of the species range are already receiving some level of in situ conservation. Investigation into the threats facing the two subpopulations would help to estimate whether there is any ongoing decline in population size and would also help to determine the rate of decline.
Red List habitat: This xerophytic species is found in sand dunes and swales between 1,000 and 2,000 m a.s.l., on open, disturbed, field soils and under sand dune agriculture in the southern part of its range (NatureServe 2013). Nabhan (1989) identified populations of the anomalous sunflower on top of the mesas (flat topped hills or mountains, otherwise known as tableland) within the Hopi Indian Reserve, Arizona, although it is not known whether this population is introduced.
Red List threats:
The reasons for the scarcity of this species described by Selier (2007) are unknown, although the same author notes that it had been an extremely dry year and that there was no evidence of the species being present in the fragile sandy habitat. Selier (2007) hypothesises that because several sand dune habitats had become popular off-road vehicle recreational areas, this may have posed a serious threat to the species' already fragile existence. 

According to NatureServe (2013) more general threats to this species include the total abandonment of agricultural fields and road construction. 

Furthermore, given this species' affiliation with arable land and the partial dependence of some populations on active conservation by members of the Hopi tribe, modernization or mechanization (in particular the use of pre-emergent herbicides or frequent, deep ploughing with tractors) of Hopi agriculture could pose a plausible threat to this species (Nabhan 1989).
Red List population:
In 1983 this species was known from less than 25 localities across a geographic range of 46,000 km2 in Utah and Arizona (Nabhan and Reichhardt 1983). The same authors noted that five of the seven populations visited at the time had 250 individuals or less, and one was destined for destruction by road construction. 

Since that time, a 'perplexing scarcity' of plants at all 25 previously known sites has been documented by Selier (2007) from a collecting expedition carried out in the year 2000. Only two localities, both in the northwest part of the species' range at a distance of 5 km from one another, presented achene-bearing plants (i.e. were reproducing populations); these were both small subpopulations of between 200 and 250 individuals scattered over an area of 0.2 ha (Selier 2007).
Red List range: NatureServe (2013) states that Helianthus anomalus is endemic to North America, specifically the states of Utah and northern Arizona, extending along the Colorado Plateau to the eastern Great Basin into Nevada. Contrary to other sources, New Mexico is also listed, but its presence in this state is recorded as 'Not ranked/Under Review' (NatureServe 2013).
Red List use trade:
The genus Helianthus attracts a large number of native bees, and so is listed in the Pollinator programme at The Xerces Society for Invertebrate Conservation (Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center 2013).

This species is a secondary genetic relative of the cultivated Sunflower H. annuus L. (USDA, ARS National Genetic Resources Program 2013) and also belongs to Taxon Group four of the Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus L. (Schilling and Heiser 1981). It has already been utilized for the breeding of fertility restoration genes into cultivated sunflower (Seiler 1991). 

In addition to this, H. anomalus is heavily associated with native American communities where is has high cultural value due to its traditional use by the people of the Hopi Indian Reserve. For example, Voth (1903) wrote a monograph describing how the dried petals were ground up and used both as a power for decorating the faces of maidens during ceremonies and as a charm put on the boomerangs and sticks of hunters to "cause game to walk slow". Seeds were traditionally eaten and the plant used as stock fodder (Nabhan and Reichhardt 1983).
Red List conservation actions:
In 1999, NatureServe (2013) assessed this species as vulnerable (at moderate risk of extinction) across its entire range and imperilled (at high risk of extinction) in Nevada and Arizona. This is because, despite being widespread along the Colorado plateau and Great Basin, the species is often found in low numbers at particular sites (NatureServe 2013).
It should also be noted that H. anomalus is given as a synonym of H. deserticola by the Nevada Natural Heritage Program (NNHP 2001), a species that is included on both the 'Sensitive species' list as well as being ranked as both globally and regionally imperilled (high risk of extinction due to any of the following: restricted range, few populations or occurrences, steep declines, severe threats or other factors).

Despite its rarity, Nabhan and Reichhardt (1983) identified active conservation for at least seven of the 25 known localities by farmers, priests and other members of local native Indian communities on and around the Hopi reserve; the anomalous sunflower is spared from the otherwise rigorous weeding practices as it may be the only source of a ceremonial face paint (see Use and Trade section). However, in situ surveys would be useful to confirm whether or not these populations are still present as Selier (2007) only found this species in two localities during an expedition in the year 2000.

H. anomalus is reported as present in three protected areas within its native range (Information Center for the Environment (ICE) 2013):
  • Arches National Park in Utah (reproducing population present)
  • Glen Canyon National Recreation Area in Arizona (population information not recorded)
  • Grand Canyon National Park in Arizona (reproducing population present)

According to Botanical Garden Conservation International (BGCI 2013) this species has living collections in three botanical gardens worldwide, although the origin and location of the collections are not detailed in this resource (garden locations are undisclosed to protect rare and valuable plant species). Furthermore, two accessions (900 seeds) are duplicated and conserved ex situ in the Svalbard Global Seed Vault (SGSV Data Portal 2013), both of which originate from the National Plant Germplasm System (USA) which holds a total of six accessions for this species, four of which are of wild origin and backed up at a second site (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: FL(SNR); NC(SNA); TX(S4)
Red List rationale: The Silverleaf Sunflower is globally assessed as Least Concern as it appears to be secure within its native range (NatureServe 2013) and is subject to ex situ conservation (SGSV Data Portal 2013, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013). Surveying of protected areas in which this species is thought to occur would be useful to confirm presence and to enable the establishment of active in situ conservation.
Red List habitat: This annual herb flowers from late summer (July) to autumn (October), and is often found in sunny, open areas with disturbed, well drained, sandy soils or sand dunes from sea level to approximately 30 m a.s.l. This species naturally hybridizes with Helianthus annuus (Whistler 2000, Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006).
Red List threats: There is no evidence of threats impacting this species in Florida, Texas or North Carolina (Florida Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services, Florida Forest Service 2013, Texas Parks and Wildlife Department 2013, Krings et al. 2013). However, ground-truthing should take place to confirm that that there are no current or potential threats to this species.
Red List population: NatureServe (2013) gives this species a global status of G4: 'apparently secure', although this species was last reviewed in 1994. In some countries where this species is naturalized it has become a weedy species (Hawaiian Ecosystems at Risk Project 2008).
Red List range: Helianthus argophyllus is native to Florida, North Carolina and Texas in northern America (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013). This species is also naturalized in South Africa (KwaZulu-Natal), Australia (Queensland), Tonga and the Bahamas (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).
Red List use trade:
The genus Helianthus attracts large numbers of native bees, and so is listed in the Pollinator programme at The Xerces Society for Invertebrate Conservation (Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center 2013). It also acts as a larval host for the Bordered Patch Butterfly Chlosyne lacinia and the Silvery Checkerspot Chlosyne nycteis (Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center 2013).

H. argophyllus is a secondary genetic relative of the cultivated Sunflower H. annuus, and a Taxon Group four relative of the Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus. It has already been used to breed genes into sunflower that confer fertility restoration (Seiler 1991), downy mildew resistance (Miller and Guyla 1988, Hulke et al. 2010) and resistance to other diseases (Jan et al. 2004); this species also has potential to confer drought resistance to sunflower (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

Known in cultivation as the Silverleaf Sunflower since 1889 (Heiser 1951), this species is also used as an ornamental in Fiji (Smith 1991).
Red List conservation actions:
According to Botanical Garden Conservation International (BGCI 2013) this species has living collections in 10 botanical gardens worldwide, although the origin and location of the collection are not detailed in this resource (garden locations are undisclosed to protect rare and valuable plant species).

Thirty-five accessions (15,600 seeds) are duplicated and conserved ex situ in the Svalbard Global Seed vault (SGSV Data Portal 2013), all of which originate from the National Plant Germplasm System (NPGS, USA) which holds a total of 36 accessions all from the USA and 29 of these are of wild origin and backed up at a second site (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

This species may occur in the protected areas of Padre Island National Seashore and Amistad National Recreation Area in Texas, however presence is unconfirmed and so surveys at these sites to determine presence or absence are recommended (Information Center for the Environment (ICE) 2013).

NatureServe G RANK REASONS: """It is known from relatively few sites"" (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006)."
NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: AZ(S1); NM(SNR)
Red List rationale: Helianthus arizonensis is globally assessed as Data Deficient as there is currently insufficient information available to evaluate this species. Available distributional data (Crop Wild Relative Global Occurrence Database 2013) suggests that the estimated extent of occurrence for this species is 15,000â20,000 km2, suggesting this it has the potential to be classified as Vulnerable under criterion B. Furthermore, it is thought to be rare in New Mexico, and might also be rare in Arizona (being regionally documented as 'critically imperilled'). However, accompanying evidence of population size, distribution and trends as well as potential threats is not available so further research and surveying of wild subpopulations is recommended. This would also determine any passive in situ conservation that may already be in place, and facilitate novel conservation planning where appropriate.
Red List habitat:
This perennial herb species is found in open pine woodlands from 1,200 to 2,100 m a.s.l. (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006) and in dry frequently sandy soil (New Mexico Rare Plant Technical Council 1999).

Potentially suitable World Wildlife Fund for Nature (WWF) terrestrial ecoregions within the known range for this species include: Arizona Mountains forests, Colorado Plateau shrublands (specifically thought to be Pinyon-Juniper woodland) and Sierra Madre Occidental pine-oak forests (WWF 2013).

It is closely related and morphologically similar to the Texas Blueweed Helianthus cilaris which is noted as being common and is registered as a "restricted pest" by the Arizona Department of Agriculture (2013).
Red List threats:
Species specific threats are currently unknown. 

The WWF (2013) record habitat degradation and loss from mining and overgrazing as a general threat to biodiversity in two of the three potentially suitable terrestrial ecoregions (Arizona Mountains forest and Colorado Plateau shrublands). While fire suppression, off road vehicle use, habitat conversion (logging and road building) are also identified as threats in Arizona Mountains Forest, and agriculture, invasion of exotics followed by heavy grazing, oil and gas exploration, damn and urbanization constitute further threats for the Colorado Plateau Shrubland (WWF 2013).
Red List population:
The Arizona Sunflower is know from relatively few sites (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006). NatureServe (2013) gives this species a global status of G4: 'apparently secure', a status that was last reviewed in 1994. However, in the same source this species is assessed as 'Critically imperilled' in Arizona, although no justification is presented and the species is not featured on the Rare Plant List of the Arizona Native Plant Society (2000).

It is found on the New Mexico list of Rare Plants (New Mexico Rare Plant Technical Council 1999), having 'Species of Concern' status in the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service and the State of New Mexico, and is deemed 'Sensitive' by the U.S. Forest Service despite being classed as 'apparently secure' in the State by NatureServe (2013). As a result, the current population trend cannot be determined and survey work is recommended to determine population size, distribution and trend.
Red List range: Helianthus arizonensis is native to the states of Arizona and New Mexico in North America (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006).
Red List use trade:
The genus Helianthus attracts large numbers of native bees and so is listed in the Pollinator programme at The Xerces Society for Invertebrate Conservation (Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center 2013).

This species is also a tertiary genetic relative of the cultivated Sunflower Helianthus annuus (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013), with potential breeding use conferring high linoleic acid concentrations in seed to H. annuus (Seiler 1984). It is also a Taxon Group four relative of the Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus (Schilling and Heiser 1981).
Red List conservation actions:
This species is not conserved in the Svalbard Global Seed Vault (SGSV Data Portal 2013) or found in Botanical Garden Conservation International 'PlantSearch' (BGCI 2013). 
However, two accessions are held in National Plant Germplasm System (NPGS), both of which are of wild origin and backed up at a second site (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013). It is acknowledged in the New Mexico Rare Plants Species profile that little is known about this species and more research and field work to determine range, abundance, habitat, reproduction and other important biological parameters would be highly beneficial to conservation efforts (New Mexico Rare Plant Technical Council 1999).

NatureServe G RANK REASONS: Widespread; often abundant species of southeastern and south-central United States.
NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: AL(SNR); FL(SNR); GA(S4); IL(SNR); KY(S3S4); LA(SNR); MS(SNR); NC(S5); SC(SNR); TN(SNR); VA(S5)
Red List rationale: Helianthus atrorubens is globally assessed as Least Concern as it is widespread and abundant throughout its range (NatureServe 2013) with some provision of both in situ and ex situ conservation. However, threats have been recognised in some parts of this species' native range and so regular population monitoring and management is recommended across its full range but more urgently in areas where it is threatened to ensure the population remains stable.
Red List habitat: This perennial species reaches around 50 to 200 cm in height and is often found in open mixed woodland and disturbed areas along roadsides (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006). The same source notes that it is morphologically similar to Helianthus silphoides which has a geographical distribution centred around the Ozark region; it is also sometimes associated with H. eggerti (Jones 1994).
Red List threats: In the southern Appalachian region, this species is documented to be highly threatened by land-use conversion and habitat fragmentation, as well as a moderately threatened by human disturbance (NatureServe 2013, Southern Appalachian Species Viability Project 2002). It is unknown whether these threats are applicable to other parts of the species range.
Red List population: This species is a widespread and often abundant species at very low risk of extinction, with a global status of G5 (secure) (NatureServe 2013).
Red List range: Helianthus atrorubens is native to the southeast of the United States of America (Alabama, Florida, Georgia, Kentucky, Louisiana, Mississippi, North Carolina, South Carolina, Tennessee and Virginia) (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).
Red List use trade:
The genus Helianthus attracts large numbers of native bees and so is listed in the Pollinator programme at The Xerces Society for Invertebrate Conservation (Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center 2013).

This species is also a tertiary genetic relative of the cultivated Sunflower H. annuus (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013), with potential for use as a gene donor, particularly in conferring high linoleic acid concentrations in seed to H. annuus (Seiler 1984). It is also a Taxon Group four relative of the Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus (Schilling and Heiser 1981).
Red List conservation actions:
Despite being listed as Vulnerable in Kentucky (NatureServe 2013), this species does not appear on the Kentucky Rare Plants Database (KY State Nature Preserves Commission 2006).

According to Botanical Garden Conservation International (BGCI 2013) this species has living collections in 17 botanical gardens worldwide, although the origin and location of the collections are not detailed in this resource (garden locations are undisclosed to protect rare and valuable plant species). 
In addition, six accessions (2,700 seeds) are duplicated and conserved ex situ in the Svalbard Global Seed Vault (SGSV Data Portal 2013), all of which originate from the National Plant Germplasm System in the USA, which holds a total of 14 germplasm accessions for this species, eight of which are documented to be of wild origin and backed up at a second site (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resource Program 2013).

Furthermore, according to the Information Center for the Environment (ICE) (2013), H. atrorubens is documented as present in 15 protected areas across its range where passive in situ conservation is presumed. 13 of these areas have no associated population information: 
  • Big South Fork National River and Recreation Area, Tennessee 
  • Blue Ridge Parkway, North Carolina
  • Carolinian-South Atlantic Biosphere Reserve, North Carolina, South Carolina, Georgia 
  • Colonial National Historic Park, Virginia

NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: CA(SNR); OR(S2)
Red List rationale: Helianthus bolanderi is globally assessed as Least Concern as it is a widespread species with an apparently stable population. There is evidence of passive in situ conservation and provision of ex situ conservation. No threats to this species are currently known but further research is required to confirm this. The establishment of active in situ population monitoring would be advisable to ensure the species remains stable across its full range.
Red List habitat: This annual herb is found in grassy, open disturbed places below 1,800 m a.s.l. (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006). In California it is documented to occur in the following communities; Yellow Pine Forest, Foothill Woodland, Chaparral and Wetland-riparian (Calflora 2013).
Red List threats: There are no apparent threats to this species but further research is recommended to confirm this.
Red List population: This species is recorded as 'not rare' across its global range (this species is endemic to the USA) by the Rare, Threatened, and Endangered Species list of Oregon Biodiversity Information Center (ORBIC 2013). It has also been classified by NatureServe (2013) as G4 which means the species is apparently secure. Furthermore, distribution data suggests that this species has an estimated extent of occurrence of 295,000 km<sup>2</sup> in California alone (Crop Wild Relative Global Occurrence Database 2013).
Red List range: This species is native to the states of Oregon and California in the United States of America (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).
Red List use trade:
The genus Helianthus attracts large numbers of native bees and so is listed in the Pollinator programme at The Xerces Society for Invertebrate Conservation (Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center 2013). 

This species is also a secondary genetic relative of the cultivated Sunflower H. annuus (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013) and a Taxon Group four relative of the Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus (Schilling and Heiser 1981). It has been used as genetic stock (Jan 1992) and to confer breeding fertility restoration genes into cultivated Sunflower (Seiler 1991).
Red List conservation actions:
According to Botanical Garden Conservation International (BGCI 2013) this species has living collections in five botanical gardens worldwide, although the origin and location of the collection are not detailed in this resource (garden locations are undisclosed to protect rare and valuable plant species). 

Three accessions (1,500 seeds) are duplicated and conserved ex situ in the Svalbard Global Seed Vault (SGSV Data Portal 2013), all of which originate from the National Plant Germplasm System in the USA, which holds a total of five germplasm accessions for this species, all of which are documented to be of wild origin and backed up at a second site (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resource Program 2013).

Helianthus bolanderi is also noted as present in the following protected areas in California: Dye Creek Preserve and Yosemite National Park. Passive in situ conservation is presumed for these areas, but they would benefit from active population monitoring (Information Center for the Environment (ICE) 2013).

NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: CA(SNR)
Red List rationale: Helianthus californicus is globally assessed as Least Concern as it is apparently secure within its relatively restricted native range, it occurs in several protected areas and accessions of this species are conserved ex situ. Conservation efforts to restore wetland habitats are likely to benefit this species.
Red List habitat: This perennial herb, flowering during summer and autumn, is found mostly in wetlands such as stream banks, wet meadows and freshwater marshes; in Baja California it also occurs on dry rocky soils and damp/wet areas (GÃ³mez and GonzÃ¡lez 1995, Schilling 2006, Calflora 2016).
Red List threats: The loss in extent and quality of habitat due to human activities (agriculture and urbanization), invasive species, pollution, is a potential threat to Helianthus californicus, as California lost approximately 91 percent of wetlands, the typical habitat of this species, from 1780 to 1980 (Dahl and Johnson 1991, California Natural Resources Agency 2010). However, there was a reduction in the loss of wetlands during 2004â2009 (Dahl 2011). The reduction in the distribution range size due to climate change is also a potential threat to California's native flora, including H. californicus (Loarie et al. 2008).
Red List population: In 1990, Helianthus californicus was ranked as Apparently Secure at global level, as plants of this species are uncommon but not rare throughout its range (NatureServe 2015).
Red List range: This species is native to the state of California in the United States of America and Baja California in Mexico between sea level and 1,600 m a.s.l. (GÃ³mez and GonzÃ¡lez 1995, Schilling 2006, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2016, Calflora 2016).
Red List use trade: Helianthus calfornicus is a tertiary genetic relative of the cultivated Sunflower H. annuus, and a Taxon Group two relative of the Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus (Schilling and Heiser 1981, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013) and so it has the potential for use as a gene donor for crop improvement.
Red List conservation actions:
There are at least 20 available germplasm accessions of wild Helianthus californicus conserved in the North Central Regional PI Station, Iowa State University, with duplicates in the National Center for Genetic Reso (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2016). Additionally, three accessions are held in the Institute of Plant Production n.a. V.Y. Yurjev of UAAS, Ukraine; one in the Millennium Seed Bank, Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew; one in the Institute for Plant Genetic Resources 'K.Malkov', Bulgaria (GENESYS, 2008). This species is also presumed to occur in four protected areas in California, USA: Anza-Borrego Desert State Park, Mojave and Colorado Deserts Biosphere Reserve, Philip L. Boyd Deep Canyon Desert Research Center and Yosemite National Park (Information Center for the Environment (ICE) 2016). In Mexico, it is recorded in the protected area Parque Nacional ConstituciÃ³n de 1857, Baja California (CONANP 2011).

Furthermore, several projects have been implemented or are in the process of planning or implementation for the assessment, mitigation and/or restoration of wetlands in California (CWMW 2016), Actions include the restoration of riverbank, embankment and shoreline tidal environments to riparian and marsh habitats in the San Francisco Delta Bay region (CWMW 2016). These actions would have an indirect beneficial impact on the habitat and occurrence of H. californicus (CCH 2016).

NatureServe G RANK REASONS: A Florida endemic; with 19 known occurrences; located in Flagler and St. Johns counties. Populations are decreasing due to drainage of habitat for agriculture and residential construction.

CA(SNR); ID(SNR); NV(SNR); OR(SNR); WA(SNR)
AL(SNR); CT(SNR); FL(SNR); GA(SNR); LA(SNR); MA(SNR); MD(SNR); ME(SNR); MS(S4?); NC(SNA); NH(SNR); PA(SNR); RI(SNR); SC(SNR); TX(SNR); VA(SNA); VT(SNA); WV(SH)
Red List rationale: Helianthus debilis is globally assessed as Least Concern as it is a widespread species that is deemed locally common or abundant in parts of its range. Although evidence of both in situ (passive) and ex situ conservation was found for this species, it seems to be under represented in ex situ collections and so further gathering of wild germplasm for ex situ storage is recommended. It is also recommended that active in situ conservation is established with population monitoring and management, particularly for the three subspecies (H. debilis subsp. debilis, H. debilis subsp. vestitus and H. debilis subsp. tardiflorus) whose extinction risk may be higher than the overall species population.
Red List habitat: In Texas, the Cucumber Leaf Sunflower H. debilis subsp. cucumerifolius and the Forest Sunflower H. debilis subsp. silvestris occur in open areas and on sandy soils from 10 m to over 100 m a.s.l., while the latter is also associated with pine and oak species. The Beach Sunflower H. debilis subsp. debilis and the Clothed Sunflower H. debilis subsp. vestitus are both found on coastal dunes in Florida and clearings in open pine-saw palmetto or in coastal tropical hammocks (NatureServe 2013) from 0â10 m a.s.l., while the sSlow Flowering Sunflower H. debilis subsp. tardiflorus can be found on sandy beaches from sea level to 30 m a.s.l. in Alabama, Florida, Georgia and Mississippi. All subordinate taxa flower from spring to autumn, except the Clothed Sunflower which flowers all year round (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006).
Red List threats: The Clothed Sunflower Helianthus debilis subsp. vestitus is threatened in Florida by habitat destruction from coastal residential and recreational development (NatureServe 2013) and while the Beach Sunflower (H. debilis subsp. debilis) does not have any species specific threat identified on NatureServe (2013), it is deemed vulnerable (T3) and has similarities habitat preferences so may be impacted by similar threats. According to Brown (2013) the range of H. debilis subsp. debilis has spread outside of its native east coast range in Florida to the west coast of Florida too. This is where subspecies vestitus is found and as a result may pose a plausible threat to the latter through hybridization (Brown 2013).
Red List population:
This species does not appear on available state-wide Rare or Endangered Plants lists and is detailed in NatureServe (2013) to be considered globally secure (status: G5) and therefore at very low risk of extinction.

Locality data accompanying several herbarium specimens from the University of Texas at Austin states that the Cucumber Leaf Sunflower Helianthus debilis subsp. cucumerifolius is locally common in various locations (The Plant Resources Center of the University of Texas at Austin 2013), and this infraspecific taxon is also assigned a secure status by NatureServe (2013). The Forest Sunflower H. debilis subsp. silvestris is deemed apparently secure (T4).

In contrast to this, the Beach Sunflower H. debilis subsp. debilis is deemed vulnerable (T3) by NatureServe (2013) and the Clothed Sunflower H. debilis subsp. vestitus is classified as imperilled (T2) as only 22 occurrences have been recorded by the Florida National Areas Inventory as of 1997 and a high rate of habitat destruction has also been recorded (NatureServe 2013). Finally, the Slow Flowering Sunflower H. debilis subsp. tardiflorus is classified as vulnerable (T3) as it is scattered along shorelines in specialized and naturally limited habitat. It has only been collected from four or five sites in Florida and the primary reason that this subspecies is under collected is due to the inaccessibility of coastal sites, unless accessed by boat (NatureServe 2013).
Red List range:
Helianthus debilis is native to the states of Texas, Alabama, Florida, Louisiana and Mississippi in northern America (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013). 

This species has five subspecies with various distributions within northern America: the Cucumber Leaf Sunflower H. debilis subsp. cucumerifolius and the Forest Sunflower H. debilis subsp. silvestris are both native to the state of Texas; the Beach Sunflower H. debilis subsp. debilis and the Clothed Sunflower H. debilis subsp. vestitus are native to Florida; the Slow Flowering Sunflower H. debilis subsp. tardiflorus is native to the states of Alabama, Florida, Georgia and Mississippi.
Red List use trade:
The genus Helianthus attracts large numbers of native bees and so is listed in the Pollinator programme at The Xerces Society for Invertebrate Conservation (Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center 2013).

This species, and the five subspecies, are secondary genetic relatives of the cultivated Sunflower H. annuus (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013), and Taxon Group four relatives of the Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus (Schilling and Heiser 1981). H. debilis has already been used for breeding fertility restoration genes (Seiler 1991) and powdery mildew resistance (Jan and Chandler 1988) into cultivated sunflower.

Additionally, the flowers and seeds of H. debilis as well as subspecies debilis and vestitus, were used by native Americans to produce green/purple-black dyes for decorative purposes (painting or dyeing of skin, textiles, pottery, and baskets) (Brown 2013).
Red List conservation actions:
The Weak Sunflower Helianthus debilis has a verified occurrence in the Gus Engeling Wildlife Management Area in Texas (Singhurst et al. 2003) and so is subject to some passive in situ conservation.


Passive conservation of H. debilis is also presumed in the following protected areas, although information concerning subpopulation trends in these areas is not available (Information Center for the Environment (ICE) 2013) :

  • Big Thicket Biosphere Reserve, Texas
  • Padre Island National Seashore, Texas
  • Canaveral National Seashore, Florida
  • Fort Caroline National Memorial, Florida
  • Fort Matanzas National Monument, Florida


According to Botanical Garden Conservation International (BGCI 2013) this species has living collections in 10 botanical gardens worldwide, although the origin and location of the collections are not detailed in this resource (garden locations are undisclosed to protect rare and valuable plant species).

Accessions of H. debilis have not yet been duplicated and conserved in the Svalbard Global Seed Vault (SGSV Data Portal 2013). However, one accession is held in the National Plant Germplasm System in the USA (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resource Program 2013) and the EURISCO Catalogue (2013) documents five accessions of wild origin, four of which are held in the Institute of Plant Production n.a. V.Y. Yurjev of UAAS (Ukraine), and the remaining one is held in the Millennium Seed Bank Project (RBG, Kew).

Red List rationale: Helianthus decapetalus is a common species within its native range with a stable global population, it occurs in several protected areas and germplasm of this species is conserved in ex situ collections; it is therefore globally assessed as Least Concern. However, further conservation may be required in areas where local populations are likely to be threatened (i.e. Delaware, Quebec and New Brunswick).
Red List habitat:
Helianthus decapetalus can be found in rich soils in shaded woodlands, but is not common in open woods; it seems to be frequent in mesic to wet woodland edges, savannas, partially shaded areas along rivers, riverbanks, meadows, and thickets (Heiser et al. 1969, Schilling 2006, Hilty 2016, USDA-NRCS 2016).

Flowerheads attract numerous pollinating species (bees, butterflies, wasps and various kinds of flies), the seeds constitute attractive feed for birds (mainly gamebirds and granivorous songbirds), muskrats occasionally use leaves and/or stems as food or lodge building material (wetlands) and young plants are often grazed by rabbits, deer, groundhogs and many kinds of livestock. It may spread aggressively in some situations (weedy potential) (Hilty 2016).
Red List threats: There are no recorded threats to this species.
Red List population: Helianthus decapetalus is widespread in eastern Canada and the United States of America. It is common and abundant within its range, and ranked as globally secure, although at local level some states were assessed as apparently secure (Georgia, Iowa, New Jersey, North Carolina), vulnerable (Delaware, Quebec) or critically imperilled (New Brunswick) (NatureServe 2015). This species is occasional yet widely scattered in Illinois, but largely absent in the south of the state (Hilty 2016). It is infrequent in Kentucky (Jones 2005).
Red List range: Helianthus decepetalus is widely distributed across eastern states of the United States of America and Canada, from Ontario, Quebec and New Brunswick to Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama and Georgia; it occurs at elevations from 10 to 1,200 m asl (Heiser et al. 1969, Schilling 2006, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2016, USDA-NRCS 2016).
Red List use trade: Helianthus decapetalus is an attractive plant to pollinating bees and it has economic importance as an ornamental plant; it is also a tertiary genetic relative of cultivated Sunflower (H. annuus) and a Taxon Group two relative of the Jerusalem Artichoke (H. tuberosus) and so it has the potential for use as a gene donor for crop improvement (Schilling and Heiser 1981, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013, Greenbelt Native Plant Center 2016, Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center 2016).
Red List conservation actions:
This species occurs in at least 20 protected areas within its native range in the United States of America (Information Center for the Environment (ICE) 2016): Adirondack Park, NY; Allegheny Portage Railroad Nat'l Hist. Site, PA; Blue Ridge Parkway, NC; Bluestone National Scenic River, WV; Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Hist. Park, D.C.,MD; Cumberland Gap National Hist. Park, KY, TN, VI; Cuyahoga Valley National Recreation Area, OH; Friendship Hill National Historic Site, PA; Gauley River National Recreation Area, WV; George Washington Memorial Parkway, VA; Great Smoky Mountains National Park, NC, TN; Harpers Ferry National Historical Park, WV; Indiana Dunes National Lakeshore, IN; Niagara Escarpment Biosphere Reserve; Rock Creek Park, D.C.; Rondeau Provincial Park; Saint Croix International Historic Site, ME; Shenandoah National Park, VA; Southern Appalachian Biosphere Reserve, NC, TN; Valley Forge National Historical Park, PA.

Additionally, there are at least 28 germplasm accessions of wild Helianthus decapetalus conserved in the North Central Regional PI Station, Iowa State University, with duplicates in the National Center for Genetic Resources Preservation, Fort Collins; two accessions are kept in the Institute of Plant Production n.a. V.Y. Yurjev of UAAS, Ukraine, three in the Institute of Oil Crops, Ukraine, and three in the Institute for Plant Genetic Resources 'K.Malkov', Bulgaria  (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2016, GENESYS 2016).


The genus Helianthus is recognized by pollen ecologists as attracting large numbers of native bees, and so is listed in the Pollinator programme at The Xerces Society for Invertebrate Conservation (Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center 2013).

NatureServe G RANK REASONS: Known from over 20 EOs in Nevada (4/2008) and several more from southern Utah; subject to grazing and recreational use in some areas. Considered distinct molecularly and morphologically from H. anomalus by a current expert on North American sunflowers; Lo
NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: NV(S3); UT(SNR)
Red List rationale: Helianthus deserticola is globally assessed as Data Deficient as there is currently insufficient information available to evaluate it. This species is relatively uncommon, with small population sizes throughout most of its range and a low tolerance of disturbance, however, there is no evidence of any decrease in its range. Due to its possible rarity and potential susceptibility to known threats within its range, it is possible that this species is threatened. However, to quantify this species' extinction risk, surveys are required to determine population size, distribution and trend. It should be ensured that in situ conservation with active population monitoring and management are established across the species' range so secure this resource in the long-term. Further ex situ collecting should also be carried out as a back up of material conserved in the wild.
Red List habitat: This annual herb is a xerophytic species found in dry, open areas, with sandy soils (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006). For example, in Nevada this species is heavily dependant on sand dunes or deep sand and can be found in loose soils of aeolian deposits, vegetated dunes and dune skirt areas, on flat and gentle slopes of all aspects and more generally in alkaline areas, often thriving on road berms and other stabilized disturbances within such soils (NNHP 2001). The desert sunflower can grow up to 40 cm and, in Nevada at least, appears to flower opportunistically from late spring, continuing as summer rains permit through to autumn (NNHP 2001, Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006). From its known range and the Virgin River Basin Conservation Management Assessment (VRBCMA) species profiles this species is endemic to stabilized, sandy soils on desert floors of Mojave desert (VRBCMA 2013).
Red List threats: This species is known to have little disturbance tolerance (Rieseberg et al. 2000, VRBCMA 2013) which is a concern as the threats listed by the VRBCMA (2013) that are impacting this species include modernization and mechanization of agricultural practices, total abandonment of agricultural fields and road construction (it should be noted that these threats are those recorded for Helianthus anomalus, which NatureServe (2013) treats as a species for which H. deserticola is a synonym and other sources treat H. deserticola as a species in its own right (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013)).
Red List population:
This species is distributed in small populations across western Nevada, west central Utah, and along the Utah-Arizona border (Gross et al. 2003) and is presumed to have the same historic and present ranges (VRBCMA 2013). The Flora of North America states that this species is 'relatively uncommon' although it is not federally listed (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006).

In the Nevada Natural Heritage Program 2001 population census, 21 occurrences of this species were mapped, with state population estimated at more than 25,000 individuals over a total area of more than 77.3 ha (0.773 km2) (NNHP 2010).

This species is on the Plant and Animal At-Risk Tracking List of Nevada (NNHP 2010) as it has been given a global rank of G2 (imperilled due to rarity or other demonstrable factors) to G3 (vulnerable to decline because rare and local throughout its range, or with very restricted range), and a state rank of S3 (defined the same as G3).
Red List range: This species is native to the states of Arizona, Nevada and Utah in North America, occurring between 400 to 1,500 m a.s.l. (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006).
Red List use trade:
This species is a secondary genetic relative of the cultivated Sunflower H. annuus, and a Taxon Group four relative of the Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus. It has already been used for breeding downy mildew resistance genes into cultivated sunflower (Seiler 1991). Seiler (2007) also identifies that the species has potential for use in the industrial production of sunflower oil.

The genus Helianthus attracts large numbers of native bees and so is listed in the Pollinator programme at The Xerces Society for Invertebrate Conservation (Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center 2013).
Red List conservation actions:
Thirteen accessions are available from the National Plant Germplasm System (NPGS), all of which are of wild origin and backed up at a second site (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013). Furthermore, according to Botanic Gardens Conservation International (BGCI 2013) this species has a living collection in one botanical garden worldwide, although the origin and location of the collection is not detailed in this resource (garden locations are undisclosed to protect rare and valuable plant species).

In terms of existing in situ conservation, Gross et al. (2003) report the presence of one population of Helianthus deserticola in the Little Sahara Recreation Area (Utah), which contains the Rockwell Outstanding Natural Area; a vehicle free wilderness area and protected landscape. In addition, this species is listed as one of the 108 special status upland species of the Lower Virgin River in the Virgin River Basin Conservation Management Assessment (VRBCMA 2013) which was written under the the direction of the Clark County Desert Conservation Program to satisfy a requirement of the Section 10 Incidental Take Permit, issued in 2001 by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service (USFWS). This initiative aims to protect habitats and native species in the area, however information regarding active conservation efforts in this area for this particular species remain unknown (VRBCMA 2013). More generally, the conservation objectives of the VRBCMA (2013) include offsetting the potential effects of specific threats on special status species, of which H. deserticola is one.

NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: AL(SNR); AR(SNR); CT(SNR); DC(SNR); DE(S1); FL(SNR); GA(SNR); IA(S3); IL(SNR); IN(SNR); KY(S5); LA(SNR); MA(SNR); MD(SNR); ME(SNR); MI(SNR); MO(SNR); MS(SNR); NC(S5); NH(SNR); NJ(S5); NY(S5); OH(SNR); OK(SNR); PA(SNR); RI(S1); SC(SNR); TN(SNR); VA(S5); VT
Red List rationale: This species is globally assessed as Least Concern as, despite being vulnerable or critically imperilled in small parts of its native range, it is otherwise though to be stable and secure (MDDEP 2001, NatureServe 2013) with no recorded threats, though research should be undertaken to further investigate whether there are any key threats facing this species. Some accessions are conserved ex situ for this species and some level of passive in situ conservation exists in some areas of its native range. Establishment of active conservation management, particularly in provinces or states where this species is vulnerable, is recommended as well as ensuring that the full range of geographic and genetic diversity of the species is represented in gene banks.
Red List habitat: This perennial species flowers from June to early September and is often found in dry, open sites (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006). For example, in Canada it is known from the escarpments of the Canadian Shield ('Bouclier Canadien' in French) in dry, open, oak groves facing south or southwest, and in the valley of the Ottawa river on outcrops of crystalline limestone (MDDRP 2001). While in Delaware, it is found in the physiogeographical provinces of piedmont and coastal plain, usually in rich woods (McAvoy 2013).
Red List threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
Red List population:
This species is reported to be globally and nationally secure in both Canada and the United States of America (NatureServe 2013). However, in the same source Helianthus divaricatus is reported to be vulnerable in the Canadian state of Quebec and the USA state of Iowa, and is critically imperilled in Delaware (McAvoy 2013) and Rhode Island (NatureServe 2013).
In Canada, subpopulations in the northern part of this species range (Quebec) face a higher risk of extinction than more southern subpopulations (Ontario) due to the presence of a limited number viable subpopulations in Quebec (seven viable out of a total of 18 subpopulations), and limited subpopulation size as the remaining 11 subpopulations in Quebec are considered too small (less than 2,000 stems) (MDDEP 2001). In addition, northern subpopulations are documented to grow more slowly than their conspecifics in southern Ontario, while low reproductive success also suggests that colonization within the province may be unlikely (MDDEP 2001).
Red List range: This species is native to north-central and eastern states of the United States of America and the provinces of Quebec and Ontario in Canada; it is found at elevations between 10 m and 900 m a.s.l. (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).
Red List use trade:
This species is a tertiary genetic relative of the cultivated Sunflower Helianthus annuus (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013) and a Taxon Group two relative of the Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus (Schilling and Heiser 1981). It has already been used for breeding broomrape resistance genes into cultivated sunflower (Jan et al. 2002).

In addition, the genus Helianthus attracts large numbers of native bees, and so is listed in the Pollinator programme at The Xerces Society for Invertebrate Conservation (Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center 2013).
Red List conservation actions:
As previously stated, this species is identified as vulnerable in Quebec (NatureServe 2013) and so has been legally protected in Quebec since 1998. However, the population does not seem to be decreasing in this province and five occurrences are within a protected territory so have a basic level of passive in situ conservation (MDDEP 2001).

In terms of ex situ conservation, Botanical Garden Conservation International (BGCI 2013) states that this species has living collections in 24 botanical gardens worldwide, although the origin and location of the collections are not detailed in this resource (garden locations are undisclosed to protect rare and valuable plant species). Furthermore, 10 accessions (4,500 seeds) are duplicated and conserved ex situ in the Svalbard Global Seed Vault (SGSV Data Portal 2013), all of which originate from the National Plant Germplasm System (NPGS in the USA), which holds a total of 27 germplasm accessions all originating from within the USA and 14 of which are of wild origin and backed up at a second site (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

CA(S3)
Red List rationale: Helianthus exilis is globally assessed as Near Threatened as the species is known to be endemic to California, it is classified as vulnerable by NatureServe (2013) and according to the Crop Wild Relative Global Occurrence Database (2013) this species has an area of occupancy of 160 km2 which meets the threshold for global classification as Endangered (B2). However, there is a lack of data regarding population distribution, size and trend although it is suspected that the population is in decline. Survey work to determine these population parameters and research into the threats to which the species is exposed are recommended to determine whether or not this species should be assigned the Endangered threat category.
Red List habitat: This Californian endemic herb flowers from June to November and is restricted to moist seeps, a specialised microhabitat within large outcrops of serpentine seeps of California (Wolf 2001, Safford et al. 2005). It is also documented to be found on gravelly or wetland riparian habitats, in chapparal, and cismontane woodland (CNPS 2013).
Red List threats: This species has a Rare Plant Rank of 4.2 (uncommon and fairly endangered in California), as well as a global and state rank of 3 (vulnerable) and 3.2 (vulnerable and threatened) respectively (CNPS 2013). However, specific threats to this species remain unknown.
Red List population: Jain et al. (1992) report that Helianthus exilis has a high local persistence and so is likely to be relatively resilient to a reduction in number of subpopulations. However, this species is of conservation concern within its native range according to the Flora of North America Editorial Committee (2006), and although specific population information is lacking it is suspected that its population is in decline.
Red List range: This species is endemic to the state of California in the United States of America, occurring in the counties of Colusa, Glenn, Lake, Napa, Santa Clara, Shasta, Siskiyou, Sonoma, Tehama and Trinity; it is found at elevations between 100 m and 1,400 m a.s.l. (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013, California Native Plant Society (CNPS) 2013, NatureServe 2013). According to data from the Crop Wild Relative Global Occurrence Database (2013), this species has an area of occupancy (AOO) of only 160 km<sup>2</sup>.
Red List use trade:
This species is a tertiary genetic relative of the cultivated Sunflower Helianthus annuus (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

In addition, the genus Helianthus attracts large numbers of native bees and so is listed in the Pollinator programme at The Xerces Society for Invertebrate Conservation (Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center 2013).
Red List conservation actions:
In terms of ex situ conservation, 12 accessions (5,300 seeds) are duplicated and conserved ex situ in the Svalbard Global Seed Vault (SGSV Data Portal 2013), all of which originate from the National Plant Germplasm System (NPGS, in the USA) which holds a total of 30 germplasm accessions for this species, 28 of which are of wild origin and backed up at a second site (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resource Program 2013). According to Botanical Garden Conservation International (BGCI 2013) this species has a living collection in one botanical garden worldwide, although the origin and location of the collection is not detailed in this resource (garden locations are undisclosed to protect rare and valuable plant species).

Distribution data from the Crop Wild Relative Global Occurrence Database (2013) suggest that this species is present in the following protected areas in California where passive in situ conservation is presumed:
  • Tahoe National Forest
  • Lassen Volcanic National Park
  • Six Rivers National Forest
  • Shasta Trinity National Forest
  • Mendocino National Forest.

Red List rationale: Helianthus giganteus is globally assessed as Least Concern as it is reported to be stable and secure across the majority of its native range in the United States of America and Canada. Population surveying and ongoing monitoring is recommended to ensure the long-term survival of this species, this is particularly key in the three states that report imperilled subpopulations.
Red List habitat: This species is found in wet, open sites (fens, bogs, sedge meadows, open forests and swamps) (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006). It is further documented by Hilty (2004â2013) to be found in high quality wetlands in Illinois.
Red List threats: The threats to this species remain unknown.
Red List population: This species is globally and nationally secure in Canada and the United States of America, despite being vulnerable in Iowa, imperilled in Georgia and critically imperilled in Illinois (NatureServe 2013).
Red List range: Helianthus giganteus is native to Canada and north-central and eastern states of the United States of America; it is also naturalized in Newfoundland, Canada and in Europe (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013). This species is found at elevations between 10 m and 600 m a.s.l. (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006).
Red List use trade:
Helianthus giganteus is a tertiary wild relative of the cultivated Sunflower H. annuus (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013) and has already been used to confer fertility restoration genes (Seiler 2000), and cytoplasmic male sterility (Whelan and Dedio 1980) to cultivated Sunflower. It also belongs to Taxon Group two of the Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus (Schilling and Heiser 1981).

In addition, the genus Helianthus attracts large numbers of native bees and so is listed in the Pollinator programme at The Xerces Society for Invertebrate Conservation (Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center 2013).

Historically, this plant was ground into powder and used medicinally by the Cherokee to induce sneezing (Hamel and Chiltoskey 1975).
Red List conservation actions:
This species is included in the Illinois Endangered Species Protection Act which prohibits gathering and trade of species without authorization by the Department of Conservation (Illinois Endangered Species Protection Board 2011). This species is also conserved ex situ in the National Plant Germplasm System (NPGS, in the USA) with 19 accessions of wild origin that are backed up at a second site (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013). In terms of in situ conservation, the Wetlands campaign is ongoing in Illinois and aims to protect and improve functionality of remaining wetlands (Wetlands Campaign 2013). This project does not directly state the inclusion of Helianthus giganteus, but may indirectly benefit this species depending on localities in which action is implemented.

H. giganteus is thought to be found in the following protected areas, where passive in situ conservation is presumed (Information Center for the Environment (ICE) 2013):
  • Adirondack Park, New York (present with no other population information)
  • Blue Ridge Parkway, North Carolina (present with no other population information)
  • Bombay Hook National Wildlife Refuge, Delaware (present with no other population information)
  • George Washington Memorial Parkway, Virginia (present with no other population information)
  • Indiana Dunes National Lakeshore, Indiana (present with no other population information)
  • Effigy Mounds National Monument, Iowa (uncommon with reproducing population)
  • Oconee National Forest, Georgia (present with reproducing population)
  • Saint Croix International Historic Site, Maine (uncommon with reproducing population)
  • Sleeping Bear Dunes National Lakeshore, Michigan (present with non reproducing population)
  • Voyageurs National Park, Minnesota (present with non-reproducing population)
  • Lake Superior Provincial Park, Canada (present yet rare)
  • Fundy National Park, Canada (present with reproducing population)
  • Point Pelee National Park, Canada (present with reproducing population)
  • Riding Mountain Biosphere Reserve, Canada (present with reproducing population).

Red List rationale: Helianthus grosseserratus is globally assessed as Least Concern as it is a widespread species with a secure population across its native range. It is concerning that within the majority of protected areas in which it occurs, this species is recorded as having a non-reproducing population and as a result is recommended that long-term monitoring of populations across its full native range is established to detect any subpopulations at risk of decline.
Red List habitat: This species is found in full sunlight in dry to wet prairies, it prefers sandy loamy soils (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006).
Red List threats: The threats to this species remain unknown.
Red List population: Helianthus grosseserratus is nationally and globally secure (NatureServe 2013).
Red List range: This species is native to central and eastern regions of the United States of America; it is also naturalized in Canada and certain states of the USA (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013). It is found at elevations between 10 m and 300 m a.s.l. (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006).
Red List use trade:
This species belongs to the tertiary gene pool of the cultivated Sunflower Helianthus annuus (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013) and has already been used to confer broomrape resistance (Jan et al. 2002) to sunflower. It also belongs to Taxon Group two of the Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus (Schilling and Heiser 1981).

In addition, the genus Helianthus attracts large numbers of native bees and so is listed in the Pollinator programme at The Xerces Society for Invertebrate Conservation (Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center 2013).

Historically, the poultice of this species' blossoms were used by the Meskwaki people to dress burns (Smith 1928).
Red List conservation actions:
This species is conserved ex situ in the National Plant Germplasm System (NPGS, in the USA) which contains a total of 44 accessions, 37 of which are of wild origin and backed up at a second site (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

In terms of in situ conservation, Helianthus grosseserratus is recorded in the following protected areas and, as a result, is thought to be subject to passive in situ conservation (Information Centre for the Environment (ICE) 2013): 
  • Fort Scott National Historic Site, Kansas (present with non-reproducing population)
  • George WA Carver National Monument, Missouri (present with non-reproducing population)
  • Herbert Hoover National Historic Site, Iowa (present with non-reproducing population)
  • Indiana Dunes National Lakeshore, Indiana (present)
  • Saint Croix International Historic Site, Maine (present with non-reproducing population)
  • Upper Miss. River Nat'l Wildlife Refuge, Minnesota, Wisconsin, Iowa, Illinois (present with reproducing population).

Red List rationale: Helianthus hirsutus is globally assessed as Least Concern as it is a secure and widespread species in North America, it occurs in several protected areas and germplasm of this species is conserved ex situ. Conservation of this species where it is thought to be vulnerable or imperilled (e.g. North Carolina and Pennsylvania) is recommended.
Red List habitat: The Hairy Sunflower prefers dry, open sites and woodland edges, and it is persistent in disturbed areas and roadsides, often associated with open pine and oak forests (Heiser et al. 1969, GÃ³mez and GonzÃ¡lez 1995, Schilling 2006, Michigan Natural Features Inventory 2007)
Red List threats: The threats to this species remain unknown.
Red List population: In 1985, Helianthus hirsutus was assessed as globally secure as individuals of this species are common, widespread and abundant (NatureServe 2015). At local level, it has been ranked as apparently secure in West Virginia (the species is uncommon but not rare), vulnerable in North Carolina, Michigan, Virginia and Iowa, and imperilled in Pennsylvania (Michigan Natural Features Inventory 2007, NatureServe 2015).
Red List range: Helianthus hirsutus is native to eastern North America, particularly southeastern Canada (Ontario), eastern and central United States (from Minnesota to Pennsylvania in the north and from Florida to Texas in the south) and in northern Mexico (Coahuila and Nuevo LeÃ³n), and it is found at elevations between 10 m and 900 m a.s.l. (Schilling 2006, NatureServe 2015, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2016).
Red List use trade: Helianthus hirsutus is a tertiary genetic relative of the cultivated Sunflower H. annuus, it also belongs to Taxon Group two of the Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus, and so it has the potential for use as a gene donor for crop improvement, particularly in conferring pest resistance to cultivated sunflower (Schilling and Heiser 1981, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).
Red List conservation actions:
Helianthus hirsutus occurs in 15 protected areas in the United States (Information Center for the Environment (ICE) 2016):
  1. Blue Ridge Parkway, North Carolina
  2. Buffalo National River, Arkansas 
  3. Chickamauga & Chattanooga Nat'l Military Park, Georgia
  4. Chickasaw National Recreation Area, Oklahoma
  5. Cumberland Gap National Hist. Park, Kentucky, Tennessee, Virgin Islands
  6. Cuyahoga Valley National Recreation Area, Ohio (the species is uncommon with reproducing population is present)
  7. George WA Carver National Monument, Montana (the species is uncommon with reproducing population is present)
  8. Kennesaw Mountain National Battlefield Park, Georgia
  9. Mammoth Cave Area Biosphere Reserve (Natn'l Park), Kentucky (reproducing population is present)
  10. Ozark National Scenic Riverways, Montana (reproducing population is present)
  11. Saint Croix International Historic Site, Maine (non-reproducing population present)
  12. Shiloh National Military Park, Tennessee
  13. Sleeping Bear Dunes National Lakeshore, Michigan (non-reproducing population present)
  14. Southern Appalachian Biosphere Reserve, North Carolina, Tenesse
  15. Tennessee River Gorge, Tennassee (reproducing population is present).

In Mexico, the species is recorded to be present in the Cumbres de Monterrey National Park (CONANP 2006, Estrada-CastillÃ³n et al. 2013). 
The species is also conserved ex situ. There are at least seven germplasm accessions available in the North Central Regional Plant Introduction Station, Iowa State University, with duplicates in the National Center for Genetic Resources Preservation, Fort Collins (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2016). Additionally, two germplasm accessions are conserved in the Institute for Plant Genetic Resources K. Malkov, Bulgaria and three at the Institute of Oil Crops, Ukraine (GENESYS 2008).

NatureServe G RANK REASONS: Although Helianthus laevigatus has a somewhat-restricted range; it is abundant in glades; in barrens; and at roadsides within that range (especially in Virginia). It is threatened primarily by fire suppression and by invasion of exotic plant species.
