Red List rationale: This species is globally assessed as Least Concern as, despite being threatened in Wyoming, it is widespread and stable in the rest of its range across North America. Furthermore, it is subject to ex situ conservation and passive in situ conservation within its native range. Subpopulation management and monitoring in protected areas where this species is thought to occur would benefit this species.
Red List habitat: This species occurs in prairies, fields and waste areas (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006).
Red List threats: The threats to this species remain unknown.
Red List population: This species is classified by NatureServe (2013) as nationally and globally secure. Due to this and its presence across much of northern America it is suspected that its population is stable despite the same source recording it as imperilled in the state of Wyoming. It is also introduced across many states of North America (Kentucky, Michigan, New Jersey, New York, North Carolina, Virginia and West Virginia) and Canada (Alberta, British Columbia, Ontario, Prince Edward Island and Quebec) (NatureServe 2013).
Red List range: Helianthus maximiliani is native to Canada (Saskatchewan and Manitoba) and the United States of America, where it is relatively widespread (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006, NatureServe 2013). This species is native to mid continental prairie regions of North America, but has spread as an exotic species along transport corridors (railroads and highways) into all areas of North America; widespread cultivation may have facilitated the spread of this species (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006). It is primarily found at elevations between sea level and 300 m a.s.l. but does occur up to 2,100 m a.s.l. (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006).
Red List use trade:
This species is a tertiary wild relative of the cultivated Sunflower Helianthus annuus (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013) and has already been used to confer broomrape resistance (Jan et al. 2002) and cytoplasmic male sterility (Whelan and Dedio 1980) to sunflower. It is also a Taxon Group two wild relative of the Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus (Schilling and Heiser 1981). Furthermore, it is cultivated as an ornamental, it is used for forage and it is used for environmental purposes such as for erosion control and as a revegetator (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

In addition, the genus Helianthus attracts large numbers of native bees and so is listed in the Pollinator programme at The Xerces Society for Invertebrate Conservation (Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center 2013).
Red List conservation actions:
This species has 67 accessions conserved ex situ in the National Plant Germplasm System (NPGS, in the USA), 47 of which are of wild origin and backed up at a second site (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

According to the Information Center for the Environment (ICE 2013), it is presumed to be subject to passive in situ conservation in the following protected areas:
  • Algonquin Provincial Park, Canada (rare)
  • Chickasaw National Recreation Area, Oklahoma (origin unknown)
  • Fort Larned National Historic Site, Kansas (non-reproducing population present)
  • Fort Scott National Historic Site, Kansas (uncommon with reproducing population)
  • Knife River Indian Villages National Hist. Site, North Dakota (reproducing population)
  • Lake Meredith National Recreation Area, Texas (origin unknown)
  • Pipestone National Monument, Minnesota (uncommon with reproducing population)
  • Riding Mountain Biosphere Reserve, Canada (reproducing population introduced by humans)
  • Southern Appalachian Biosphere Reserve, North Carolina, Tennessee
  • Wind Cave National Park, South Dakota (reproducing population).

NatureServe G RANK REASONS: Known only from a few scattered populations in Texas and New Mexico; some of which are quite large. Hybridizes easily with some common sunflower species; which may be detrimental to its genetic integrity.
NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: NM(SNR); TX(S2)
Red List rationale:
Helianthus neglectus is globally assessed as Data Deficient as there is currently insufficient information available to evaluate this species. With an estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of 10,000 km2, this species meets the Vulnerable threshold under criterion B1 and with an estimated area of occupancy (AOO) of only 44 km2, this species also meets the Endangered threshold under criterion B2. However, no evidence of severe fragmentation, continuing decline or extreme fluctuations was found and so it does not qualify for a threatened category under this criterion.

An estimate of 1,000 to 3,000 individuals of this species are thought to occur (Walter and Gillett 1997) but it is unclear whether this figure represents the whole native population, or only the individuals occurring within Texas. If the former, this species could be classified as Near Threatened under criterion D1 but more evidence is needed to clarify this point. It is recommended that research be undertaken to identify subpopulation sizes and trends to help quantify the extinction risk for this species. Evidence also suggests there is very limited provision for this species in terms of ex situ or in situ conservation for this species. Due to its imperilled global status (NatureServe 2013), the establishment of active in situ population monitoring and management is required with complementary ex situ back up of wild material.
Red List habitat: Helianthus neglectus grows up to two metres tall, occurring on sandy soils and sand dunes from 800â1,100 m a.s.l. (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006). The closely related species H. petiolaris also occurs in sandy soils, and subpopulations are often adjacent to each other with no clear geographical boundary of separation; given this close proximity, natural hybrids of these species are not uncommon where the two ranges overlap (Raduski et al. 2010).
Red List threats: Hybridization between this and other common sunflower species can occur easily and may be a threat to the genetic integrity of H. neglectus (NatureServe 2013). Any additional threats to this species remain unknown.
Red List population:
NatureServe (2013) lists Helianthus neglectus as imperilled both globally and nationally. According to the List of the Rare Plants of Texas (Poole et al. 2010), the species status is 'G3', meaning that '21â100 occurrences are known globally; either very rare and local throughout its range or found locally (even abundantly at some of its locations) in a restricted range (e.g., a single state or physiographic region), or because of other factors making it vulnerable to extinction throughout its range'; it has also been moved to a watch list for species of concern.
In the 1997 IUCN Red List of Threatened Plants this species was assessed as 'Indeterminate' (DD) in New Mexico and  'Vulnerable' in Texas, meaning there were likely to be between 6â20 occurrences or 1,000â3,000 individuals (Walter and Gillett 1997).
Red List range: Only known in a few counties of western Texas (Ector, Loving (historical), Ward and Winkler) and in southeastern New Mexico (Poole et al. 2007), Helianthus neglectus occurs at elevations between 800 m and 1,100 m a.s.l. (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006).
Red List use trade:
This species belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of the cultivated Sunflower H. annuus (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013) and has already been used to confer fertility restoration genes (Seiler 1991) to this crop. It also belongs to Taxon Group four of the Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus (Schilling and Heiser 1981).

In addition, the genus Helianthus attracts large numbers of native bees and so is listed in the Pollinator programme at The Xerces Society for Invertebrate Conservation (Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center 2013).
Red List conservation actions: The Flora of North America states that this species is of conservation concern, however no further detail is given (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006). In terms of the current provision of ex situ conservation for this species, nine accessions of wild origin are found in the National Plant Germplasm System (NPGS, in the USA), all of which are backed up at a second site (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2014). In contrast, distributional data (Crop Wild Relative Global Occurrence Database 2013) suggest that Helianthus neglectus is not found in any protected areas and so is not subject to passive in situ conservation, although it is possible that this species is found in Monahans Sandhills State Park in Texas (Poole et al. 2007).

NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: AZ(S3S4); CA(SNR); NM(SNR); NV(SNR); TX(SNR)
Red List rationale: Helianthus niveus is globally assessed as Data Deficient as there is currently insufficient information available to evaluate this species. Although it is possibly secure across its range, there is evidence that some parts of its native range are threatened, including parts of the range of H. niveus subsp. tephrodes. This species does occur in protected areas in situ and there is one accession held ex situ, however, active in situ population management and monitoring is recommended as well as additional collecting of germplasm for ex situ conservation. Surveys to determine population size, distribution and trend information are also required to be able to accurately assess this species.
Red List habitat: Helianthus niveus is found on disturbed, sandy sites (Schilling 2006, Calflora 2016). In Mexico it is found in arid, sandy soils, coastal dunes and xerophytic scrubs (GÃ³mez and GonzÃ¡lez 1995, Felger 2000, LeÃ³n de la Luz 2013). In Greater San QuintÃ­n, Baja California, it is found along the coasts on sandy soils of dunes, riparian and middens (Vanderplank 2011). H. niveus subsp. tephrodes (Algodones Dunes Sunflower) is found in subshrub habitats and sand hills (Schilling 2006, CNPS 2016).
Red List threats: Threats to Helianthus niveus include declining of habitat quality due to human activities and development, including urbanization, mining, agriculture, off-road vehicles use and livestock grazing (Vanderplank 2011).
Red List population:
In 1991, Helianthus niveus was ranked as apparently secure throughout its range, as plants of this species are uncommon but not rare (NatureServe 2015). At local level, it was ranked as vulnerable in Arizona (NatureServe 2015, CNPS 2016) and rare in the California Floristic Province portion of Baja California (Vanderplank 2011, Vanderplank et al. 2014). 

The California Native Plant Society (CNPS 2016) ranked H. niveus subsp. tephrodes as rare, threatened or endangered throughout its range, but fairly endangered in California, with a population that has declined over the past century. In 1997, the subspecies was globally ranked as rare (having around 21â100 occurrences or 3,000â10,000 individuals) and locally ranked as critically imperilled in Arizona and California (having five or fewer occurrences, or 1,000 or fewer individuals) (Walter and Gillett 1998).
Red List range: Helianthus niveus is native to southwest United States of America (Texas, New Mexico, Arizona, California) and northern Mexico (Baja California, Baja California Sur, Sonora), occurring between 50 m to 300 m a.s.l., and there is one accepted subspecies: H. niveus subsp. tephrodes distributed in Arizona, California and Sonora (Heiser et al. 1969, GÃ³mez and GonzÃ¡lez 1995, Felger 2000, Schilling 2006, Vanderplank 2011, The Plant List 2013, LeÃ³n de la Luz 2013, LeÃ³n de la Luz et al. 2015, Calflora 2016, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2016).
Red List use trade: This species is a secondary genetic relative of the cultivated Sunflower Helianthus annuus with potential for use as a gene donor for crop quality and disease resistance (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013), it is also a Taxon Group four relative of the Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus L. (Schilling and Heiser 1981)
Red List conservation actions: Helianthus niveus occurs in at least three protected areas in California: Joshua Tree National Park, Mojave and Colorado Deserts Biosphere Reserve and Philip L. Boyd Deep Canyon Desert Research Center (Information Center for the Environment (ICE) 2016). In Mexico, the species occurs in the Biosphere Reserve El VizcaÃ­no, Baja California (INE 2000). There is one available accession of H. niveus conserved in the North Central Regional PI Station, Iowa State University, with a duplicate conserved in the National Center for Genetic Resources Preservation, Fort Collins (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2016).

NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: AZ(SNR); CA(SU); NM(SNR); NV(SNR); TX(SNR)

Red List rationale: Helianthus nuttallii is globally assessed as Least Concern as it is a widespread species across northern America which appears to be secure, despite the extinction of one subspecies.. It is subject to both ex situ and passive in situ conservation, though the establishment of active in situ population monitoring and management would benefit this species, particularly in states/provinces where it is thought to be vulnerable or imperilled (i.e. Minnesota, Manitoba and British Colombia).
Red List habitat: Habitat type is variable for all subordinate taxa: subsp. parishii (now thought to be extinct) was found in freshwater and salt marshes of California at 10â500 m a.s.l., while subsp. nuttallii is found in moist open places, in ditches and on roadsides from 300â2,700 m a.s.l. and subsp. rydbergii is found in open areas on sandy dry soils and in wet places from 200â1,000 m a.s.l. (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006).
Red List threats:
Extinction of H. nuttallii subsp. parishii is documented to have been caused by urbanization (CNPS 2010), more specifically this includes land conversion for a community park as part of a large scale community housing project, draining of marshes, channelization of watercourses and potentially grazing as well (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006, NatureServe 2013). 

The threats to H. nuttallii and its other subordinate taxa remain unknown.
Red List population: According to NatureServe (2013), Helianthus nuttallii is globally and nationally secure. Looking more specifically at individual subspecies, H. nuttallii subsp. nuttallii is also globally and nationally secure, as is H. nuttallii subsp. rydbergi although it is ranked as vulnerable in Minnesota, imperilled in Manitoba and critically imperilled in British Columbia (NatureServe 2013). However, H. nuttallii subsp. parishii is possibly extinct in California as the subpopulation that was rediscovered in 2002 has since been identified as the new taxon H. inexpectatus (Keil and Elvin 2010, NatureServe 2013).
Red List range:
This species and its three subspecies, H. nuttallii subsp. nuttallii, H. nuttallii subsp. rydbergiand H. nuttallii subsp. parishii, are native to central and western states of the United States of America, the former two subspecies are also native to Canada (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2014). It occurs at elevations between 10 m and 2,700 m a.s.l. (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006).

H. nuttallii subsp. nuttallii is native to the states of Arizona, California, Colorado, Idaho, Kansas, Missouri, Montana, Nebraska, Nevada, New Mexico, North Dakota, Oregon, South Dakota, Utah, Washington and Wyoming in the United States to the provinces of Alberta, Manitoba and Saskatchewan in Canada; H. nuttallii subsp. rydbergi is native to Colorado, Iowa, Kansas, Minnesota, Montana, Nebraska, North Dakota and South Dakota in the United States of America and to the provinces of Alberta, British Colombia, Manitoba and Saskatchewan in Canada; H. nuttallii subsp. parishii is endemic to Los Angeles, Orange and San Benito counties in California (NatureServe 2013).
Red List use trade:
This species is a tertiary wild relative of the cultivated Sunflower Helianthus annuus (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013) and belongs to Taxon Group two of the Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus (Schilling and Heiser 1981) and so has potential for use as a gene donor for crop improvement.

In addition, the genus Helianthus attracts large numbers of native bees and so is listed in the Pollinator programme at The Xerces Society for Invertebrate Conservation (Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center 2013).
Red List conservation actions:
The National Plant Germplasm System (NPGS, in the USA) stores six, 21 and 12 accessions of wild origin for Helianthus nuttallii, H. nuttallii subsp. nuttallii and H. nuttallii subsp. rydbergi respectively and all of these accessions are backed up at a second site; no accessions were found for H. nuttallii subsp. parishii. (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2014). Additionally, H. nuttallii, H. nuttallii subsp. nuttallii and H. nuttallii subsp. rydbergi have living collections in 12, three and one botanical garden(s) worldwide, while H. nuttallii subsp. parishii has two living collections (BGCI 2013).

In terms of in situ conservation and according to the Biological inventories of the world's protected areas (Information Center for the Environment (ICE) 2013), H. nuttallii is thought to be subject to passive in situ conservation in the following protected areas:
  • Aztec Ruins National Monument, New Mexico
  • Carlsbad Caverns National Park, New Mexico
  • Guadalupe Mountains National Park, New Mexico
  • John Day Fossil Beds National Monument, Oregon (common with reproducing population present)
  • Yellowstone Biosphere Reserve, Idaho, Montana, Wyoming (uncommon with reproducing population present)
  • Bighorn Canyon National Recreation Area, Montana (uncommon)
  • Glacier National Park and Biosphere Reserve, Montana (uncommon with reproducing population present)
  • Banff National Park, Canada (reproducing population present)
  • Redberry Lake Biosphere Reserve, Canada (rare with reproducing population present)
  • Waterton Lakes National Park, Canada (reproducing population present).

H. nuttallii subsp. nuttallii is presumed to be subject to passive in situ conservation in the following protected areas (Information Center for the Environment (ICE) 2013) :
  • Curecanti National Recreation Area, Colorado
  • Death Valley National Park, California
  • Mojave and Colorado Deserts Biosphere Reserve, California.

H. nuttallii subsp. rydbergii is thought to have reproducing populations present in the following Canadian protected areas where passive in situ conservation is presumed (Information Center for the Environment (ICE) 2013) :
  • Elk Island National Park
  • Forillon National Park
  • Fundy National Park
  • Grasslands National Park
  • Prince Albert National Park
  • Riding Mountain Biosphere Reserve.

Red List rationale:
Helianthus paradoxus is globally assessed as Least Concern. Despite being listed as threatened under the U.S. Endangered Species Act and its reliance on a rare and threatened wetland habitat, the species was reported to be relatively stable in 1998 and active management and monitoring of this species has since been implemented thanks to the species recovery plan published in 2005 (USFWS 2005). There is evidence to suggest the provision of active in situ conservation is having a positive effect on population sizes and is even allowing the species to reestablish in previously lost areas. The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service aim to delist the species from the Endangered Species Act by 2019.

However, due to its reliance on cienega habitats and the various threats it faces, if there is a sudden cessation of conservation actions it could cause sudden losses of subpopulations of this species. Therefore, it is vital that the cooperative management plans that have been established as part of the species' recovery plan are upheld and continue in the long-term. Ongoing education of the public and land owners and the strengthening of state, federal and private partnerships are essential.
Red List habitat: This annual herb can grow to 1â2 m in height and is found in wetland habitat with permanently saturated soils called cienegas (desert springs and seeps); it can also be found on margins of lakes, creeks and impoundments (USFWS 2005). Cienegas are a rare wetland habitat in the arid southwest region of the United States of America (Hendrickson and Minckley 1984) and typically have saline/alkaline soils due to the presence of water that is high in dissolved solids coupled with high evaporation rates that leave salt deposits (USFWS 2005).
Red List threats: The primary threat to the population of Helianthus paradoxus is the loss of wetland habitat through the lowering of ground water levels as water is diverted/extracted for agriculture and urban development purposes (USFWS 2005). Competition from exotic species is also a prominent threat to H. paradoxus, particularly due to the spread of salt cedar (Tamarix ssp.) which removes all native vegetation from wetlands that it invades and alters the habitat to become drier and more saline (NatureServe 2013). Hybridization between this species and common Sunflower has also been observed in some areas where they co-occur and this has the potential to compromise the genetic integrity of the H. paradoxus population (NatureServe 2005). The same source also highlights that livestock grazing and wildfires can have negative impacts on H. paradoxus populations, however there is evidence to suggest that some level of grazing can reduce competition and actually benefit these sunflower populations if it occurs at an appropriate stage of the plant's life cycle i.e. non-flowering months (USFWS 2005). Another threat to this species is the development of wetlands for other uses, furthermore some populations occur on private land where owners have expressed an interest in draining the wetlands on which the species occurs (NatureServe 2013). Finally, one of the sites in west Texas occurs in an oil and gas field where there is potential for contamination of the desert spring and ground water (NatureServe 2013).
Red List population: According to NatureServe (2013), Helianthus paradoxus is imperilled in New Mexico and critically imperilled in Texas however, it should be noted that these statuses were last reviewed in March 2003 and since then a recovery plan has been put in place (USFWS 2005). It is known to occur in seven localities, five of which are within the state of New Mexico (two separate localities in the Pecos River Valley in eastern New Mexico, two localities on the Rio San Jose and one locality on the Rio Grande in west-central New Mexico) and two of which are located in desert springs in west Texas (USFWS 2005). The locality in Diamond Y Creek in Texas is thought to contain hundreds of thousands of individuals and the other locality, in East Sandia Springs, contains thousands of individuals (NatureServe 2013). NatureServe (2013) suggest that, during surveys carried out before 2003, only a couple of the subpopulations in New Mexico were locally abundant (with greater than 3,000 individuals) whereas many of the others were small and non-viable. Furthermore, in 1999, this species was listed as threatened under the US Endangered Species Act (USESA). Although at the time the overall population was considered to be relatively stable it was also recognized that its long-term survival was completely dependent on the maintenance and protection of suitable habitat (NatureServe 2013). More recent anecdotal evidence suggests that the numbers of individuals and subpopulations of H. paradoxus may be increasing due to successful conservation activities (Zenone 2012).
Red List range: Helianthus paradoxus is endemic to the states of New Mexico and Texas in the United States of America, occurring at elevations between 1,000 m and 1,200 m a.s.l. (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006).
Red List use trade:
This species belongs to Gene Pool two of the cultivated Sunflower Helianthus annuus (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013) and Taxon Group four of the Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus (Schilling and Heiser 1981), as a result this species has potential for use as a gene donor for crop improvement, particularly as a source of salt tolerance for sunflower (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

In addition, the genus Helianthus attracts large numbers of native bees and so is listed in the Pollinator programme at The Xerces Society for Invertebrate Conservation (Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center 2013).
Red List conservation actions:
Despite the vast array of threats identified that may be affecting this species, conservation measures are in place across this species' native range. In 1999, it was listed as threatened under the U.S. Endangered Species Act and in 2005 a species recovery plan was adopted to work towards long-term protection and management of the species so that it may be removed from the Endangered Species Act by 2019 (USFWS 2005). The recovery plan aimed to achieve this by: 1) identifying core conservation areas and isolated stands of the species, 2) identifying and filling gaps in knowledge regarding appropriate management actions based on the species' life history and habitat, 3) implementing active protection of these core conservation areas and isolated stands through landowner education, management plans and land acquisition and 4) monitoring these sunflower populations and their management in the long-term to ensure the species can be removed from the Endangered Species Act (USFWS 2005).

There is evidence to suggest this recovery plan is having positive results. The Nature Conservancy own both localities where this species occurs in Texas and actively manage the subpopulations through exotic species removal, rotational grazing programs and on-going hydrological research (USFWS 2005). Furthermore, Zenone (2012) report that the state of New Mexico has acquired Blue Hole Cienega (in Santa Rosa, New Mexico) where fencing was then put up, cattle removed and exotic invasive trees were also removed, all of which have had positive effects on the size of the Helianthus paradoxus population at this locality and it is thought to be permanently protected. The same author highlights a number of cooperative management plans and actions that have been established across the species' range on tribal, private, state and federal lands, which are seeing population expansion and re-establishment in areas where it had previously been lost.

In terms of ex situ collection, ten accessions of wild origin are held by the National Plant Germplasm System (NPGS, in the USA), all of which are backed up at a second site (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2014) and the species also has one living collection in a botanical garden though the location of this collection is not reported (BGCI 2013).

Red List rationale: Helianthus pauciflorus is globally assessed as Least Concern as it is widespread across Canada and the United States of America and is reported by NatureServe (2013) as both globally and nationally secure. Some ex situ collection of this species has already taken place but a gap analysis to determine whether these collections are representative of the whole of the species' range is recommended. Monitoring of in situ populations should be established to ensure the population remains stable, this is particularly important in states/provinces that report the presence of threatened subpopulations.
Red List habitat: The subspecies pauciflorus occurs in dry to moderately wet prairies and open places, while the subspecies subrhomboideus occurs in dry, open habitats (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006); it has also been recorded on roadsides (NatureServe 2013).
Red List threats: The threats to this species remain unknown.
Red List population:
According to NatureServe (2013), Helianthus pauciflorus is documented to be globally and nationally secure; it is recorded as imperilled in Ontario, Canada but according to the Flora of North America (2006) it is introduced in this part of its range.

The subspecies pauciflorus is reported as critically imperilled in Arkansas but apparently secure in Iowa, while the subspecies subrhomboideus is vulnerable in Wyoming, secure in Saskatchewan and apparently secure in Alberta and Manitoba; overall, both subspecies are recorded as globally and nationally secure (NatureServe 2013).
Red List range: This species is native to Canada and the United States of America, and is naturalized in Europe and eastern Canada; it is also cultivated (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013). Helianthus pauciflorus subsp. pauciflorus occurs at elevations between 50 m and 600 m a.s.l. whereas H. pauciflorus subsp. subromboideus occurs between 400 m and 2,400 m a.s.l. (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006).
Red List use trade:
This species is a tertiary wild relative of the cultivated Sunflower Helianthus annuus (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013) and so it has potential for use as a gene donor for crop improvement. It has already been used to confer cytoplasmic male fertility (Jan et al. 2002) and Sclerotinia resistance (Miller and Gulya 1999) to Sunflower. It also belongs to Taxon Group four of Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus (Schilling and Heiser 1981) and is cultivated as an ornamental (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

In addition, the genus Helianthus attracts large numbers of native bees and so is listed in the Pollinator programme at The Xerces Society for Invertebrate Conservation (Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center 2013).
Red List conservation actions:
Helianthus pauciflorus subsp. pauciflorus has five living collections in botanical gardens worldwide, while H. pauciflorus subsp. subrhomboideus has three (BGCI 2013).
In addition, nine accessions of wild origin are held by the National Plant Germplasm System (NPGS), all of which are backed up at a second site (USDA, ARS. National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

It is not known whether this species occurs in any protected areas, therefore survey work to determine any existing passive or active in situ conservation is recommended.

Red List rationale: Helianthus petiolaris is globally assessed as Least Concern as it is a widespread species across North America and is recorded by NatureServe (2013) as globally and nationally secure. Active population monitoring is recommended to ensure the population remains stable, particularly in Manitoba where this species is recorded as vulnerable.
Red List habitat: Helianthus petiolaris is found in dry, open areas, and subspecies petiolaris prefers sandy soils (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006).
Red List threats: The threats to this species remain unknown.
Red List population: This species is widespread throughout Canada and the United States of America and is recorded as globally and nationally secure in both of these countries (NatureServe 2013). According to NatureServe (2013) the only part of its range where is it not secure is Manitoba in Canada where is it recorded as vulnerable.
Red List range: This species is native to Canada and the United States of America (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013). Subspecies petiolaris is widespread across these two countries and occurs at elevations between 10 m and 1,500 m a.s.l., while subspecies fallax has a much more limited native distribution, occurring in the American states of Arizona, Colorado, Nevada, New Mexico and Utah and at elevations between 1,200 m and 2,500 m a.s.l. (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006).
Red List use trade:
This species and subordinate taxa are secondary wild relatives of the cultivated Sunflower Helianthus annuus (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013), and have already been used to confer cytoplasmic male sterility (Prescott-Allen and Prescott-Allen 1986), Verticillium resistance (Hoes et al. 1973), disease resistance (Jan et al. 2004), fertility restoration genes (Seiler 1991) and sunflower moth resistance (Rogers et al. 1984) to sunflower. It also belongs to Taxon Group four of the Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus (Schilling and Heiser 1981).

In addition, the genus Helianthus attracts large numbers of native bees and so is listed in the Pollinator programme at The Xerces Society for Invertebrate Conservation (Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center 2013).
Red List conservation actions:
In terms of ex situ conservation, the National Plant Germplasm System (NPGS, in the USA) holds 20 accessions of Helianthus petiolaris, 13 of which are of wild origin and backed up at a second site (USDA, ARS, National Plant Genetic Resources Program 2013). The same source reports one accession of subspecies fallax and 53 accessions of subspecies petiolaris, all of which are of wild origin and backed up at a second site. H. petiolaris also has living collections in eight botanical gardens worldwide, while subspecies fallax has one living collection and subspecies petiolaris has four (BGCI 2013).

It is also thought to be subject to passive in situ conservation in at least 41 protected areas in North America (see Information Center for the Environment (ICE) 2013 for further details), while subspecies fallax is associated with the following four protected areas: Canyonlands National Park, Utah (reproducing population present), Natural Bridges National Monument, Utah (reproducing population present), Chaco Culture National Historical Park, New Mexico (status unknown), and Coronado National Monument Arizona (status not recorded).

TX(SNR)
Red List rationale: This species is globally assessed as Least Concern as it is reported to be secure across its range in Texas (NatureServe 2013). Whilst Helianthus praecox subsp. hirtus is recorded as imperilled, it appears to still have a very large, stable population and as such, is not cause for immediate concern. However, there is a lack of information regarding in situ conservation efforts and so it is recommended that population surveys are carried out for the species as a whole (but with a particular focus on subsp. hirtus and subsp. praecox which are both recorded as imperilled) to determine population trends and localities that coincide with protected areas. Active monitoring (and management, where appropriate) of populations should then be implemented to ensure long-term survival of the species, particularly in Dimmit county where urbanization poses a threat.
Red List habitat: This species and its subspecies occur on sandy soils; more specifically, the subspecies hirtus occurs on well-drained sandy soils in open shrublands or shrub-invaded grasslands and the subspecies runyonii is found in coastal prairies on the South Texas Sand Sheet (NatureServe 2013).
Red List threats: Helianthus praecox subsp. hirtus has a very restricted population that is threatened by urbanization as the town of Carrizo Spring grows; grazing and hybridization with co-occurring populations of common sunflower also present plausible threats to this subspecies (NatureServe 2013). Further threats to this species and its other subspecies remain unknown.
Red List population: NatureServe (2013) reports that this species is apparently secure, however, Helianthus praecox subsp. hirtus and H. praecox subsp. praecox are both recorded as imperilled. Despite this, H. praecox subsp. hirtus is reported to occur in 35â40 subpopulations in northwestern Dimmit County, Texas and estimates suggest that approximately 1.7 million individuals occur on public land in this area, increasing to nearly 10 million individuals when private land is taken into account (NatureServe 2013). The overall population of this subspecies is thought to be relatively stable but that some subpopulations are increasing while others are declining (NatureServe 2013). Finally, the subspecies runyonii is common, weedy, disturbance tolerant and secure (NatureServe 2013).
Red List range: This species and all three subspecies are endemic to the state of Texas in the United States of America (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006). Helianthus praecox subsp. hirtus occurs in the county of Dimmit, near the town of Carrizo Springs, in southern Texas, between 50 m and 100 m a.s.l., while subsp. runyonii and subsp. praecox are more widespread in southern Texas and occur at elevations from sea level to 50 m a.s.l. (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006, Turner 2014).
Red List use trade:
This species and its subordinate taxa are secondary wild relatives of the cultivated Sunflower Helianthus annuus (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013) and have already been used in plant breeding to confer downy mildew, rust, Verticillium wilt and broomrape resistance (Hajjar and Hodgkin 2007), and fertility restoration genes (Seiler 1991) to sunflower. It also belongs to Taxon Group four of the Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus (Schilling and Heiser 1981).

In addition, the genus Helianthus attracts large numbers of native bees and so is listed in the Pollinator programme at The Xerces Society for Invertebrate Conservation (Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center 2013).
Red List conservation actions:
Little is known about the provision of in situ conservation for this species.

However, in terms of ex situ conservation, it is known that the National Plant Germplasm System (NPGS, in the USA) holds the following numbers of accessions for the subspecies of Helianthus praecox, all are of wild origin and are backed up at a second site (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2014):
  • Six accessions of H. praecox subsp. praecox
  • One accession of H. praecox subsp. hirtus
  • Six accessions of H. praecox subsp. runyonii.

Living collections of this species are present in four botanical gardens worldwide, and each subspecies also has at least one living collection in a botanical garden (BGCI 2013).

Red List rationale: This species is globally assessed as Least Concern as, although it is uncommon in North Carolina, it is apparently secure in the rest of its global native range. It is also subject to ex situ conservation. However, this species would benefit from surveys to confirm population trends and to identify threats and areas suitable for active in situ conservation and population monitoring to ensure the long-term survival of the species.
Red List habitat: This species occurs on roadsides and in open areas (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006).
Red List threats: The threats to this species remain unknown.
Red List population: According to NatureServe (2013), this species is recorded as apparently secure across its full native range in North America, however it is vulnerable in the state of North Carolina where Krings et al. (2012) report that it is uncommon.
Red List range: This species is native to the southeastern states of Alabama, Florida, Georgia, Mississippi, North Carolina and South Carolina in the United States of America; it is found at elevations from sea level to 900 m a.s.l. (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006).
Red List use trade:
This species is a tertiary wild relative of the cultivated Sunflower Helianthus annuus (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013) and has already been used in plant breeding to confer fertility restoration (Seiler 1991) to sunflower. It also belongs to Taxon Group two of the Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus (Schilling and Heiser 1981) and is cultivated as an ornamental (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

In addition, the genus Helianthus attracts large numbers of native bees and so is listed in the Pollinator programme at The Xerces Society for Invertebrate Conservation (Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center 2013).
Red List conservation actions: This species has 19 accessions held in the National Plant Germplasm System (NPGS, in the USA) that are of wild origin and backed up at a second site (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013), it also has living collections in four botanical gardens worldwide (BGCI 2013). No evidence of in situ conservation was found for this species.

NatureServe G RANK REASONS: Rank of G4 from Texas Heritage Program (7/94). Locally common in east Kansas limestone outcrops.
NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: IL(SNA); KS(SNR); MD(SNR); MO(SNR); NE(SNR); NY(SNA); OH(SNR); OK(SNR); TX(S2)
Red List rationale: Helianthus salicifolius is globally assessed as Least Concern as, although it is reported to be imperilled in Texas, it is apparently secure across its native range as a whole and is locally common in Kansas. It is also subject to ex situ conservation, however there is little available information regarding existing in situ conservation activities. Research to determine the population trend in Texas and threats across the whole of its range would benefit this species and would enable the establishment of active population management and monitoring to ensure long-term survival of this species.
Red List habitat: This species occurs on limestone prairies and outcrops (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006).
Red List threats: The threats to this species remain unknown.
Red List population: According to NatureServe (2013), Helianthus salicifolius is reported to be apparently secure both globally and nationally but is imperilled in Texas, despite this, it is not included in Texas rare plant publications (Poole et al. 2007). It is locally common in east Kansas limestone outcrops (NatureServe 2013).
Red List range: This species is native to the United States of America, particularly in the region of the Ozark Plateau including the states of Kansas, Missouri, Nebraska, Oklahoma and Texas; it also occurs in Maryland and Ohio but is naturalized in Illinois and New York (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006, NatureServe 2013). It occurs at elevations between 100 m and 300 m a.s.l. (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006).
Red List use trade:
Helianthus salicifolius is a tertiary wild relative of the cultivated Sunflower H. annuus (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013) and has already been used in plant breeding to confer high leaf crude protein concentration (Seiler 1983) to sunflower. It also belongs to Taxon Group two of the Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus (Schilling and Heiser 1981) and is cultivated as an ornamental (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

In addition, the genus Helianthus attracts large numbers of native bees and so is listed in the Pollinator programme at The Xerces Society for Invertebrate Conservation (Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center 2013).
Red List conservation actions: This species has 19 accessions in the National Plant Germplams System (NPGS, in the USA) all of which are of wild origin and backed up at a second site (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013), it also has living collections in 49 botanical gardens worldwide (BGCI 2013). No evidence of in situ conservation was found for this species.

NatureServe G RANK REASONS: Endemic to North and South Carolina. There are 63 extant occurrences known in NC; most of them along roadsides where they are difficult to protect. The species has lost much of its native habitat to forest succession due to the elimination of natural dist
NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: NC(S3); SC(S3)

NatureServe G RANK REASONS: GRANK from botanists at TNC 1992 SE Conference. Helianthus silphioides is fairly abundant in a somewhat limited range.
NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: AL(SNR); AR(SNR); IL(S1?); KY(S1); LA(S3S4); MO(SNR); MS(S4?); OK(S1); TN(S2S3)
Red List rationale: This species is globally assessed as Least Concern as, although it is reported to be imperilled in some areas with plausible threats, it is secure, abundant and stable in a large proportion of its global native range. It is also subject to ex situ conservation and occurs in at least two protected areas. However, because it is imperilled in some parts of its range, it is important that populations are actively monitored to prevent loss of individual/populations, particularly in Illinois, Oklahoma and Kentucky. Including the species on existing protected area management plans would be beneficial.
Red List habitat: This species occurs in open sites with high light availability and acidic soil (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006), this includes low sandy or alluvial soil near streams, fallow fields, woodland borders, dry uplands, open woods, thickets and roadsides (Steyermark 1963).
Red List threats: The major threats to this species include habitat conversion for agriculture, pastureland or closed canopy pine plantations, invasive species (e.g. Kudzu and Japanese Honeysuckle) and development (NatureServe 2013).
Red List population: According to NatureServe (2013) this species as apparently secure both globally and nationally and is fairly abundant despite its limited range. However, the same source reports that is it critically imperilled in Illinois (where it is possibly extinct (Vlaszek 1985)), Kentucky and Oklahoma, imperilled in Tennessee, vulnerable in Louisiana but apparently secure in Mississippi. Despite these reports that it is threatened in a number of these states, NatureServe (2013) also report that the species is abundant in Alabama, Tennessee and Mississippi and state that the species has been collected from 34 counties in Arkansas. As a result it is suspected that the overall native population is somewhat stable (NatureServe 2013).
Red List range: This species is native to the north-central and southeastern states of Alabama, Arkansas, Illinois, Kentucky, Louisiana, Mississippi, Missouri, Oklahoma and Tennessee in the United States of America and it found at elevations between 100 m and 300 m a.s.l. (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006).
Red List use trade:
Helianthus silphioides is a tertiary wild relative of the cultivated Sunflower H. annuus (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013) and has potential for use as a gene donor for plant breeding, particular due to its high oleic acid concentration (Seiler 1984). It also belongs to Taxon Group four of the Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus (Schilling and Heiser 1981) and is cultivated as an ornamental (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

In addition, the genus Helianthus attracts large numbers of native bees and so is listed in the Pollinator programme at The Xerces Society for Invertebrate Conservation (Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center 2013).
Red List conservation actions:
In terms of ex situ conservation, 15 accessions are conserved in the National Plant Germplasm System (NPGS, in the USA) all of which are of wild origin and backed up at a second site (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013). It is also found in three botanical gardens worldwide (BGCI 2013). 

This species is associated with the Obed Wild and Scenic River protected area as well as the Shiloh National Military Park in Tennessee and so is presumed to be subject to some passive in situ conservation (Information Center for the Environment (ICE) 2013). No evidence of active in situ conservation was found.

Red List rationale: This species is globally assessed as Least Concern as it is a widespread species that is secure in the majority of its range across North America. It is thought to be present in a number of protected areas, but survey work should be carried out to confirm this, and ex situ collections of the species are stored in gene banks. Active population management and monitoring in protected areas would benefit this species, particularly in Saskatchewan, Canada to ensure the long-term survival of the species. It is also important to ensure that the range of genetic diversity within the species is fully represented in populations conserved in situ and accessions stored ex situ.
Red List habitat: Wild populations of this species are most commonly found in disturbed habitat such as roadsides, in old fields and meadows, moist river and stream banks, and waste areas (Gleason and Cronquist 1963, Alex and Switzer 1976, Kays and Nottingham 2007).
Red List threats: The threats to this species remain unknown.
Red List population: NatureServe (2013) records this species as secure globally and nationally (USA and Canada) and so it is suspected that its population trend is stable, however, it is recorded as imperilled in Saskatchewan, Canada.
Red List range: The exact native range of Helianthus tuberosus is uncertain, however, NatureServe (2013) report it as native to Saskatchewan and Ontario in Canada and to many states of the United States of America, particularly in central and eastern regions. It is found at elevations between sea level and 1,000 m a.s.l. (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006). It is also widely naturalized and cultivated in temperate regions throughout the world, particularly in Europe (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).
Red List use trade:
Helianthus tuberosum is widely cultivated for its tuberous root that is used as human food and drink and animal fodder and forage; it is also used to produce alcohol in the French Cognac industry, ithas potential as a petroleum substitute, and the tubers contain 8% inulin â a polysaccharide that may be of use to diabetics (NatureServe 2013, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013). 

Wild H. tuberosum belong to Taxon Group 1b of the cultivated H. tuberosum and the tertiary Gene Pool of cultivated Sunflower H. annuus and so has potential for use as a gene donor for crop improvement (Schilling and Heiser 1981, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

In addition, the genus Helianthus attracts large numbers of native bees and so is listed in the Pollinator programme at The Xerces Society for Invertebrate Conservation (Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center 2013).
Red List conservation actions:
Thirty-five accessions are held at the National Plant Germplasm System (NPGS, in the USA), all of which are of wild origin and backed up at a second site (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

In terms of in situ conservation, this species is associated with 27 protected areas and so is presumed to be subject to passive protected in these areas (Information Center for the Environment (ICE 2013), though no evidence of active conservation could be found.

Red List rationale: Hordeum arizonicum is globally assessed as Near Threatened as it has been described as uncommon, it is globally vulnerable according to NatureServe (2014) which suggests it has a moderate risk of extinction and it has an area of occupancy that meets the threshold for classification as Endangered and is suspected to be declining (although there is a lack of population information available to meet all criteria necessary for this category). An understanding of the threats facing this species is urgently required. Vincent et al. (2012) recognize that this species is a priority for ex situ collection. Furthermore, active in situ management and monitoring is recommended to ensure the long-term survival of this species.
Red List habitat: Hordeum arizonicum is an annual graminoid species that grows in saline habitats, along irrigation, ditches, canals and ponds (von Bothmer et al. 2012).
Red List threats: The threats to this species remain unknown.
Red List population: According to the Jepson Flora Project (2013), this species is uncommon. It is also classified as nationally imperilled in the United States of America and globally vulnerable (NatureServe 2014). As a result, it is assumed that the population is in decline and survey work is a priority to determine accurate measures of population size and trend.
Red List range: Hordeum arizonicum is native to southwestern and south-central United States of America and Sonoro in northern Mexico (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2014).
Red List use trade: Hordeum arizonicum is a tertiary genetic relative of Barley (H. vulgare L.) and so it has the potential for use as a gene donor for crop improvement (von Bothmer et al. 1995).
Red List conservation actions:
The genus Hordeum is listed in Annex I of the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture (ITPGRFA) which aims to guarantee sustainable agriculture and food security through the conservation and sustainable use of plant genetic resources for food and agriculture, as well as ensuring the fair and equitable sharing of the benefits arising out of their use (FAO 2009).

No germplasm accessions of this species are held in the National Plant Germplasm System (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2014). While 10 accessions (5,000 seeds) are duplicated and conserved ex situ in the Svalbard Global Seed Vault, originating from one genebank (SGSV Data Portal 2013). EURISCO reports eight germplasm accessions held in European genebanks, none of which are reported to be of wild or weedy origin, and six of which have no reported information regarding their origin (EURISCO Catalogue 2013).

The GrainGenes database (USDA, ARS 2014) reports accessions in the following collections: Gatersleben (one accession), National Small Grain Collection USDA-ARS (one accession), Research Institute for Bioresource Okayama University (one accession), and Plant Gene Resources of Canada Central Experimental Farm Agriculture (one accession). However, it is unknown whether these are of wild origin and whether they are unique accessions or duplicated material. Vincent et al. (2012) report 14 accessions from seven sources thought to contain the largest collections of wild Hordeum seed accessions, identifying this species as a high priority for ex situ conservation within its genus.

According to Botanical Garden Conservation International (BGCI 2013) this species has a living collection in one botanical garden worldwide, although the size, state, origin and location of the collection are not detailed in this resource (garden locations are undisclosed to protect rare and valuable plant species).

This species' native distribution overlaps with at least one protected area, inferred using GeoCAT (Bachman et al. 2011), and so passive conservation is presumed in this area. However, there is no evidence of active management or monitoring of this species despite being vulnerable according to NatureServe (2014).

NatureServe CANADIAN PROVINCES AND S RAN: AB(S3); BC(S5); LB(S1S2); NF(S2); NS(S1); QC(S1); SK(S1); YT(SNA)
Red List rationale: Hordeum brachyantherum is globally assessed as Least Concern as it is widespread throughout the USA and parts of Canada, also occurring in one region of the Russian Federation (Kamchatka), and its global population is thought to be stable. It has accessions stored ex situ and it also occurs in some existing protected areas. It is recommended that active management and monitoring of in situ populations is established, particularly in regions where the species is thought to be threatened (e.g. Quebec and Saskatchewan in Canada).
Red List habitat: Hordeum brachyantherum grows in salt marshes, pastures, woodlands, subartic woodland meadows and sub-alpine meadows (von Bothmer et al. 2012).
Red List threats: The threats to this species remain unknown.
Red List population: Populations are reported to be uncommon in Illinois (though according to NatureServe (2013) it is also exotic in Illinois) but common to sporadic elsewhere, being a dominant species in pastures and producing large stands where found (von bothmer et al. 1995). Furthermore, it is documented by NatureServe (2013) to be secure in both Canada and the United States of America, despite also being classed as imperilled on Newfoundland Island and critically imperilled in Quebec and Saskatchewan, Canada. Overall the global population is thought to be stable.
Red List range: This species is native across North America, also occurring in Baja California in Mexico and in Kamchatka in the Russian Federation (NatureServe 2013, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2014).
Red List use trade: Hordeum brachyantherum is a tertiary genetic relative of Barley (H. vulgare L.) (von Bothmer et al. 1995) and as a result it has the potential for use as a gene donor for crop improvement.
Red List conservation actions:
The genus Hordeum is listed in Annex I of the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture (ITPGRFA) which aims to guarantee sustainable agriculture and food security through the conservation and sustainable use of plant genetic resources for food and agriculture, as well as ensuring the fair and equitable sharing of the benefits arising out of their use (FAO 2009).

The National Plant Germplasm System holds seven germplasm accessions of this species, all of which are of wild origin and backed up at a second site (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2014). A total of 70 accessions (35,000 seeds) are duplicated and conserved ex situ in the Svalbard Global Seed Vault, originating from two genebanks (SGSV Data Portal 2013). EURISCO reports 69 germplasm accessions held in European genebanks, none of which are reported to be of wild or weedy origin, and 64 of which have no reported information regarding their origin (EURISCO Catalogue 2013).

The GrainGenes database (USDA, ARS 2014) reports accessions in the following collections: IPK Genebank at Gatersleben (three accessions), Institute of Grassland & Environmental Research (IGER) (one accession), the National Small Grain Collection USDA-ARS (eight accessions), and the Research Institute for Bioresource Okayama University (one accession). However, it is unknown whether these are of wild origin and whether they are unique accessions or duplicated material. Vincent et al. (2012) report 160 accessions from seven sources thought to contain the largest collections of wild Hordeum seed accessions, identifying this species as low priority for ex situ conservation within its genus.

According to Botanical Garden Conservation International (BGCI 2013) this species has living collections in nine botanical gardens worldwide, although the size, state, origin and location of the collections are not detailed in this resource (garden locations are undisclosed to protect rare and valuable plant species).

This species' native distribution overlaps with at least one protected area in the United States of America, inferred using GeoCAT (Bachman et al. 2011) and so passive conservation is presumed in this area.

NatureServe G RANK REASONS: Common and widespread in western U.S. and Canada; found in meadows; pastures and streambanks; coastal areas and wet to mesic meadows.

Red List rationale: Hordeum depressum is globally assessed as Least Concern as it thought to be globally secure. However, further research to determine the population size and threats facing the species would be beneficial. Collection of germplasm for conservation ex situ is a priority for this species.
Red List habitat: Hordeum depressum grows in saline areas, vernal pools and ephemeral habitats, often in alkaline soil, and it may also occur close to agricultural land in ditches and canals (von Bothmer et al. 1995, 2012).
Red List threats: The threats to this species remain unknown.
Red List population: According to NatureServe (2013), this species is globally secure. Although von Bothmer et al. (1995) states that this species is scattered in central and southern California where suitable habitats occur, with a few localities in Oregon and Washington, the global population is thought to be secure.
Red List range: This species is native to the states of Idaho, Oregon, Washington, California and Nevada in the United States of America, it also occurs in Baja California in Mexico and British Columbia in Canada though these occurrences are thought to be introduced (NatureServe 2013, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2014).
Red List use trade: Hordeum depressum is a tertiary genetic relative of Barley (H. vulgare) and so it has the potential for use as a gene donor for crop improvement (von Bothmer et al. 1995).
Red List conservation actions:
The genus Hordeum is listed in Annex I of the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture (ITPGRFA) which aims to guarantee sustainable agriculture and food security through the conservation and sustainable use of plant genetic resources for food and agriculture, as well as ensuring the fair and equitable sharing of the benefits arising out of their use (FAO 2009).

No germplasm accessions of this species are held in the National Plant Germplasm System (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2014), while 22 accessions (11,000 seeds) are duplicated and conserved ex situ in the Svalbard Global Seed Vault, originating from two genebanks (SGSV Data Portal 2013). EURISCO reports 23 germplasm accessions held in European genebanks, none of which are reported to be of wild or weedy origin, and 20 of which have no reported information regarding their origin (EURISCO Catalogue 2013).

The GrainGenes database (USDA, ARS 2014) reports accessions in four germplasm collections, however it is unknown whether these are of wild origin and whether they are unique accessions or duplicated material.

According to Botanical Garden Conservation International (BGCI 2013) this species has a living collection in one botanical garden worldwide, although the size, state, origin and location of the collection are not detailed in this resource (garden locations are undisclosed to protect rare and valuable plant species).

Vincent et al. (2012) report 23 accessions from seven sources thought to contain the largest collections of wild Hordeum seed accessions, identifying this species as a high priority for ex situ conservation within its genus.

This species' native distribution overlaps with at least one protected area, inferred using GeoCAT (Bachman et al. 2011) and so passive conservation is presumed in these area.

NatureServe G RANK REASONS: Limited habitats of vernal pools; dry; saline streambeds; alkaline flats in sw CA and nw Baja CA.

Red List rationale: Hordeum jubatum is listed as Least Concern because it is very widespread and common throughout North America, Canada, Russia and also occurs in China and Mexico and has no major threats. The collection of additional accessions for ex situ conservation that are fully representative of the range of genetic diversity found in situ is recommended.
Red List habitat: Hordeum jubatum grows in meadows, prairies around riverbeds and seasonal lakes, often in saline habitats. It is also found in disturbed habitats such as roadsides and in other rural areas (von Bothmer et al. 1995).
Red List threats: There are no major threats to this species.
Red List population: This species is stable and common throughout its native range. It is also widely naturalized as a weed, expanding its distribution considerably (von Bothmer et al. 1995). Within its natural habitats it forms large stands and can become a noxious weed in pastures.
Red List range: Hordeum jubatum is a widespread species native from north Mexico through the United States of America and Canada to Russia and China (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2014). It occurs at elevations between sea level and 3,000 m a.s.l. (von Bothmer et al. 1995).
Red List use trade: Hordeum jubatum is a tertiary genetic relative of Barley (H. vulgare) and so it has the potential for use as a gene donor for crop improvement (von Bothmer et al. 1995).
Red List conservation actions:
The genus Hordeum is listed in Annex I of the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture (ITPGRFA) which aims to guarantee sustainable agriculture and food security through the conservation and sustainable use of plant genetic resources for food and agriculture, as well as ensuring the fair and equitable sharing of the benefits arising out of their use (FAO 2009).

Vincent et al. (2012) report 118 accessions from seven sources thought to contain the largest collections of wild Hordeum seed accessions, identifying this species as low priority for ex situ conservation within its genus.

No evidence of active in situ conservation was found for this species, however, predicted species distribution overlaps with numerous protected areas across the species range, especially in northern America, inferred using GeoCAT (Bachman et al. 2011) and so passive conservation is presumed.

Red List rationale: Hordeum pusillum is globally assessed as Least Concern as it is common throughout its distribution, populations are stable and there are no known threats. It is not yet well-represented in genebanks and so additional collection of germplasm for ex situ conservation is recommended.
Red List habitat: Hordeum pusillum grows in open grasslands, pastures and on the borders of marshes. It also grows in disturbed places such as roadsides and waste places and often in alkaline soil (von Bothmer et al. 2012).
Red List threats: There are no known threats to this species.
Red List population: This species is common throughout its range, although less so in northeastern USA, and there are also few records from Mexico and Canada (von Bothmer et al. 1995). Its global population is suspected to be stable.
Red List range: Hordeum pusillum is native and widespread throughout the United States of America, also occurring in Alberta in Canada and Baja California in Mexico (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2014). It grows at altitudes up to 1,500 m a.s.l. (von Bothmer et al. 1995).
Red List use trade: Hordeum pusillum is a tertiary genetic relative of Barley (H. vulgare) and so it has the potential for use as a gene donor for crop improvement (von Bothmer et al. 1995).
Red List conservation actions:
The genus Hordeum is listed in Annex I of the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture (ITPGRFA) which aims to guarantee sustainable agriculture and food security through the conservation and sustainable use of plant genetic resources for food and agriculture, as well as ensuring the fair and equitable sharing of the benefits arising out of their use (FAO 2009).

Vincent et al. (2012) report 35 accessions from seven sources thought to contain the largest collections of wild Hordeum seed accessions, identifying this species as a high priority for ex situ conservation within its genus.

No evidence of active in situ conservation was found for this species, however, predicted species distribution overlaps with numerous protected areas across the species' range, inferred using GeoCAT (Bachman et al. 2011) and so passive conservation is presumed.

Red List rationale: This tree species has a very wide distribution, large population, is not currently experiencing any major threats and no significant future threats have been identified. This species is therefore assessed as Least Concern.
Red List habitat: Rare as a tree, 3â5 m tall, more frequently found as a shrub, 2â 4 m tall. This species occurs in cloud forest (in Mexico) but is also found in pine-oak forest or swamp vegetation (in the United States).
Red List threats: There are no major threats to the species.
Red List population: There is no information on the population size and structure.
Red List use trade: There is no known use or trade for this species.
Red List conservation actions: This species has been assessed as Least Concern in The Red List of Mexican Cloud Forest Trees (GonzÃ¡lez-Espinosa et al. 2011).

NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: AL(SNR); AR(SNR); FL(SNR); GA(SNR); LA(SNR); MS(SNR); NC(S2); SC(SNR); TX(SNR)
Red List rationale: This species has a disjunct distribution in both north and south America. It has, therefore an extremely large geographic range and it occupies a fairly large area within that range such that its area of occupancy (AOO = 2,772 km<sup>2</sup>) exceeds the threshold for threatened species. In addition, it is not known to face any specific threats, and it is presumed to have a large population. It is therefore globally assessed as Least Concern.
Red List habitat: It is a weedy annual forb/herb and vine (Encyclopedia of Life 2018, J.R.I. Wood pers. comm. 2018a) which is found in disturbed sites, waste ground, roadsides and railroads (Tenaglia 2007). It does benefit from disturbance as it is usually found near settlements and houses (J.R.I. Wood pers. comm. 2018b).
Red List threats: It is not threatened and, as a weedy plant, it benefits from disturbance and forest clearance (J.R.I. Wood pers. comm. 2018).
Red List population: It is locally abundant in South America in Argentina, Bolivia and Paraguay, but very rare in Brazil (J.R.I. Wood pers. comm. 2018).
Red List range: Ipomoea cordatotriloba consists of two distinct populations (see Munoz et al. 2018). In North America it is restricted to the southern states of the USA (Alabama, Arkansas, Florida, Georgia, Mississippi, North Carolina, South Carolina, Texas and New Mexico) (J.R.I. Wood pers. comm 2018a). It is also present in northern Mexico (Chihuahua) (J.R.I. Wood pers. comm 2018a). USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System (2018) also includes the state of Louisiana in USA and Tamaulipas in Mexico. In south America it is locally abundant in the lowlands of eastern Bolivia, northern Argentina and Paraguay but is very rare in Brazil (Mato Grosso do Sul) (J.R.I. Wood pers. comm. 2018a). USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System (2018) refers this species to occur in Gran Chaco in Bolivia and in the regions of Buenos Aires, Catamarca, Chaco, Corrientes, Formosa, Jujuy, Salta, Santiago del Estero and Tucuman in Argentina. It grows up to c. 1,000 m (J.R.I. Wood pers. comm. 2018a). It is also reported to be naturalized in Colombia, Cuba, Jamaica, north-west Mexico, and other parts of Central America (USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2018), however there is no good evidence of the species in these areas so it is likely these subpopulations have been misidentified (J.R.I. Wood pers. comm. 2018b) and these areas will therefore not be included in this assessment. Extent of occurrence (EOO) is around 16,000,000 km2 and area of occupancy (AOO) is 2,772 km2. It is likely to be increasing its range (J.R.I. Wood pers. comm. 2018a).
Red List use trade: It is a tertiary genetic wild relative of, and potential gene donor to Sweet Potato (USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2018). It can be potentially used to confer tolerance to cold and sandy soil (Khoury et al. 2015).
Red List conservation actions:
The genus Ipomoea is listed in Annex I of the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture as part of the Sweet Potato gene pool (FAO 2009).

Genesys reports 106 accessions, 104 of which are of wild origin. All but one of these accessions are known to originate from within the native distribution. Of the accessions of wild origin, 82 are backed up at a second genebank, but none are duplicated and conserved in the Svalbard Seed Vault (Genesys Global Portal on Plant Genetic Resources 2018).

According to Botanic Gardens Conservation International (BGCI 2018), this species has living collections in six botanic gardens worldwide, as well as one for I. cordatotriloba var. cordatotriloba, which is considered a synonym in this assessment. Therefore, in total the species has living collections in seven botanic gardens worldwide, although the origin and locality of the collections are not detailed in this resource (garden locations are undisclosed to protect rare and valuable plant species).

It was assessed at the global scale as Not Threatened (G5) in 1993 and I. cordatotriloba var. cordatotriloba was assessed as Not Threatened (T5) in 1986 (NatureServe 2018). Another source also lists the species as Least Concern at the global scale (Board of Trustees, RBG Kew 2018).

Research is recommended into the population and threats to this species. Population and habitat should be monitored to ensure they are not declining. Khoury et al. (2015) identified that this species is poorly represented in genebank collections and needs to be collected for ex situ conservation, namely from Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Mexico, Paraguay and USA.

AL(SNR); AR(SNR); DC(SNR); DE(S4); FL(SNR); GA(SNR); IA(S1); IL(SNR); IN(SNR); KS(SNR); KY(S5); LA(SNR); MA(SNR); MD(SNR); MO(SNR); MS(SNR); NC(S4); NJ(SNA); NY(SNA); OH(SNR); OK(SNR); PA(S4); SC(SNR); TN(SNR); TX(SNR); VA(S5); WV(S2)
Red List rationale: This species has an extensive geographic range in south-eastern USA, is presumed to have a widespread population and is not facing any specific threats. Although it has an area of occupancy (AOO) of 820 km<sup>2</sup>, which would qualify it as Vulnerable, it is not severely fragmented or undergoing continuous decline or extreme fluctuations. It is therefore globally assessed as Least Concern.
Red List habitat: It is a weedy and annual species of disturbed roadsides, field borders and similar habitats (J.R.I. Wood pers. comm. 2018). Encyclopedia of Life (2018) refers this species occurring in black soil prairies, thickets, streams and banks of lakes, moist meadows near rivers or woodlands, abandoned fields, areas along roads and railroads and waste areas.
Red List threats: This species is not threatened and as a weedy species, it probably benefits from disturbance and forest clearance (J.R.I. Wood pers. comm. 2018).
Red List population: This species appears to be common (J.R.I. Wood pers. comm. 2018).
Red List range:
Ipomoea lacunosa is widespread and endemic to south-eastern USA, but widely naturalized elsewhere due to its weedy nature, including south America, the Caribbean and Asia (Board of Trustees, RBG Kew 2018, USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2018). Furthermore, it is reported as an adventive in Europe (J.R.I. Wood pers. comm. 2018).

In particular it is recorded in Alabama, Florida, Georgia, Louisiana, Mississippi, North Carolina, South Carolina and Tennessee (USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2018). It is also known to be native to Arkansas, Delaware, District of Columbia, Illinois, Indiana, Kentucky, Maryland, Missouri, Ohio, Oklahoma, Texas, Virginia and West Virginia. Elsewhere its native distribution is also reported to include Kansas and Pennsylvania (Board of Trustees, RBG Kew 2018), but the origin of these subpopulations is not clear and therefore these states will not be included in the assessment of this species. It is found at elevations of around 150 m.

Extent of occurrence (EOO) is around 2,500,000 km2 and area of occupancy (AOO) is 820 km2. It is likely to be increasing its range (J.R.I. Wood pers. comm. 2018).
Red List use trade: It is a tertiary genetic wild relative of, and potential gene donor to Sweet Potato (Vincent et al. 2013, USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2018). It has been used to increase fertility of its related crop (Austin 1978) and could potentially be used in the future to increase its tolerance to cold and drought (Khoury et al. 2015). In addition, it has traditionally been consumed by several native American tribes (Encyclopedia of Life 2018).
Red List conservation actions:
The genus Ipomoea is listed in Annex I of the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture as part of the Sweet Potato gene pool (FAO 2009).

Genesys reports 13 accessions, five of which are of wild origin and are from within the native distribution, in the USA. One of these accessions is backed up at a second genebank, but none are duplicated and conserved in the Svalbard Seed Vault (Genesys Global Portal on Plant Genetic Resources 2018). Khoury et al. (2015) identified that this species is poorly represented in genebank collections and needs to be collected for ex situ conservation. According to Botanic Gardens Conservation International (BGCI 2018), this species has living collections in three botanic gardens worldwide, although the origin and locality of the collections are not detailed in this resource (garden locations are undisclosed to protect rare and valuable plant species).

It has previously been globally assessed as Not Threatened - G5 - in 1988 (NatureServe 2018).
