Red List rationale: This species has an extremely widespread distribution in the islands of the Indian and Pacific oceans, stretching from Madagascar to French Polynesia. Although it has an area of occupancy (AOO) of 480 km<sup>2</sup>, which would qualify as Endangered, it has a stable population and is not known to be facing any specific threats. It is therefore globally assessed as Least Concern.
Red List habitat: It is a seashore plant also sometimes found inland near the sea (J.R.I. Wood pers. comm. 2018). It is found on sandy seashores, in coastal thickets and on forest floors (Encyclopedia of Life 2018).
Red List threats: There are no obvious threats to this species (J.R.I. Wood pers. comm. 2018).
Red List population: There is no evidence that the population is increasing or decreasing so it is assumed to be stable (J.R.I. Wood pers. comm. 2018).
Red List range: It is widely distributed on islands in the Pacific and Indian Oceans (not on Socotra) but is absent from continental Africa and America (J.R.I. Wood pers. comm. 2018). In Asia it is known from Bangladesh and South East Asia but mostly on islands (Java, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Philippines, New Guinea, NE Australia) (J.R.I. Wood pers. comm. 2018). Extent of occurrence (EOO) is around 90,000,000 km2 and area of occupancy (AOO) is 480 km2. It occurs at elevations of up to 100 m asl (Encyclopedia of Life 2018).
Red List use trade: It is a secondary genetic relative, a possible progenitor of, and a potential gene donor to, Sweet Potato (Vincent et al. 2013, USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2018). It has been used to provide genes to this crop which increase its yield and resistance to Black Rot (Iwanaga 1988). In addition, it has potential to increase the sweet potato tolerance to drought, heat, sandy soil, waterlogging, and its resistance to Scab and Weevil (Khoury et al. 2015). In Micronesia, the species is eaten as a vegetable (USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2018).
Red List conservation actions:
The genus Ipomoea is listed in Annex I of the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture as part of the sweet potato gene pool (FAO 2009).

Genesys reports 10 germplasm accessions, only one of which is of wild origin. This accession of wild origin is from within the native distribution, in Australia, but is not backed up at a second genebank, nor is it duplicated and conserved in the Svalbard Seed Vault (Genesys Global Portal on Plant Genetic Resources 2018). Khoury et al. (2015) identified that this species is poorly represented in genebank collections and needs to be collected for ex situ conservation, namely in: Australia, Fiji, French Polynesia, Guam, India, Indonesia, Kiribati, Madagascar, Malaysia, Mauritius, Micronesia, N. Mariana Islands, New Caledonia, Papua New Guinea, Philippines, Seychelles, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand, Timor-Leste and USA.

According to Botanic Gardens Conservation International (BGCI 2018), this species has living collections in three botanic gardens worldwide, although the origin and locality of the collections are not detailed in this resource (garden locations are undisclosed to protect rare and valuable plant species).

It has been assessed as Vulnerable in the Seychelles (Gerlach 1997), as Near Threatened in Sri Lanka (MOE 2012) and as Least Concern in China (Chinese Ministry of Environmental Protection 2013). In addition, it has been assessed as possibly threatened (rare) in Singapore (Ng and Wee 1994), and as Critically Endangered in La RÃ©union (UICN France et al. 2010), but these countries are considered to be outside the native distribution of the species.

NatureServe G RANK REASONS: The name I. longifolia is accepted in Kearney & Peebles (1951) and Shreve and Wiggins (1964). The plants from OK and TX may be of hybrid origin.

NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: FL(S1)
Red List rationale: Ipomoea tenuissima is found in Florida in the USA, and the Caribbean. It therefore has a fairly large global range but does not occupy a large area within this range, which means it has an area of occupancy (AOO) of 44 km2, which qualifies it as Endangered. Although additional non georeferenced occurrence data from Hispaniola which were not included in the calculation, and there are likely to be additional records from Mona Island, Puerto Rico, it is unlikely that these would increase AOO over the Endangered threshold of 500 km2. In addition, it is likely to be severely fragmented, and is undergoing continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat as a result of continued development and fire suppression. Furthermore, it is known to be rare throughout much of its range. It is therefore globally assessed as Endangered, meeting criteria B2ab(iii).
Red List habitat: Originally, the species was often found in pine rocklands in Florida. However, as a result of continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat, it is now often found in disturbed areas (Encyclopedia of Life 2018). It also occurs in low dry forests and plains âsabanasâ (J.R.I Wood pers. comm. 2018).
Red List threats: Continuing development and fire suppression are resulting in habitat decline for this species (Encyclopedia of Life 2018). It is unlikely to face any threats in its main area of occurrence (Cuba) (J.R.I. Wood pers. comm. 2018).
Red List population: The species is very rare in south Florida (Gann et al. 2018) with only four known occurrences (NatureServe 2018). In Mona Island it is known from a single collection. In Hispaniola it is described by Liogier (1994) as âbastante frecuenteâ (very frequent) but J.R.I. Wood (pers. comm. 2018) thinks that it is likely to be rare as there are few specimens known. It is common throughout Cuba and there are 15 known collections from different parts of the island (J.R.I. Wood pers. comm. 2018). Populations are thought to be stable (J.R.I. Wood pers. comm. 2018). It is likely to be severely fragmented, with very little, if any, dispersal between Florida and Cuba subpopulations.
Red List range: Ipomoea tenuissima is native to Florida in south-eastern USA, as well as Cuba, Hispaniola (both Haiti and the Dominican Republic sides) and Mona Island (Puerto Rico) in the Caribbean (J.R.I. Wood pers. comm. 2018, USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2018). Extent of occurrence (EOO) is 210,765 km2 and area of occupancy (AOO) is 44 km2. In addition to the data points included in this calculation, it is known from five localities in Hispaniola (The New York Botanical Garden 2018), but these points do not have coordinates and therefore cannot be used in the calculation of EOO and AOO. Further, occurrence data from Mona island is also missing.
Red List use trade: It is a tertiary genetic wild relative (and probable progenitor) of, and potential gene donor to Sweet Potato (Vincent et al. 2013, USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2018). It could potentially be used to confer increased tolerance to heat, cold and sandy soil (Khoury et al. 2015).
Red List conservation actions:
The genus Ipomoea is listed in Annex I of the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture as part of the Sweet Potato gene pool (FAO 2009).

Genesys reports only one germplasm accession of wild origin, which originates from USA, within the native distribution of this species. This accession is backed up at a second genebank, but is not duplicated and conserved in the Svalbard Seed Vault (Genesys Global Portal on Plant Genetic Resources 2018). Khoury et al. (2015) identified that this species is poorly represented in genebank collections and needs to be collected for ex situ conservation, namely throughout its entire native range (Cuba, Dominican Republic, Haiti, Puerto Rico and USA). In addition, this species has living collections in one botanic garden worldwide, although the origin and locality of the collections are not detailed in this resource (garden locations are undisclosed to protect rare and valuable plant species) (BGCI 2018). It is reportedly present in 26 conservation areas in Florida (Gann et al. 2018).

This species has been globally assessed as Vulnerable in the 1997 Red List of Threatened Plants (IUCN 1997) and as Vulnerable (G3) in 2001 (NatureServe 2001).

NatureServe G RANK REASONS: Juglans californica is endemic to California and occurs in Los Angeles; Orange; Riverside; Santa Barbara; San Bernardino; San Diego and Ventura counties (CNPS 2001). While the California Native Plant Society considers Juglans californica rare; it is curre
NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: CA(S3)
Red List rationale: This shrub or small tree is endemic to California in the United States of America. The species is found in the south of the state, where it is present in seven counties. The extent of occurrence of the species is 28,850 km<sup>2 </sup>and area of occupancy is estimated to be around 2,000 km<sup>2</sup>. The population size is unknown and the species can be dominant in woodland. Despite this there is continuing decline in population size due to threats from habitat loss and conversion, grazing of the habitat and increased occurrence of fire. There are also concerns for the future regeneration of the species and potential habitat availability due to a local growing human population which could put pressure on the species and its habitat. The species is assessed as Near Threatened as it almost reaches the criteria for Vulnerable B2ab(iii) but is found in more than ten locations. More information on the current status of population size would be valuable.
Red List habitat:
Southern California walnut is a shrub or small tree, growing to 6 - 15 m in height (Stone 1997). The species can form woodland where it may be monospecific or mixed, often occurring alongside Quercus agrifolia. The species is sometimes found in small stands in chaparral and coastal shrub. Trees generally occur on mesic sites such as north slopes, creekbeds, canyon bottoms, and alluvial terraces (Esser 1993). They grow best in deep, alluvial soils with high water-holding capacity. Walnut woodland generates important habitat for vertebrates and invertebrates especially birds. The species can resprout after fire.

This habitat type is currently in decline due to urbanisation and local grazing of the woodland.
Red List threats: There are many threats to Juglans californica. Urbanisation, including the development of expressways and golf courses, leads to the clearance of large stands of the tree. These threats coupled with human population growth (could increase by roughly 50%) are the major future threats to the species (J. Keeley pers. comm. 2018). This could have a dramatic affect on the habitat available for the species in the future. Cattle grazing is another threat to the species reducing the regeneration potential for the species as young seedlings are consumed. These threats have led to Walnut woodland becoming fragmented and small (NatureServe 2018). There is also threat from more fire and competition with introduced invasive species. The species may also be at risk from climate change (Potter et al. 2017). The species may become threatened by the fungal pathogen that causes Thousand Cankers Disease in J. nigra but currently J. californica shows resistance. Another risk is from hybridization with J. hindsii which has been introduced to J. californica range (Potter et al. 2018).
Red List population:
The species is most common in Los Angeles, Orange and Ventura counties. Small stands are found in the Simi Hills, Santa Susana Mountains, Santa Monica Mountains, San Jose Hills, Puente Hills and Chino Hills (Esser 1993). 3,500 living individuals were recorded from Sulphur Mount, Ventura County, California making up 49% of the basal area (Keeley 1990). In the same study, 1,130 living individuals were found on Mount Washington, LA County contributing to 90% of the basal area (Keeley 1990). Finally, at Montecito heights, LA County 1,710 living individuals were counted with a basal cover of 95% (Keeley 1990). At each of these three sites, there were also 50 to 100 dead individuals of the species (Keeley 1990).  Keeley (1990), also looked at the size structure of the species and most individuals had a small dbh. Based on estimates from these three sites, population size is suspected to exceed 10,000 mature individuals. Nature Serve (2018) describes the population size as 'sufficient' and widespread. It can also be dominant in woodlands (Esser 1993). A lack of natural reproduction is also reported (NatureServe 2018). Subpopulations are found in protected areas and due to the species dominance in woodland, these can be large and stable subpopulations. 

Riordan et al. (2015), looked at the possible behavior of this species and its' preferred habitat type in response to climate change. A potential 20,493 km2 of climatically suitable habitat was identified for the species, 31% of this habitat has already been subject to decline due to anthropogenic development of urban areas and agriculture and before 2080 a further 33% could be lost. Climate change also has the potential to cause 48 - 61% of currently suitable habitat to be lost, which alongside anthropogenic changes could see J. californica experience habitat loss of between 64 and 70% (worst case scenario). However, climate change may not have a negative impact and could see the range of the species expand along the coast by 218% (Riordan et al. 2015). More information is needed on how the species will disperse, and reproduce alongside fine scale habitat and ecological information (soil moisture etc.) is needed before these models can better predict what will happen to the population size of the species in response to climate change.

Considering these details, overall the population is experiencing decline due to loss of habitat and grazing of the natural habitat. Californian Walnut forests are also becoming more fragmented. There has been great historical decline due to human population growth in the state and this growth is predicted to continue if not increase into the future. This will have a major impact on the population of J. californica oustide of protected areas, as available habitat may be significantly reduced. However in the protected sites large stable subpopulations will persist.
Red List range: This species is endemic to California, USA. Following NatureServe (2018), the species is only present in the counties of Santa Barbara, Ventura, Los Angeles, San Bernardino, Orange, Riverside and San Diego. There are records of the species as far north as the Santa Clara County but these specimens are likely to have been misidentified or are from planted trees.  The extent of occurrence of the species is 28,850 km<sup>2</sup>. Based on the current herbarium record of the species area of occupancy is 1,200 km<sup>2</sup> but may be larger (up to 2,000 km<sup>2</sup>).
Red List use trade: Southern California black walnuts are consumable by people, but the species is not commercially grown for this purpose. The tree is grown for ornamental landscaping in urban forestry projects and some rehabilitation sites. Southern California black walnut woodland is grazed by livestock (Esser 1993).
Red List conservation actions:
This species is found in at least 19 ex situ collections (BGCI 2018). The range includes protected areas of Los Padres National Forest, Chino Hills and Cuyamaca Rancho State Park. There may be some more targeted, local conservation of the species but details are not available. The species has been recently reassessed at the state and global level as G4- apparently Secure (CNPS 2018). In the wake of climate change, protected areas should be adaptable and expanded to take in sites that species may move into following a change in climate (Riordan et al. 2015).

Population numbers for this species would be valuable and monitoring of changes in size to further quantify the rate of population decline.

NatureServe CANADIAN PROVINCES AND S RAN: MB(SNA); NB(S1); NS(SNA); ON(S2?); PE(SNA); QC(S3)
Red List rationale: This species is native the United States of America and Canada. The species is not abundant across this wide range and the population is also in rapid decline. This is caused by the invasion of the non-native, fungal pest Ophiognomonia clavigignenti-juglandacearum which upon infection can kill trees. The infection can spread quickly and already the pest is found across the species range. There is limited natural resistance to this fungus which was introduced in 1967. Since this time reports of decline from different states varies from 27% to 91%. Due to this variation it is predicted that historical population decline has been up to 80%. This figure is also given to decline across a three generation shifting window and to a suspected decline, over the next 100 years. Efforts are being made to better understand ways to protect butternut from the pest. The species is currently globally assessed as Endangered.
Red List habitat: This large tree species can grow up to 30 m in height (NatureServe 2018). The species occupies riparian sites, occurring in bottomlands and floodplains and along ravines, terraces, creeks and streams in mesophytic forest (Burns & Honkala 1990). The species can produce seed from around 20 years of age, and lives around 75 years (Michler et al. 2006). The species is often associated with Acer saccharum, Tilia americana, Lirodendron tulipifera, Quercus rubra, Fagus spp. and many more hardwood types (Burns & Honkala 1990). The species is not abundant in its habitat, with individual butternut trees being found in mixed stands. It is a shade intolerant tree, and can reach the canopy (Burns & Honkala 1990, Coladonato 1991).
Red List threats:
The greatest threat to the species is decline due to butternut canker, caused by the pathogen Ophiognomonia clavigignenti-juglandacearum (Borders et al. 2015). This pest can infect trees of all age and size classes (McIlwrick et al. 2000). It can infect rapidly and invade just as quickly, hence only a few uninfected stands remain (NatureServe 2018). The pest is thought to be waterbourne but may also be dispersed by insects (Borders et al. 2015). Infection results in the premature death of the tree as the tree becomes girdled and the cambium is destroyed. During this time the tree can also become more susceptible to other pests and diseases which reduces the viability of the tree further (NatureServe 2018). The pest was thought to be introduced at the end of the 1960's and has since caused the global population of butternut to decline. Currently methods of mitigation are not fully understood. The population now exists in smaller numbers, than across the last century.

Parks et al. 2013 also notes that the species is threatened by historical habitat loss, poor regeneration and genetic dilution caused by hybridisation with Juglans ailantifolia. Potter et al. 2017 also identified that the species may be 'vulnerable' to climate change but with some capacity to adapt.
Red List population:
The species is 'scattered' or 'sporadic' in its habitats but may occasionally form small pure groups (Broders et al. 2015).  Small isolated pockets are found in the south of the range, and subpopulations in Wisconsin, Michingan, Ontario and Quebec are considered disjunct (Coladonato 1991). The species is rarely dominant, but in some sites is co-dominant with an overall low abundance (Michler et al. 2006).

Population is subject to a high rate of decline. This is a consequence of infection of trees by the fungus Ophiognomonia clavigignenti-juglandacearum, commonly known as butternut canker (Broders et al. 2015, NatureServe 2018). This fungal pest was first reported in 1967 and the population of butternut has continued to decline since its invasion. In some states up to 91% of trees can be infected, putting them at risk of death (McIlwrick et al. 2000). Seven midwestern states recorded a decline in butternut trees of 23% (Michler et al. 2006) while Wisconsin recorded a loss of between 27 and 92% by 1992 (Michler et al. 2006). Flickinger (2015) reports a decrease in number of butternut trees from 1.4 million individuals to 84,000 individuals, a 94% decline. In general, the average loss across reporting states is around 80% (McIlwrick et al. 2000). The species is also subject to decline in its Canadian range at a similar rate.

Despite this decline the species is still present in habitat as infected individuals, uninfected saplings, mature putative resistant trees (McIlwrick et al. 2000). The species currently maintains good genetic diversity and there is some natural resistance to O. clavigignenti-juglandacearum (Ross-Davis et al. 2008). Other causes of population decline are due to habitat loss, poor regeneration and genetic dilution (Parks et al. 2013).

The species produces seed from 20 to 60 years old, hence generation length is given as 40 years. Therefore, across three generations looking from 1967 to 2067 it is estimated that the population will experience decline between 50 and 80%. There has been a historical reduction of up to 80% based on the loss of trees due to butternut canker, and the variable rate this has occurred across the range. There is a high rate of infection and high rate of mortality of the tree. Decline will continue into the future as O. clavigignenti-juglandacearum is present across the entire species range and there is no known remedy (Parks et al. 2013). Decline over the next 100 years could also be as much as 80%, considering a conservative estimate.
Red List range: This species is native to North America where it is present in much of eastern Canada and eastern United States. Here it occurs from new Brunswick, south to Georgia and Alabama, across to Missouri and north to Wisconsin. It is present in 29 US states (NatureServe 2018). The species occurs at low elevations up to 4,900 ft.
Red List use trade: Butternut is a valued lumber and timber species (NatureServe 2018). The wood can be used to make cabinets, furniture and novelties (Burns & Honkala 1990). The nut of the tree can also be harvested and eaten by humans. The bark, roots and husks can be utilised for medicinal purposes (Ross-Davis et al. 2008).
Red List conservation actions:
The species is assessed as Endangered for Canada (COSEWIC 2008). US NatureServe tracks that the species is at risk in many states, but at the national level is assessed as G4 ('Apparently secure'), as the species 'is not currently vulnerable to extinction' as large numbers still persist across the species range. The species is present on the US Endangered Species Act (McIlwrick et al. 2000). There was also a moratorium placed on the trade of this species from Minnesota (McIlwrick et al. 2000) and in general, the harvest of this species for timber is now more restricted to ensure that healthy, uninfected individuals persist in the wild. 

There is currently no effective or practical management techniques known that completely protect Juglans cinerea from butternut canker. Various research is occurring to investigate remedies to butternut canker infection. This includes looking at in vitro propagation, breeding resistance, use of fungicides and pesticides, reducing timber harvest and developing ex situ conservation stands, DNA and seed banks (McIlwrick et al. 2000, NatureServe 2018). Remaining stands of the tree need to be managed to encourage regeneration, such as reducing canopy to better establishment of butternut (Parks et al. 2013). There needs to be continuing monitoring of the population for decline and regeneration. The species is present in at least 137 ex situ collections.

NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: AZ(S4); NM(SNR); TX(SNR); UT(SNR)
Red List rationale: This species is native to the south-west of the United States into Mexico. The species has a large native range and population is assumed to be large as in the US it can be dominant in some habitats and can form pure stands. Information for Mexico is not widely available but the species was reported as threatened from the country in 2010. In the US, the species is considered stable and is rarely used for timber. The species is globally assessed as Least Concern.
Red List habitat: This tree species can grow up to 20 m in height (Pavek 1993). The species occurs in the riparian areas of deserts, where there is ephemeral streams and occasional flooding. The species is generally scattered in its habitats although it can also form pure stands. It may also be dominant or codominant in broadleaved woodland and can also grow in oak and conifer woodland. It can be present at all stages of succession and flowers in spring. Reproduction is sexual (Pavek 1993).
Red List threats: In the future the species may become affected by climate change. A study by Potter et al. (2017) identified the species to have 'high vulnerability and potential adaptation' in response to climate change. Further information is needed to fully understand this risk to the species. Otherwise, in the US, the species is not considered threatened. For Mexico, threats to the species are unknown.
Red List population: This species can form pure stands and can be dominant or co-dominant in certain habitats (Pavek 1993). It is also widespread, hence it is assumed that the population is large. The population is reported to be stable by Nature Serve (2018) in the United States. Information is not available for population in Mexico.
Red List range: This species is native to Mexico and the United States of America. It has a wide distribution in Mexico (VillaseÃ±or 2016) where it occurs in the North west, along the west coast states to Guerro and Oaxaca. The species is not native east of this range in Mexico, specimens from these sites are likely to be misidentifications. In the US the species range extends from Central Texas west into New Mexico and Central Arizona, it is also reported from Utah (Pavek 1993, NatureServe 2018). This species has an extent of occurrence of over 1.9 million km<sup>2</sup>.
Red List use trade: This species is used for timber but this is not a major use due to the limited distribution. When harvested it is used for furniture gunstocks, veneer and fence posts (Pavek 1993). The tree can also be browsed by cattle and the walnut is eaten by humans.
Red List conservation actions: This species is reported from 28 ex situ collections (BGCI 2018). The species has most recently been considered Threatened in Mexico (SEMARNAT 2010) but in 2005, a separate assessment for Mexico found the species not threatened (BGCI ThreatSearch 2018). For the US it is assessed as G4 - Apparently Secure (Nature Serve 2018).

NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: KS(S2); NM(SNR); OK(SNR); TX(SNR)
Red List rationale: This species is native to the US and Mexico. The species has a wide native range, far exceeding the boundaries for a threatened category under criterion B. In this range, the species occurs in narrow habitats where it is common. No major threats to the species are reported and it is rarely used for timber. The species is globally assessed as Least Concern.
Red List habitat: This shrub or tree can grow to between six and fifteen meters in height (Tirmenstein 1990). It is abundant in riparian woodland communities. This includes in stream bottoms, canyons, river beds and edges and arroyos of the Chihuahuan Desert (Tiremenstein 1990). Most habitats the species occupies are narrow in area and dry. The species mostly reproduces through seed and flowering occurs in spring. This is a valuable food source for small mammals in its habitat (Wynia 2008).
Red List threats: This species is not reported as threatened.
Red List population: In the US the population of this species is considered stable (NatureServe 2018) and large. Information on population in Mexico is not available, but is well represented in the herbarium record (GBIF 2018). It is assumed that population is stable.
Red List range:
This species is native to Kansas, New Mexico, Oklahoma and Texas (Wynia 2008) in the United States and Chihuahua, Coahuila, Nuevo Leon in Mexico (VillaseÃ±or 2016).
The species has an extent of occurrence of over 800,000 km2.
Red List use trade: This species can be used for timber. This can be utilised to produce furniture, cabinets, paneling and veneer, however, its use is rare as the tree is not common. There is potential for the species to be planted and used in the face of climate change as it is tolerant of dry conditions (Wynia 2008).
Red List conservation actions: This species is present in at least 57 ex situ collections (BGCI 2018). In the US the species is assessed as G5 - Secure (NatureServe 2018).

Red List rationale: This species is here assessed as Least Concern because of its large, stable population and the extensive range over which the species is found.
Red List habitat: Black Walnut is a large tree (up to 38 m tall). It grows slowly on wet bottomlands, dry ridges, and slopes and has preference for rich deep, moist soils. It grows extremely well on deep loams and fertile alluvial deposits. The species is a key component of major United States forest types and is commonly associated with other United States hardwood species such as American Elm (Ulmus americana), Hackberry (Celtis laevigata), Green Ash (Fraxinus pennsylvanica), Box Elder (Acer negundo), and Butternut (Juglans cinerea). It can be scattered within forests or form pure stands (Coladonato 1991).
Red List threats: European canker and walnut caterpillar are pests that attack Black Walnut (USDA, NRCS 2018). These are not considered major threats to the species.
Red List population: The known population is stable. Black Walnut is a common associate in five forest cover types within North America, suggesting the species is abundant and has a large population (Coladonato 1991).
Red List range: Black Walnut (Juglans nigra) is found throughout eastern North America. It grows as far north as southern Minnesota, southern Wisconsin, southern Michigan, and Maine in the US and Ontario in Canada. Its range then extends south to northwestern Florida, and to Texas and New Mexico. Within this distribution the species does not occur in the Mississippi Valley and Delta regions. Some isolated populations are found within the eastern parts of the species range and in in the Midwest (Coladonato 1991).
Red List use trade:
Black Walnut wood is heavy, strong and ranks with the most durable United States hardwoods. Its principal uses are for dining room and bedroom furniture and as an interior finish in cafes and public buildings. It is also prized for expensive shotguns and sporting rifles.

The tree nuts are commercially harvested and are eaten plain or with honey and used to flavour cakes, candy and ice cream. Dye can also be extracted from the roots and the tree can be planted as an ornamental. The shells may also be used in the automobile industry as a non-slip agent for tires and to protect gears and jet engines (Coladonato 1991).
Red List conservation actions: Juglans nigra is ranked as G5 - secure by NatureServe (NatureServe 2018) due to its extensive range and large, stable population. There is currently no conservation actions in place in the states where it is native. This species is found in 205 ex situ collections (BGCI 2018).

NatureServe G RANK REASONS: Widespread patchy distribution in North America; with thousands of occurrences.

Red List rationale: Malus fusca is globally assessed as Least Concern as it is known to be abundant and secure in British Colombia and California with reproducing populations reported from a number of protected areas across its native range (Information Center for the Environment (ICE) 2013). Ex situ accessions are stored in the NPGS (USDA, National Germplasm Resource Program 2013), however research should be undertaken to determine whether existing accessions are representative of the species' geographic and genetic diversity and collecting should take place to fill any gaps in its ex situ conservation.
Red List habitat: This shade intolerant, broadleaved tree species can vary in height from 3â12 m tall; it occurs in cool mesothermal climates on nitrogen rich soils in moist to wet habitats (Klinkenberg 2013, Giblin 2014). It is found scattered in open canopy forests, and on water collecting sites such as streambanks, upper breaches, shoreline thickets, estuary fringes, swamps and open canyons from 0 to 1,420 m asl (at an average elevation of 121 m asl, with occurrence decreasing with increasing elevation) (Klinkenberg 2013, Giblin 2014). It is documented to be common in sites with ocean spray, such as on coastal islands and adjacent mainland, and is characteristic of nutrient-rich wetlands (Klinkenberg 2013). In Alaska this species occurs in calcareous Karst fens which are documented to be rare due to the limited presence of limestone geology (Alaska Natural Heritage Program 2014).
Red List threats: There are no current known threats to this species (Devine et al. 2012), however Karst fen habitat in southern Alaska has been designated of conservation concern and so it should be determined whether this species is directly or indirectly affected by the threats facing this habitat (Alaska Natural Heritage Program 2014). Threats to Karst fens in this region include: increased runoff from intensive timber harvest, surface disturbance, conversion of land to grazing, agriculture, invasive species (increased by close proximity to roads) and activities that influence water chemistry or hydrology (Alaska Natural Heritage Program 2014). Climate change is also suspected to have an impact on this species' habitat but more research is required to validate this.
Red List population: The Burke Museum of Natural History and Culture states that this species is abundant and of no conservation concern (Giblin 2014). It has also been assessed as 'Yellow' (apparently secure and not at risk of extinction) in the Canadian Province of British Columbia (B.C. Conservation Data Centre 2014). Further research is needed to ascertain population information across the rest of this species native range, but its global population trend is thought to be stable.
Red List range: The species is native to the United States of America (the states of Alaska, Oregon, Washington and California) and British Colombia in Canada (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013) and occurs between 0 and 1,420 m asl (Klinkenberg 2013, Giblin 2014).
Red List use trade:
This species is a tertiary genetic relative and graft stock relative of the cultivated Apple Malus domestica and so has potential for use as a gene donor for crop improvement (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013). 

This species is also planted for wildlife and restorative purposes as it tolerates wet and saline soils better than many other species (Devine et al. 2012).
Red List conservation actions:
The Biological Inventories of the World's Protected Areas (Information Center for the Environment (ICE) 2013) reports this species as present in protected areas in California (California Coast Ranges Biosphere Reserve, Redwood National Park), Alaska (Glacier Bay National Park and Preserve, Glacier BayâAdmiralty Island Biosphere Reserve), Washington (Mount Rainer National Park, Olympic Biosphere Reserve) and British Colombia (reproducing population present in Gwaii Haanas National Park Reserve and Pacific Rim National Park Reserve; reproducing population present in Mount Arrowsmith Regional Park where it is also noted to be uncommon). Passive conservation is presumed in these protected areas, however it is unknown whether active population management and monitoring occurs for this species. 

Fifty germplasm accessions are available from the National Plant Germplasm System (NPGS), only six of which are of wild origin and backed up at a second site (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

The genus Malus is included in Annex 1 of the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture (ITPGRFA), which promotes sustainable agriculture and food security through the conservation and sustainable use of plant genetic resources for food and agriculture, and the fair and equitable sharing of the benefits arising from their use (FAO 2009).

NatureServe G RANK REASONS: Occurs in the U.S. in Arizona and possibly in New Mexico; and in the Mexican states of Sonora; Chihuahua; Sinaloa; and Baja California between 1000 and 2000 m alt. Its habitat includes rocky hillsides; ridges; and crevices; oak woodlands or grasslands; et
NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: AZ(SNR); NM(SU)
Red List rationale: Manihot angustiloba has an extensive range through southwestern USA and northern Mexico. Its area of occupancy (AOO) is around 600 km2 and although is thought to be affected by development, it does not seem to be significant as the population is thought to be abundant and apparently secure. From the known distribution of this species, it is present in protected areas in Mexico, although monitoring and management of these subpopulations are most probably not carried out. It is therefore globally assessed as Least Concern. However, no active ex situ conservation measures are ongoing, therefore population monitoring, management and collection is highly recommended.
Red List habitat: Manihot angustiloba grows in hillsides, desert, riparian, forest, oak woodlands and grasslands. This species occurs between 914 to 2,000 m asl (NatureServe 2017, SEINet 2017).
Red List threats: According to Howeler et al. (2000), it is threatened by development but there is no further specific information.
Red List population: There is no specific information about the population of Manihot angustiloba. However, this species is considered widespread, abundant, and apparently secure (NatureServe 2017).
Red List range: Manihot angustiloba is native to Guatemala, northwest to central and south Mexico (Aguascalientes, Baja California Sur, Chiapas, Chihuahua, Colima, Coahuila, Durango, Guanajuato, Guerrero, Jalisco, Morelos, MichoacÃ¡n, Nayarit, Oaxaca, QuerÃ©taro, Sinaloa, Sonora and Tamaulipas) to the United States of America (USA), namely to Arizona and possibly to New Mexico (Villarreal 2001, CONABIO 2009, CONABIO, SUMA, UMSNH 2005, CONANP 2005, NatureServe 2017, Tropicos 2017, USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017, USDA, NRCS 2017).
Red List use trade: It is a tertiary wild relative of Cassava with potential to improve the starch content of the crop (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017). It has also been used to confer drought tolerance to the crop (Jennings 1995). Rogers and Appan (1973) mention this species has a strong odour of HCN in all parts of the plant, which has potential economic value. This species is also used like "quelite" in La Mixteca, Oaxaca (Katz 1992).
Red List conservation actions: Manihot angustiloba is present in four protected areas in Mexico [Janos Biosphere Reserve in Chihuahua, Sierra de Huautla Biosphere Reserve in Morelos and, Sierra de Alamos-Rio Cuchujaqui Area of Protection of Flora and Fauna and El Aribabi Conservation Ranch (private natural protected area) in Sonora] (SÃ¡nchez-Escalante 2013, SEMARNAT-CONANP 2013, CONANP 2005, SEMARNAT-CONANP 2015). There are no accessions of wild origin reported by Genesys (Genesys Global Portal on Plant Genetic Resources 2017) and there is only one accession from Arizona registered in USDA, ARS, GRIN (2017). It is therefore suggested that collection missions are carried out to conserve this species ex situ.

NatureServe G RANK REASONS: Distribution includes the U.S. (Arizona) and Mexico (Sonora; Chihuahua; Sinaloa). It usually occurs at high altitudes in the Santa Catalina; Baboquivari; and northern Sierra Madres Occidental mountains; but descends to sea level at the southern end of its
NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: AZ(S2)
Red List rationale: Manihot davisiae is globally assessed as Data Deficient as there is currently insufficient information available to evaluate this species. This species has a narrow area of occupancy of 160 km2, it is considered globally secure and imperilled in the state of Arizona (USA), where it is threatened by grazing and subpopulations seem to be small. However, there is no information regarding population size, distribution and trend of the Mexican sub-populations. Research into the status and trends of the Mexican sub-populations is thus recommended.
Red List habitat: In Arizona, this species typically occurs in grassy and herbaceous open areas on south-facing limestone slopes (US Forest Service and SWCA Environmental Consultants 2013). In Mexico, this species is present in the northern desert areas (Cervantes-Alcayde 2015).
Red List threats: In Arizona, this species is mainly threatened by grazing (US Forest Service and SWCA Environmental Consultants 2013).
Red List population: Manihot divisiae is ranked by NatureServe (2017) as apparently globally secure, nationally imperilled, and imperilled in the state of Arizona. In this state, it is a sensitive and extremely rare perennial herb (The Arizona Native Plant Society 2017). There have been two collections, one in Agua Caliente Canyon and another in Florida Canyon. A 2011 survey resulted in the discovery of a small subpopulation near lower McCleary Canyon, and two small subpopulations in Santa Rita mountains. Additionally, two individuals were found in separate locations in the Rincon Mountains, a mountain range from which it had not been known to occur (Rosemont Copper Company and WestLand Resources, Inc. 2012, US Forest Service and SWCA Environmental Consultants 2013). There is no information about the Mexican subpopulations of this species.
Red List range: Manihot davisiae is native to Arizona in the southwestern United States and northern Mexico (Chihuahua, Sinaloa and Sonora) (Rogers and Appan 1973, CONABIO 2009, SEINet 2017, USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017). It usually occurs at high altitudes in the Santa Catalina, Baboquivari, and northern Sierra Madre Occidental mountains, but descends to sea level at the southern end of its range (Rogers and Appan 1973). In Arizona, this species typically occurs at elevations ranging from 1066 to 1,458 m asl (US Forest Service and SWCA Environmental Consultants 2013).
Red List use trade: It is a wild relative of, and potential gene donor to Cassava (Vincent et al. 2013) and has been used to confer drought tolerance to the crop (Jennings 1995).
Red List conservation actions: According to NatureServe (2017), M. divisiae is apparently globally secure, nationally imperilled, and imperilled in the state of Arizona. In Arizona it is considered a sensitive species and with the goal of maintaining the species viability, it was advised that it should be considered in land managing activities (Arizona Game and Fish Department 2017). It is present in the Coronado National Forest, US (USDA, US Forest Service 1986). In Mexico this species is not known to occur in any existing protected area. According to Hershey (2010) and to the Genesys Global Portal on Plant Genetic Resources (2018) it is not conserved ex situ. It is, therefore, recommended that active conservation is initiated for this species.

NatureServe G RANK REASONS: A regional endemic of southern Texas and northern Mexico; this species was thought to have been extirpated from the U.S. until a single surviving plant was discovered in 1990. Several additional occurrences have since been found (1995) on U.S. Fish and Wi
NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: TX(S1)
Red List rationale: Walkerâs Manioc (Manihot walkerae) is endemic to Texas in the United States and Tamualipas in Mexico in an extent of occurrence (EOO) of around 95,000 km2 and an area of occupancy (AOO) of 52 km2. The population totalizes 1,000 mature individuals occurring in 33 subpopulations which include between 6 to about 90 mature individuals each indicating that the species is probably severely fragmented. Over 95% of the habitat of this species has been cleared for agriculture, grazing and development. The remaining habitat exists as patches which are highly vulnerable to herbicide application, overgrazing, herbivory by native and introduced wildlife, surface mining of caliche, petroleum and natural gas exploration, competition from invasive grasses (mainly Buffelgrass), and urban and residential development that continues at a rapid pace namely in the border of southern Texas and northern Mexico. The subpopulations along the Rio Grande in Texas and adjoining Mexico were threatened of extinction due to intensive cultivation in 1973 which, if it has already happened, resulted in a decline in the extent of occurrence, area of occupancy, area, extent and quality of habitat, number of subpopulations and of individuals. Manihot walkerae is therefore globally assessed as Endangered meeting criteria B2ab(i,ii,iii,iv,v); C2a(i). Given the population reduction of 95% based on the decline in the species' habitat quality, if the generation length of this species is known, the threat category would most likely increase to Critically Endangered. It is urgent that an update and implementation of the Walkerâs Manioc recovery plan is undertaken if we are to revert the decline of this species. Ex situ conservation, reintroduction of the species in well preserved or recovered patches of habitats as well as control of the invasive grasses are also recommended.
Red List habitat: It is a perennial herb that grows in grasslands and herbaceous habitats as well as in shrublands and chaparrals. It is associated to native grasses and herbaceous plants, and low shrubs and sub-shrubs. Many of the known populations of Walkerâs Manioc occur on current or former cattle ranches. This species is endemic to the Tamaulipas grassland-thornscrub community of the Lower Rio Grande Valley, where it occurs on sandy-loam soils underlain by caliche (U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service 2007, NatureServe 2017).
Red List threats: The major threat to Walker's Manioc is the destruction and fragmentation of native brush and grassland habitats where it is currently found. Over 95% of this species' native brushland habitat has been cleared for agriculture, grazing and development. Remaining native habitats exist as fragments and are vulnerable to accidental herbicide application, overgrazing, among others (Centre for Plant Conservation 2017, NatureServe 2017). Other main threats include surface mining of caliche, competition from invasive grasses (mainly Buffelgrass), urban and residential development that continues at a rapid pace throughout the border region of south Texas and northern Mexico, petroleum and natural gas exploration, and herbivory by native and introduced wildlife. All known sites are subject to one or more of these threats (U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service 2017). One observation of M. walkerae recorded at the iNaturalist in 2015 in GBIF (2017) refers to this species as endangered. In addition, Rogers and Appan (1973) highlights that intensive cultivation in the localities along the Rio Grande in Texas and adjoining Mexico are leading this species to extinction.
Red List population: In total, botanists have documented Walkerâs Manioc at a total of 33 sites, nine in Texas (since 1990) and 24 in Tamaulipas, Mexico (U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service 2007) with a total of about 1,000 mature individuals. Three of these sites in the US are located in protected tracts of Lower Rio Grande Valley National Wildlife Refuge, consisting of up to 90 individuals each, perhaps large enough to be considered viable subpopulations. Other five sites have as many as 30 individuals each, four of these are on private lands and one site is along a Texas Department of Transportation highway right-of-way. Pronatura Noreste, a Mexican non-profit conservation organization, documented 24 Walkerâs Manioc sites in the Mexican State of Tamaulipas, the smaller had six individuals and the largest had 67 individuals. One observation of M. walkerae recorded at the iNaturalist in 2015 (GBIF 2017) refers that only a few supopulations are known in the Lower Rio Grande Valley. According to Rogers and Appan (1973), this species is very close to extinction in the localities along the Rio Grande in Texas and adjoining Mexico due to intensive cultivation.
Red List range: Manihot walkerae is native to Texas in the United States and Tamualipas in Mexico (Gordillo et al. 2002, USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017). Altitude information for this species is unavailable.
Red List use trade: It is a wild relative of, and potential gene donor to Cassava. It has already been used to confer resistance to post-harvest physiological deterioration (PPD) which significantly diminishes the storage life of edible Cassava roots. Manihot walkerae is the only known source of resistance to PPD (US Fish and Wildlife Service 2007).
Red List conservation actions:
Manihot walkerae has been under cultivation at the University of Texas at Austin since 1940. Currently, the San Antonio Botanical Garden maintains a core collection of this species of plants from UT-Austin in a cold frame and greenhouse. Some plants were planted into a test plot and demonstration garden for both research and educational reasons. Seeds from core collection plants are currently stored on site for research (Center for Plant Conservation 2017).

Additionally, three of the largest US populations are on protected sites of the Lower Rio Grande Valley National Wildlife Refuge. Three private landowners have signed voluntary conservation agreements to protect the species, two in Tamaulipas and one in Texas (US Fish and Wildlife Service 2017). Some of these sites are qualitatively monitored at least annually, but have not been quantitatively inventoried since 1996 (US Fish and Wildlife Service 2007). Approximately half of the range of Walkerâs Manioc occurs in Mexico and the this species is not protected under Mexican protected species regulations (US Fish and Wildlife Service 2017). There are no accessions of wild origin reported by Genesys (Genesys Global Portal on Plant Genetic Resources 2018). It has been previously assessed as Threatened at global level (IUCN 1998). Walkerâs manioc recovery plan has been issued on December 12, 1993 and three factors that are relevant to its conservation have been identified: (i) present or threatened destruction, modification or curtailment of its habitat or range; (ii) disease or predation; and (iii) inadequacy of existing regulatory mechanisms (US Fish and Wildlife Service 1993).

Red List rationale: This tree species has a very wide distribution, large population, is not currently experiencing any major threats and no significant future threats have been identified. This species is therefore assessed as Least Concern.

NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: AZ(SNR); NM(SNR); TX(S2)
Red List rationale: The overall population of Phaseolus acutifolius is widely distributed from southwestern and southâcentral USA to northern and southern Mexico. The species is therefore assessed as Least Concern. However, wild subpopulations of P. acutifolius var. acutifolius are reported to be very scarce and P. acutifolius var. latifolius is recorded as scarce. Therefore, these two subtaxa require careful evaluation with a view to possible Red Listing under a threatened category. The establishment of active in situ management and monitoring of these subtaxa is also recommended.
Red List habitat: P. acutifolius var. acutifolius is usually found in pine-oak forest, where it is scattered among small shrubs and cacti, and can typically grows along stream beds and in dry washes (Freytag and Debouck 2002). P. acutifolius var. tenuifolius is most commonly found in canyon bottoms and on rocky slopes in open oak-acaia-cactus forests or in the shrubby chaparral of foothills (Nabhan 1979, Buhrow 1983, cited in Freytag and Debouck 2002). P. acutifolius var. latifolius grows in the understorey of open forests in canyon bottoms and flood plains, typified by spiny shrubs, cacti, and sparse grasses (Buhrow 1983, cited in Freytag and Debouck 2002). Subpopulations of P. acutifolius var. latifolius can also be found in arid subtropical  forests of small trees, as well as colonizing the sides of trails, abandoned fields and fence rows (Nabhan 1979, cited in Freytag and Debouck 2002).
Red List threats: This species is attacked by several pests, such as flies and caterpillars, and is eaten by grazing animals (Freytag and Debouck 2002).
Red List population: Freytag and Debouck (2002) record Phaseolus acutifolius var. acutifolius as "very scarce" in southwest USA and northwest Mexico, P. acutifolius var. tenuifolius as "the most common wild tepary" in southwest United States and in northwest Mexico, southward, and P. acutifolius var. latifolius as "scarce" in drier areas of northwest Mexico, southwest United States and Texas. Overall, the species is suspected to have a stable global population.
Red List range:
Phaseolus acutifolius is native to southwestern and south-central USA (southeast Arizona, southwest New MÃ©xico and Texas), to northern and southern Mexico (Baja California Sur, Chihuahua, Coahuila, Colima, Durango, Jalisco, QuerÃ©taro, Nayarit, Sinaloa and Sonora), as well as being cultivated in its native range (Freytag and Debouck 2002).

P. acutifolius var. acutifolius occurs in the range 500â1,700 m asl, P. acutifolius var. tenuifolius at 900â2,000 m asl (most commonly at around 1,500 m), and P. acutifolius var. latifolius at 335â1,930 m asl (most commonly at around 975 m) (Freytag and Debouck 2002).

Extensive work is needed to differentiate between cultivated and wild subpopulations of  P. acutifolius var. acutifolius to accurately map the distribution of this species in the wild.
Red List use trade: This species is a tertiary wild relative of, and potential gene donor to common and scarlet runner bean, and is known to have potential to confer disease resistance to common bean (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017). Wild subpopulations of P. acutifolius var. acutifolius are primary sources of genetic diversity with potential for improvement of its cultivated counterpart, tepary bean. As members of Gene Pool 1b of tepary bean, P. acutifolius var. tenuifolius and P. acutifolius var. latifolius (the latter recognized as a valid taxon in some taxonomic treatments) are also primary wild relatives of the crop, and tertiary wild relatives of common and scarlet runner bean.
Red List conservation actions: It is unknown whether this species occurs within protected areas or is subject to in situ conservation management. In terms of ex situ conservation, there are 155 accessions of wild source P. acutifolius maintained in the gene bank of Centro Internacional de Agricultura Tropical (CIAT) (International Centre for Tropical Agriculture), Colombia, with duplicates and other accessions (86) held by the Western Regional PI Station, Washington State University (including 52 accessions of P. acutifolius var. tenuifolius and 20 of P. acutifolius var. acutifolius), and additional backup accessions in the National Centre for Genetic Resources Preservation, Fort Collins, Colorado. Duplicate accessions are also held by the International Livestock Research Institute, Ethiopia, and there are safety duplicates of this species in the Svalbard Global Seed Vault (GENESYS 2016, SGSV Data Portal 2016, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2016).

NatureServe G RANK REASONS: Found on rocky hillsides and mesas from southern Arizona and Texas south to Central America.

NatureServe G RANK REASONS: Grows on mesas; hills and plains of AZ (4 cos.) and NM (7 cos.); TX and Chihuahua; Mexico.
NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: AZ(SNR); NM(SNR); TX(SNR)
Red List rationale: Phaseolus angustissimus is common in most of its range and its population is considered to be stable. It has an estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of 997,000 km2, and there are no known threats that affect it. For these reasons this species is assessed as Least Concern.
Red List habitat: This species is a perennial trifoliate long climbing vine with flowers in racemes (USDA 2017). It is commonly found in grassy areas of piÃ±on-juniper, open (Ponderosa) pine or oak forest, or chaparral associations with Acacia, Amelanchier, Artemisia, Berberis, Celtis, Ephedra, Euphorbia, Fraxinus, Penstemon, Rhus, and Yucca, in rocky and sandy soils derived from limestone, sandstone, conglomerate or volcanic rock (Freytag and Debouck 2002). It is tolerant to occasional frostings.
Red List threats: There are no known threats to this species.
Red List population: It is common in the United States, but in Mexico it was collected in 1940 and has not been found since (Freytag and Debouck 2002).
Red List range: Phaseolus angustissimus is distributed in the USA (Arizona, New Mexico and Texas), and in Sonora State, Mexico (Freytag and Debouck 2002).
Red List use trade: It is a tertiary wild relative of, and potential gene donor to common bean, and has potential for conferring cold tolerance traits to the crop (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017).
Red List conservation actions: Due to the lack of information about this species in Mexico and the fact that it is only known from one collection in that country in 1940, more research and sampling efforts are needed in a wider area. Its ex situ conservation status needs to be determined.

NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: AZ(SNR); CA(S1); NM(SNR); TX(SNR)
Red List rationale: Even though this species is not particularly abundant, it is common as it has a wide range, and the population is stable. It is therefore assessed as Least Concern. However, its in situ and ex situ conservation status needs to be determined.
Red List habitat: This species is found  along sand dunes, in rocky outcrops and talus slopes, throughout the desert shrubs, and low tree forests, especially in moist areas along dry wash stream beds and canyons, and associated with Acacia, Agave, Bursera, Cercidiuum, Encelia, Euphorbia, Fouquieria, Jatropha, Larrea, Mimosa, Platanus, Prosopis, Yucca, and many cactus species and grasses. Soils may be clays, or silty to sandy, rocky, and frequently alluvial loams from basalt, volcanic ash or limestone rocks (Freytag and Debouck 2002).
Red List threats: The species is attacked by spider mites which eat the leaves.
Red List population: This species is common but not very abundant.
Red List range: The species occurs in the USA in Arizona, California, New Mexico and Texas, and in Mexico in Baja California, Baja California Sur, Chihuahua, Coahuila, Durango and Sonora (Freytag and Debouck 2002) at elevations of 0â1,200 m asl (A. Delgado-Salinas pers. comm. 2017).
Red List use trade: It is a tertiary wild relative of, and potential gene donor to common and tepary bean (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017). The pods and dry seeds are used as food in the Pinacate region of Sonora.
Red List conservation actions: This species occurs within the Pinacate and El VizcaÃ­no Biosphere Reserves in Mexico. However, it is not known whether these subpopulations are under any form of conservation management. The ex situ conservation status of the species needs to be determined.

NatureServe G RANK REASONS: Grows on rocky hillsides; at margins of thicklets; and in pine forests; in AZ; NM; TX and northern Mexico.
NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: AZ(SNR); NM(SNR); TX(SNR)

Red List rationale: This is a wide ranging and abundant species that can be found in disturbed habitats. It is affected by several pests but the overall population is stable. It is also found in several protected areas which may provide protection to some subpopulations. It is therefore assessed as Least Concern.
Red List habitat: This species grows in a wide variety of habitats including pine, pine-oak and dry subtropical forests and thorny scrub. It can grow in disturbed habitats aided by its tuberous cylindrical pivotal and adventitious roots, long fruiting period, and high seed production.
Red List threats: This species is affected by powdery mildew, rust, golden mosaic virus, and rugose virus. It is also vulnerable to Apion weevil, beetles, aphids, leaf miners, Mexican bean beetle, and spider mites (Freytag and Debouck 2002).
Red List population: This species is common.
Red List range: This species is widely distributed from Mexico to Costa Rica at elevations of 120â2,200 m asl.
Red List use trade: <span lang="EN-US">It is a wild relative of, and potential gene donor to common, Lima, scarlet runner, tepary and year bean.
Red List conservation actions: This species occurs in several protected areas, such as the Pedregal de San Angel Reserve and National Park Desierto Leones in Mexico. However, it is not known whether it is under any in situ conservation management. Its ex situ conservation status needs to be determined.

NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: AZ(SNR); NM(SNR); TX(SNR)
Red List rationale: This is a wide-ranging and abundant species, and even though pests affect it, the overall population is stable. Therefore is here listed as Least Concern.
Red List habitat: This species grows in oak and pine forests, disturbed areas, and grassland with Opuntia. It grows in open spaces and is never found in dense forest (Freytag and Debouck 2002).
Red List threats: The species is affected by Epilachna varivestis which damages the leaves and kills the plant.
Red List population: This species is abundant. It is a prostrate species and expands over large areas.
Red List range: This species occurs in Arizona, New Mexico and Texas in the USA, and in Mexico in the states of Aguascalientes, Chihuahua, Coahuila, Durango, Guanajuato, Hidalgo, Puebla, QuerÃ©taro, San Luis PotosÃ­, Sonora, Tlaxcala and Zacatecas at elevations of 1,500â2,500 m asl (Freytag and Debouck 2002).
Red List use trade:
It is a tertiary wild relative of, and potential gene donor to Lima bean (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017).

The roots of this species are harvested, dried and cut up for sale as a medicinal product known as Cacolmecac in northern Mexico and Cocolmecac in central Mexico (G. Alejandre pers. comm. 2017).
Red List conservation actions: The in situ and ex situ conservation status of this species needs to be determined. It does not occur within protected areas.

NatureServe G RANK REASONS: Pine-oak woodlands in AZ and n Sinaloa; Mexico.
NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: AZ(S2S3)
Red List rationale: This species has a wide range and is common in its forest habitat. It is therefore assessed as Least Concern. Research into its in situ and ex situ conservation status is however recommended.
Red List habitat: This species grows in temperate forest of pine, oak, Cupressus, manzanita, and nogal, with the dominant species being: Arbutus spp., Juniperus deppeana, Pinus discolor, P. chihuahuana, P. engelmannii, Quercus arizonica, Q. emoryi, Q. hypoleucoides, and Q. viminea. It is associated with Acacia, Arctostaphylos, Bursera, Centrosema, Crataegus, Desmodiae, Dalea, Dasylirion, Epilobium, Erigeron, Eysenhardtia, Hymenothrix wrightii, Lupinus garcianus, Opuntia and other cacti, Rhynchosia, Ricinus, Silene, Tagetes, Tilandsia, Yucca schotti, composites, Mimosoideae, and grasses. It is common along roadsides, steep rocky hillsides or along moist banks of streams, and in full sun or shade. Soils are rocky and sandy, and derived from volcanic ash, rhyolitic, lava, granite, schist or limestone (Freytag and Debouck 2002). The species is persistent, having a very large tuberous root from which it re-sprouts if damaged.
Red List threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
Red List population: This species is common in its forest habitat.
Red List range: This species is distributed in the states of Arizona and Texas in the USA, and in Mexico in the states of Chihuahua, Durango, Jalisco, Nayarit, Sinaloa, Sonora and Zacatecas (Freytag and Debouck 2002).
Red List use trade:
This taxon is a tertiary wild relative of, and potential gene donor to common and Lima bean, and has been used to confer disease resistance in Lima bean (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017).
The root is uses to ferment a beverage called batari of the GuarijÃ­os ethnic group of Sonora and Chihuahua.
Red List conservation actions: The in situ and ex situ conservation status of this species needs to be determined. It does not occur in protected areas.

NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: AZ(S3); NM(SNR)
Red List rationale: This species is common throughout its range, not impacted by any threats, and the overall population is stable. It is therefore assessed as Least Concern.
Red List habitat: This species grows at high elevations in pineâoak forest with other trees and shrubs, such spruces, fir, juniper, Arbutus, and grasses. It is found in rocky, deep sandstone or volcanic ash soils rich in organic matter (Freytag and Debouck 2002).
Red List threats: There are no known threats to this species.
Red List population: The subpopulations of this species are small, but it is common throughout its range and the overall population is considered to be stable.
Red List range: This species occurs along the Sierra Madre Occidental mountain range in the USA in the states of New Mexico and Arizona, and in Mexico in the states of Chihuahua, Durango, Sinaloa, Sonora, Zacatecas and Nayarit, at elevations of 1,550â2,970 m asl (Freytag and Debouck 2002).
Red List use trade: It<span lang="EN-US"> is a wild relative of, and potential gene donor to common, Lima, scarlet runner, tepary and year bean.
Red List conservation actions: The in situ and ex situ conservation status of this species needs to be determined.

NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: AL(SNR); AR(SNR); CT(SNR); DC(SNR); DE(SH); FL(SNR); GA(S4?); IA(SNR); IL(SNR); IN(SNR); KY(S4S5); LA(SNR); MD(S3); ME(SNR); MI(SX); MO(SNR); MS(SNR); NC(S3); NJ(SNR); NY(S1?); OH(S3); OK(S1); PA(S1S2); SC(SNR); SD(SNR); TN(SNR); TX(S1); VA(S4); WV(SH)
Red List rationale: Phaseolus polystachios is a widespread and common herb for which at present there are no major known threats causing a population decline, hence it is rated as Least Concern.
Red List habitat: P. polystachios is a climbing, twining or trailing perennial which grows in low and upland rocky woods, bluffs, slopes, thickets and roadsides banks. It is easily misidentified and could be overlooked due to its twining habit.
Red List threats: There are no major known threats for this species at present.
Red List population: The species is widespread and common in many areas of its natural range.
Red List range: Phaseolus polystachios occurs in the United States.
Red List conservation actions: There are no known conservation measures specifically for P. polystachios, but the species is currently known to occur in some protected areas. Samples of seed of P. polystachios should be collected and stored as an ex situ conservation measure. The species has been assessed as Globally Secure (G5) form Nature Serve (2009), which is equivalent to IUCN category Least Concern.

AL(SNR); AR(SNR); AZ(SNR); CO(SNR); CT(SNR); DC(SNR); DE(SU); FL(SNR); GA(SNR); IA(S5); IL(SNR); IN(SNR); KS(SNR); KY(S5); LA(SNR); MA(SNR); MD(SNR); ME(SNR); MI(SNR); MN(SNR); MO(SNR); MS(SNR); MT(S4S5); NC(S3); ND(SNR); NE(SNR); NH(S1); NJ(S4); NM(SNR);
Red List rationale: Prunus americana is globally assessed as Least Concern as, despite being recorded as threatened in parts of its range, it is a very widely distributed species with a stable native population overall. It is present in a large number of protected areas and has accessions stored in gene banks. However, in situ management and monitoring is suggested in areas with a threatened population, and it is also recommended that a gap analysis is carried out to ensure the range of genetic diversity found in situ is fully represented in ex situ collections and where gaps are identified, further targeted collection should take place.
Red List habitat:
This species grows in medium to coarse textured soils that are acidic to mildly alkaline (Herman et al. 2010), preferring woodland habitats, scrublands and occasionally prairies (Soper and Heimburger 1982, Magee and Ahles 2007); it is also associated with riparian zones (Dieter and McCabe 1989). Plants for a Future (2012) also reports that this six metre high tree occurs on rich soils, by streams, on the borders of swamps and in hedgerows.

In Illinois, Hilty (2012), reports that this species occurs in habitats including mesic woodlands, woodland borders, savannas, thickets, powerline clearances in wooded areas and fence rows. This species is visited by many species of bee, wasp, butterfly, skipper, moth and beetle; the fruit is also eaten by mammals, predominantly the red and Gray Fox (Hilty 2012).
Red List threats: American Plum is susceptible to overgrazing, browsing and trampling (Lewis et al. 1956, Girard et al. 1987). This species is also susceptible to stem decay, branch cankers, black knot, and plum pockets (NDSU 2014). However, the magnitude of these threats remains unknown.
Red List population:
Prunus americana is the most broadly distributed wild plum in north America (Faust and Suranyi 1998), it is reported to be regularly occurring in Canada and the United States of America and is globally secure (NatureServe 2013), suggesting that it has a stable native population.

However, NatureServe (2013) reports that in some states/provinces in this species' native range it is threatened. Is it classified as vulnerable in Wyoming, North Carolina and New York, imperilled in Saskatchewan in Canada, critically imperilled in New Hampshire and possibly extirpated in Vermont (NatureServe 2013).
Red List range:
American plum is widespread across Canada and the United States of America at altitudes between 1,000 m to 2,300 m asl (Harrington 1964, Martin and Hutchins 1981). According to NatureServe (2013), it is native to the following states and provinces:
  • Canada: Manitoba, Ontario, Saskatchewan
  • United States: Alabama, Arizona, Arkansas, Colorado, Connecticut, Delaware, District of Columbia, Florida, Georgia, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, Kentucky, Louisiana, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, Minnesota, Mississippi, Missouri, Montana, Nebraska, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New Mexico, New York, North Carolina, North Dakota, Ohio, Oklahoma, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, South Carolina, South Dakota, Tennessee, Utah, Vermont, Virginia, West Virginia, Wisconsin, Wyoming
Red List use trade:
American Plum is an ornamental plant and is also used as a windbreak and for ornamental highway and riparian plantings (NDSU 2014). The fruit of this species is edible raw, and is often eaten as a preserve or jam (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013, NDSU 2014). It is also known to have medicinal properties for treating conditions, from skin complaints to asthma (Moerman 1998).

Prunus americana is a secondary genetic relative of Peach P. persica and Japanese Plum P. salicina, a tertiary genetic relative of Plum P. domestica and is also used as graft stock for Apricot P. armeniaca (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013) and so it has the potential for use as a gene donor for crop improvement.
Red List conservation actions:
American Plum is reported to occur in a wide range of protected areas (approximately 42) across north America ranging from Adirondack Park in the state of New York, south to the Central Gulf Coastal Plain Biosphere Reserve in Florida and west to the Bighorn Canyon National Recreation Area in Montana (Information Centre for the Environment (ICE) 2013).

According to Botanic Gardens Conservation International (BGCI 2013) this species has living collections in 50 botanical gardens worldwide and, although the size, state, origin and location of the collections are not detailed in this resource (garden locations are undisclosed to protect rare and valuable plant species), this is known to include the Missouri Botanical Gardens and the Royal Botanical Gardens Kew. The National Plant Germplasm System (NPGS) holds six accessions of wild origin, four of which are backed up at a second site (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013) and the EURISCO Catalogue (2013) holds six accessions, two of which may be of wild origin.

NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: CA(SNR); NV(SNR)
Red List rationale: Amgydalus andersonii is globally assessed as Least Concern as, although its distribution is restricted to California and Nevada in the United States of America, it occurs in a number of habitats across the region and its population is thought to be secure. Further research is recommended to determine the population size and to confirm the population trend.
Red List habitat: This species occurs on dry rocky slopes, in canyons and associated with sagebrush scrub, Pinyon or Juniper woodland (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006, Jepson Flora Project 2013).
Red List threats: <span class="datalabel1">The major threats to biodiversity in California include both the loss of habitat due to human development and the introduction of non-native species (California Academy of Sciences 2005). However, the direct threats to this species remain unknown.
Red List population: Amygdalus andersonii is reported as apparently secure by NatureServe (2015). As a result, it is suspected that this species' population trend is stable.
Red List range: Amygdalus andersonii is native to the states of California and Nevada in the United States of America (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013). It occurs at elevations between 900 m and 2,600 m asl (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006)
Red List use trade: Desert Peach is a tertiary genetic relative of Japanese Plum (P. salicina), Apricot (P. armeniaca) and Myrobalan Plum (P. cerasifera) and has been used as graftstock for Japanese Plum (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013, Vincent et al. 2013).
Red List conservation actions:
Passive in situ conservation for this species is presumed due to its presence in the following national parks in California: Sequoia National Park, Kings Canyon National Park, Death Valley National Park, and Yosemite National Park (Calflora 2013). However, these national parks have no specific active conservation in place for this species, and there is no federal legislation protecting it (USDA Forest Service 2013).

While Desert Peach is not yet represented in the Svalbard Global Seed Vault (SGSV Data Portal 2013), it is held in the Millennium Seed Bank at Kew (EURISCO Catalogue 2013) and three accessions exist in the National Plant Germplasm System (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013), all of which are of wild origin and two of which are duplicated at a second site.

NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: AL(SNR); AR(SNR); CA(SNR); CO(S1); DC(SNR); DE(SNA); FL(SNR); GA(SNR); IL(SNR); IN(SNR); KS(SNR); KY(S5); LA(SNR); MD(SNA); MO(SNR); MS(SNR); NC(S5); NE(S1); NJ(SNR); NM(SNR); OK(SNR); PA(S1); SC(SNR); TN(SNR); TX(SNR); VA(S5); WV(S1)
Red List rationale: Prunus angustifolia is globally assessed as Least Concern as it is a widespread species with a stable population. Additionally, conservation measures are in place including in situ conservation in protected areas and ex situ conservation in Botanical Gardens and the NPGS. A gap analysis is recommended to ensure the full range of genetic diversity found in situ in represented in ex situ collections. Furthermore, population management and monitoring is required in the states of Colorado, Nebraska, Pennsylvania and West Virginia to protect the threatened populations found there, this could be implemented through existing protected areas in which it occurs.
Red List habitat: Cherokee Plum usually occurs on sandy soils, occurring along fence rows, in pastures, fields, stream banks, sand dunes and disturbed sites, often forming thickets (Elias 1980). This species takes the form of a shrub or small tree that can reach heights of 4â6 m and widths ranging between 5â6 m (Gilman and Watson 2012)
Red List threats: Plum pox virus is the only plant virus known to infect Prunus species and is spread by aphids (Damsteegt et al. 2007), the impact of this virus on Prunus angustifolia is unknown.
Red List population: Prunus angustifolia is classified as nationally (and therefore, globally) secure, suggesting that its overall population is stable across its native range (NatureServe 2013). However it is recorded as critically imperilled (i.e. at very high risk of extinction or elimination due to very restricted range, very few populations or occurrences, very steep declines, very severe threats, or other factors) in four states: Colorado, Nebraska, Pennsylvania and West Virginia. It is recorded as exotic in Delaware and Maryland and is also cultivated (NatureServe 2013, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).
Red List range: This species is widespread across the United States of America, it is native to Alabama, Arkansas, California, Colorado, District of Colombia, Florida, Georgia, Illinois, Indiana, Kansas, Kentucky, Louisiana, Mississippi, Missouri, Nebraska, New Jersey, New Mexico, North Carolina, Oklahoma, Pennsylvania, South Carolina, Tennessee, Texas,Virginia and West Virginia (NatureServe 2013).
Red List use trade: Cherokee Plum is an ornamental plant as well as providing fruit for human consumption, for which it is cultivated in some areas (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resource Program 2013). This species is also a secondary genetic relative of Japanese Plum P. salicina (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013) and so it has the potential for use as a gene donor for crop improvement.
Red List conservation actions:
Cherokee plum is recorded to occur in approximately 26 protected areas across the United States of America from the Great Smoky Mountains National Park in North Carolina and Tennessee in the east to the Agate Fossil Beds National Monument in Nebraska in the central region of the USA and southwards into the Lake Meredith National Recreation Area in Texas (Information Centre for the Environment (ICE) 2013).

The National Plant Germplasm System (NPGS, in the USA) holds five accessions for this species, three of which are of wild origin and none of which are backed up at a second site (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013). Furthermore, according to Botanic Gardens Conservation International (BGCI 2013) this species has living collections in 20 botanical gardens worldwide and, although the size, state, origin and location of the collections are not detailed in this resource (garden locations are undisclosed to protect rare and valuable plant species), this is known to include the Missouri Botanical Gardens and the Royal Botanical Gardens, Kew.
