Red List rationale: Prunus emarginata is globally assessed as Least Concern as is a widely distributed species which is considered stable and secure within it's native range. It is recommended that survey work is undertaken in areas such as Utah where the local population is thought to be decreasing and conservation actions implemented, with a focus in these areas.
Red List habitat: Bitter Cherry is a deciduous, small tree or shrub that grows to between one and six metres in height and often forms dense thickets; it occurs in a variety of habitats including mountain brush, woodland, and riparian (Esser 1995).
Red List threats: This species is susceptible to pests including aphids, borers and tent caterpillars, it is also susceptible to trunk and root rot fungi (Taylor and Taylor 1981). Furthermore, over-browsing by deer in the wild is decreasing Bitter Cherry cover (Vankat 1977).
Red List population: Bitter Cherry is classified by NatureServe (2013) as globally secure, suggesting that the population is stable across its native range. However, it is classified as critically imperilled in Utah, so may be in decline in this area of its range (NatureServe 2013).
Red List range: Bitter Cherry is native to Mexico (Baja California), Canada (British Columbia), and western areas of United States of America (Arizona, California, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, Oregon, Utah, Washington and Wyoming) (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013, NatureServe 2013).
Red List use trade:
Native Americans used this species for medicinal purposes, including as a treatment for eczema, heart trouble, colds and tuberculosis (Moerman 1998). It is also used for land reclamation and erosion control (Everett et al. 1980).

In addition, bitter cherry belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of Sweet Cherry P. avium and so it has the potential for use as a gene donor for crop improvement, particularly for conferring disease resistance to cherry (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).
Red List conservation actions:
Bitter Cherry occurs in the following protected areas (Information Center for the Environment (ICE) 2013):

  • California Coast Ranges Biosphere Reserve, California  
  • Coram Biosphere Reserve, Montana  
  • Crater Lake National Park, Oregon  
  • Devil's Postpile National Monument, California  
  • Ebey's Landing National River, Washington  
  • Golden Gate Biosphere Reserve, California  
  • Grand Canyon National Park, Arizona  
  • Lake Roosevelt National Recreation Area, Washington  
  • Land Between the Lakes Biosphere Reserve, Kentucky, Tennessee  
  • Lassen Volcanic National Park, California  
  • Lava Beds National Monument, California  
  • Mount Arrowsmith  Mount Tamalpais State Park, California  
  • Navajo National Monument, Arizona  
  • Redwood National Park, California  
  • Sequoia and Kings Canyon Biosphere Reserve, California  
  • Whiskey-Shasta-Trinity National Recreation Area, California  
  • Yosemite National Park, California 

While the presence of the species is recorded in these protected areas, distribution information is not available.

The National Plant Germplasm System (NPGS), in the USA, holds four accessions of this species, all of which are of wild origin and are duplicated at a second site (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013). Furthermore, according to Botanic Gardens Conservation International (BGCI 2013) this species has living collections in 40 botanical gardens worldwide and, although the size, state, origin and location of the collections are not detailed in this resource (garden locations are undisclosed to protect rare and valuable plant species) it is known to be present in the Hoyt Arboretum (Portland, USA).

Red List rationale: Prunus gracilis is globally assessed as Least Concern as it is relatively widespread across the United States of America, is classified as apparently secure across its native range and is common in some parts of its distribution. However, it is critically imperilled in other areas of its range and there is a lack of population information regarding distribution, size and trend as well as the threats facing the species. It is recommended that the in situ conservation status of this species is determined and active management and monitoring is established alongside complementary ex situ collection to ensure the long-term survival of this species.
Red List habitat: The flowers of this 1.2 m shrub are hermaphrodite and pollinated by insects (Plants for a Future 2012). It is found in fence rows, open woodlands, woodlands edge, forest openings, hillsides, slopes, sandy roadsides, upland thickets and waste places (Wildflower Center 2007, Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2007).
Red List threats: The threats to this species remain unknown.
Red List population: NatureServe (2013) classifies this species as apparently secure across its global native range. However, the same source also records it as critically imperilled in Colorado, Kansas and Arkansas as well as imperilled in Louisiana. The Oklahoma Biological Survey (1999) described this species as common giving a wide distribution within this state. Furthermore it does not feature on the Rare Plants List of New Mexico (New Mexico Rare Plant Technical Council 1999) or Texas (Poole et al. 2007).
Red List range: Oklahoma Plum is native to the states of Alabama, Arkansas, Colorado, Kansas, Louisiana, New Mexico, Oklahoma and Texas in the United States of America (NatureServe 2013). It occurs at elevations between 100 m and 1,300 m asl (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2007).
Red List use trade: The Oklahoma Plum belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of the Japanese Plum Prunus salicina (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013) and so it has the potential for use as a gene donor for crop improvement.
Red List conservation actions: While many protected areas occur within this species' native distribution, it is not known whether or not it is present within them. According to Botanic Gardens Conservation International (BGCI 2013) this species has a living collection in one botanical garden worldwide, although the size, state, origin and location of the collection is not detailed in this resource (garden locations are undisclosed to protect rare and valuable plant species). No further evidence of ex situ conservation was found for this species.

NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: TX(S3)
AR(SNR); IA(S1); IL(SNR); IN(SNR); KS(S1); KY(S4?); MA(SNR); MD(SNR); MO(SNR); NE(S1); OH(S4); OK(SNR); TN(SNR); TX(SNR); WV(SNA)
Red List rationale: Prunus hortulana is globally assessed as Least Concern as it is a fairly widespread species and is apparently secure across its native range, despite being under threat in Iowa, Nebraska and Kansas. Priorities for this species include gathering of germplasm material for ex situ conservation and field surveys to determine population distribution, size and trend, particularly in states where is threatened. Research into the threats affecting the species and the establishment of in situ conservation, where appropriate, is recommended.
Red List habitat:
Prunus hortulana occurs in roadside thickets, open woodlands and flood plains, flowering from April to May and fruiting from August to September (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006).

This species has been domesticated and numerous cultivars have been developed. As a result of cultivation, it has spread widely beyond its native range (Oklahoma Biological Survey 2014).
Red List threats: The threats to this species remain unknown. The general threats to this species' habitat include invasive species, water and air pollution, and recreational disturbance (National Park Service 2014). Outside of protected areas, American biodiversity is under threat of urbanization (Czech 2004).
Red List population: According to NatureServe (2012), Prunus hortulana is apparently secure across its global native range in the United States of America, suggesting that its overall native population is stable. However, the same source classifies it as critically imperilled in Kansas, Iowa (occurring in five counties in the southeast of the state) and Nebraska (where it occurs in only one county).
Red List range: Hortulan Plum is native to the eastern and north-central states of Arkansas, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa (in the counties Appanoose, Des Moines, Johnson, Lee, Van Buren), Kansas, Kentucky, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, Missouri, Nebraska (in the county Richardson), Ohio, Oklahoma, Tennessee, Texas and Virginia in the United States of America (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006, NatureServe 2013). It occurs between 50 m and 500 m asl and has also become naturalized in West Virginia (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013, NatureServe 2012).
Red List use trade:
Hortulan Plum is cultivated and the fruit is eaten raw, cooked or preserved (Plants for a Future 2012, Oklahoma Biological Survey 2014). It is also grown as an ornamental plant (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

This species belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of Myrobalan Plum P. cerasifera and Japanese Plum P. salicina, it also belongs to the tertiary Gene Pool of Peach P. persica, and so it has the potential for use as a gene donor for crop improvement, particularly to confer disease resistance to crops (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013). It also has potential for use as graft stock for cultivated Peach P. persica (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).
Red List conservation actions:
Hortulan Plum is present in the following protected areas: Buffalo National River (Arkansas), George WA Carver National Monument (Montana), Great Smoky Mountains National Park (North Carolina, Tennessee), Southern Appalachian Biosphere Reserve (North Carolina, Tennessee), however, many of these reserves are outside the species' native range (Information Center for the Environment (ICE) 2013).

No accessions were found in the National Plant Germplasm System (NPGS) in the USA, however, according to Botanic Gardens Conservation International (BGCI 2013) this species has living collections in six botanical gardens worldwide, although the size, state, origin and location of the collections are not detailed in this resource (garden locations are undisclosed to protect rare and valuable plant species). Gathering of germplasm material for ex situ conservation is a priority for this species, particularly in threatened parts of the species native range.

NatureServe G RANK REASONS: Restricted range; destruction of about half its rangewide habitat; fragmentation of remainder; difficulty of long-term management outside large natural or seminatural barrier dune preserves. Yet; dozens of stands extant in managed areas.
NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: CT(S4); DE(S3); MA(SNR); MD(S1); ME(S1); MI(SNR); NH(SNR); NJ(SNR); NY(S4); PA(S1); RI(SNR); VA(S1?)
Red List rationale:
Prunus maritima is globally assessed as Data Deficient as there is currently insufficient information available to evaluate this species. It has a restricted range and its habitat is threatened by the effects of tourism, however, it is reported to be present in large numbers in managed areas (NatureServe 2013). As a result, the population trend is unknown. Furthermore, despite NatureServe (2013) reporting that the species' habitat is becoming fragmented, there is no quantitative evidence to assess whether this species is severely fragmented.

It is recommended that ex situ collection is undertaken to ensure the full range of genetic diversity found in the wild is represented in genebanks. In addition, surveys to determine the in situ conservation status of P. maritima should be carried out.
Red List habitat: Prunus maritima occurs along the Atlantic coast of the United States of America on sand dunes and barrier islands, beaches, sandy fields, roadsides and coastal barrens; it is also frequent in the interdune shrub zone (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006, NatureServe 2013).
Red List threats: Coastal resorts and recreation due to tourism are particular threats to Prunus maritima, it is also at risk from trampling (NatureServe 2013).
Red List population:
Prunus maritima is recorded as apparently secure in its global native range, all of which falls within the United States of America (NatureServe 2013), however, the same source records it as critically imperilled in Maine, Maryland, Pennsylvania and Virginia and vulnerable in Delaware though it is apparently secure in New York and Connecticut.

There are an estimated 81â300 wild occurrences of this species, and tens of thousands of individuals in coastal stands, but it is experiencing habitat fragmentation; it is thought that approximately half of the species' habitat has already been lost (NatureServe 2013). 

It is worth mentioning that the profile presented on NatureServe (2013) for this species was last reviewed in 1988 and further research to ascertain population size, distribution and trends would be beneficial for this species.
Red List range: Prunus maritima is native to the states of Connecticut (county of New London), Delaware, Maine (counties of Cumberland, Knox, Sagadahoc and Yorks), Maryland (Anne Arundel, Calvert, Saint Mary's and Worcester), Massachusetts, Michigan, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New York, Pennsylvania (counties of Bucks and Montgomery), Rhode Island and Virginia in the United States of America (NatureServe 2013, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013). It is a coastal species occurring between sea level and 30 m a.s.l. (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006).
Red List use trade: The fruits of Prunus maritima are eaten by humans and it is also an ornamental plant; in addition, it belongs to the tertiary Gene Pool of cultivated Plum P. domestica and is used as graftstock for Peach P. persica (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).
Red List conservation actions:
This species is present in the following protected areas (Information Center for the Environment (ICE) 2013), however, it is not known if any active conservation is provided for Prunus maritima populations in these areas:
  • Acadia National Park (Maine)
  • Assateague Island National Seashore (Maryland)
  • Fire Island National Seashore (New York)
  • Gateway National Recreation Area (New York)
  • Beach Plum Island (Delaware).


NatureServe (2013) also suggests that some stands of this species are in areas that are actively managed and that in these localities the species is thriving.

One wild germplasm accession of this species is present in the National Plant Germplasm System (NPGS), in the USA (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013), and two accessions that may be of wild origin are present in the EURISCO Catalogue (2013). Furthermore, according to Botanical Garden Conservation International (BGCI 2013) this species has living collections in 33 botanical gardens worldwide and, although the size, state, origin and location of the collections are not detailed in this resource (garden locations are undisclosed to protect rare and valuable plant species), it is known to be present in Delaware State University Arboretum (2014) and the New York Botanical Gardens (Centre of Plant Conservation 2014).

NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: AL(SNR); AR(SNR); GA(S1?); IA(S3); IL(SNR); IN(SNR); KS(SNR); KY(S5?); LA(SNR); MO(SNR); MS(SNR); NC(SNR); NE(S2?); OH(S3); OK(SNR); SC(SNR); SD(SNR); TN(SNR); TX(SNR)
Red List rationale: Prunus mexicana is globally assessed as Least Concern as it is a relatively widespread species that is thought to be globally secure. The establishment of active management and monitoring of populations, with ex situ back up, is recommended to ensure the long-term survival of this species, particularly in areas where it may be threatened (e.g. Iowa).
Red List habitat: Prunus mexicana occurs on stream bottoms, open woods and also at the edges of woodland (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006). Unlike many other Prunus species, Mexican Plum grows singly, not in thickets (Texas Native Plant Database 2014).
Red List threats: The threats to this species remain unknown. However, this species is a known host of the plum pox virus (James and Thompson 2006).
Red List population: According to NatureServe (2012), Mexican Plum is apparently secure across its native global range; state specific evaluations show that this species is vulnerable in Iowa.
Red List range: Prunus mexicana is native to Mexico (Coahuila, Nuevo LeÃ³n, San Luis PotosÃ­ and Tamaulipas) and the states of Alabama, Arkansas, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, Kentucky, Louisiana, Mississippi, Missouri, Oklahoma, Tennessee and Texas in the United States of America (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013). It occurs between 10 m and 400 m a.s.l. (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006).
Red List use trade:
Mexican Plum belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of Japanese Plum P. salicina and so it has the potential for use as a gene donor for crop improvement (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

The fruit is eaten by humans, fresh and/or made into preserves, and is consumed by birds and mammals; this species also serves as a stock for grafting cultivated varieties of plum (Wildflower Centre 2007, Plants for a Future 2012). This species is commonly cultivated for horticulture and planted in residential gardens (Gilman and Watson 1994).
Red List conservation actions:
Mexican Plum occurs in the following protected areas in its native range (Information Center for the Environment (ICE) 2013):
  • Big Thicket Biosphere Reserve (Texas)
  • Chickasaw National Recreation Area (Oklahoma)
  • Felsenthal National Wildlife Refuge (Arkansas) â reproducing population present
  • Hot Springs National Park (Arkansas) 
  • Little River National Wildlife Refuge (Oklahoma)
  • Shaw Nature Reserve (Missouri) (Missouri Botanical Gardens 2009)
  • Bear Springs Blossom Nature Preserve (Texas) (Conservation Education 2014)
  • Arbor Hills Nature Preserve (Texas) (Plano Parks Foundation 2006).


According to Botanical Garden Conservation International (BGCI 2013) this species has living collections in 25 botanical gardens worldwide. Although the size, state, origin and location of the collections are not detailed in this resource (garden locations are undisclosed to protect rare and valuable plant species), this species is known to occur in the Worth Botanical Gardens and B.R.I.T Gardens (Texas) (Trees for Me 2012). Two germplasm accessions of wild origin are held in the National Plant Germplasm System (NPGS), in the USA (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013) but no other evidence of ex situ conservation was found.

NatureServe G RANK REASONS: Endemic to Texas on the Edwards Plateau and Rio Grande Plains where it is apparently rare on limestone slopes; sandy brushy plains; ledges; and in canyons (Correll and Johnston 1970).
NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: TX(S3S4)
TX(S2)
Red List rationale:
This species is globally assessed as Critically Endangered. Fruits have not been observed in the population so it is suspected that it is not reproducing, as a result, no plants can be recorded as mature individuals unless new evidence can be put forward to show the remaining plants are able to reproduce. Additionally, continuing decline of the population is inferred from its inability to reproduce. Furthermore, the species has no known conservation in place, this is a concern as with no human intervention it's long-term survival is highly unlikely.

Priorities for this species include undertaking field surveys to determine the distribution of remaining individuals and any external threats that may be affecting the population, establishing a well-informed species recovery programme that incorporates in situ population management and monitoring, research towards re-establishing reproductive capacity and establishment of an ex situ core collection for the species.
Red List habitat:
This species grows in far west Texas, normally occurring in thickets (e.g in the Del Norte Mountains), but can be a single-trunked tree 3.7â4.6 m in height (e.g. in the Glass Mountains) (Texas Native Plant Database 2014).

Murray Plum occurs on pine-oak-juniper or oak-juniper woodlands on steep, rocky slopes or stream banks, in mesic, high elevation canyons and along fence rows; it also occurs on both igneous and sedimentary substrates (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006, NatureServe 2013).
Red List threats: Murray Plum is a host plant of the Oriental Leaf Beetle Agelastica alni ssp. orientalis (Downing 2002). Any additional threats to this species remain unknown. However, because it has not been observed to produce fruit, its long-term survival is highly unlikely without major intervention.
Red List population:
Murray Plum was once thought to be endemic to the Glass, Del Norte, Guadalupe and Davis mountains of Brewster, Culberson and Jeff Davis counties, Texas (Poole et al. 2007). However, it is now considered so rare that since its first discovery in 1928 it has not been observed in fruit (Texas Native Plant Database 2014). According to NatureServe (2013), it is possibly extinct and all known individuals have failed to produce any fruit. 

Enquist (1997) judged Prunus murrayana to be a synonym of the more widespread taxon P. rivulens var. pubescens, which is found in Coke, Concho, Crockett, Edwards, Irion, Schleicher, Sterling, Sutton and Tom Green counties on the western Edwards Plateau, as well as in Brewster, Culberson and Jeff Davis counties in the trans-pesos region of Texas (Poole et al. 2007). However, DNA sequence analysis work suggested these are two distinct species (Rohrer et al. 2008).
Red List range: Prunus murrayana is native to Texas (in the counties of Brewster, Culbertson and Jeff Davis) in the United States of America at elevations of 500 m to 1,500 m a.s.l., however, some sources suggest it may now be extinct (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006, NatureServe 2013, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).
Red List use trade: Prunus murrayana belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of Myrobalan Plum P. cerasifera Ehrh. and Japanese Plum P. salicina Lindl. and so it has the potential for use as a gene donor for crop improvement (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).
Red List conservation actions: There is no evidence of any conservation in place for this species as it is not known to be present in any protected areas, botanical gardens or arboretums and is not present in any known genebanks.

NatureServe G RANK REASONS: Wide range - Bahamas; Florida; Mexico; West Indies; and Brazil.

Red List rationale: This species is globally assessed as Least Concern as it is a widespread species with a stable global population. It occurs in a range of protected areas and so there is potential to include the management and monitoring of this species into existing reserve management plans. Ex situ conservation is also in place though the species would benefit from collection across its full geographic range with the aim of storing accessions that fully represent the range of genetic diversity found in situ. Surveys should be undertaken in areas where the species is thought to be threatened, e.g. in Labrador, Wyoming, Indiana and Georgia to determine the threats they are facing and to plan appropriate conservation actions to ensure its long-term survival.
Red List habitat: Prunus pensylvanica occurs in open forest habitats, by streams and on lakeshores, on rocky hillsides and cliffs and in more disturbed sites including clearings, roadsides and burned areas; it often grows in thickets (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006).
Red List threats: There are no major threats to this species.
Red List population: Prunus pensylvanica is a widespread species and NatureServe (2012) reports that this species is globally secure across its native range in North America, suggesting that its population is stable. However, the same source also reports that the species is vulnerable in the Canadian region of Labrador in the province of Newfoundland and Labrador and that it is imperilled in the states of Wyoming, Indiana and Georgia in the United States of America.
Red List range: Prunus pensylvanica is a widespread species native to Canada and north, central and southeast states of the United States of America; it occurs at elevations between sea level and 2,800 m a.s.l. and is also cultivated (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006, NatureServe 2012, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).
Red List use trade:
Prunus pensylvanica has been used as graftstock for breeding Sour Cherry P. cerasus L.; it is also an ornamental species and is poisonous to mammals (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resource Program 2013).

This species is also known to have medicinal properties including uses in treating fevers, infections, stomach pains, and for sores and ulcers (Plants for a Future 2012).
Red List conservation actions:
Prunus pensylvanica occurs in a wide range of protected areas across its native range, the Information Center for the Environment (ICE) (2013) records it as present in close to 60 different reserves including Banff National Park in Alberta, Fundy National Park in New Brunswick, Great Smoky Mountains National Park in North Carolina and Tennessee and the Shenandoah National Park in Virginia, though it is suspected that these areas do not provide active population management or monitoring for this species.
Three wild germplasm accessions of this species are held in the National Plant Germplasm System (NPGS), in the USA (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013), and the EURISCO Catalogue (2013) reports three accessions of undisclosed origin held in the Millennium Seed Bank at the Royal Botanical Garden Kew. Furthermore, according to Botanical Garden Conservation International (BGCI 2013) this species has living collections in 41 botanical gardens worldwide and, although the size, state, origin and location of the collections are not detailed in this resource (garden locations are undisclosed to protect rare and valuable plant species) it is found in the Asheville Botanical Gardens (2014) and North Carolina Botanical Garden (US Forest Service 2014).

Red List rationale: Prunus besseyi is globally assessed as Least Concern as it is widespread and largely secure across its native range in North America. However, it is classified as critically imperilled in much of its Canadian range (NatureServe 2013) and there remains a lack of information regarding habitat trends and specific threats facing the species. Although P. besseyi has been recorded in a small number of protected areas, more formal population management and monitoring is recommended, particularly in areas where is it thought to be threatened.
Red List habitat: This species occurs on sandy hills, open plains, rock slopes and/or shores (Fernald 1950). It is a shrub that grows to approximately 1.2 m and flowers in May; the flowers are pollinated by insects (Plants for a Future 2012).
Red List threats: Common diseases affecting this species include Taphrina leaf curl, black knot and fireblight (NDSU 2014). The extent to which Prunus besseyi is affected by these diseases is unknown. Any additional threats to this species remain unknown.
Red List population: Prunus besseyi is recorded as apparently secure across its native range in north America, however, it does appear to be threatened in some parts of its range including Saskatchewan and Ontario where it is critically imperilled and Wyoming where it is imperilled (NatureServe 2013).
Red List range: Besseyi Cherry is native to north America, specifically to the US states of Colorado, Iowa, Kansas, Minnesota, Montana, Nebraska, North Dakota, South Dakota, Utah and Wyoming, and the Canadian provinces of Manitoba, Ontario and Saskatchewan (NatureServe 2013). In Saskatchewan it is specifically found in aspen parkland and mid-boreal lowland ecoregions (University of Saskatchewan 2014).
Red List use trade:
This species is used for environmental regeneration and as a source of food for humans. In addition it belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of Myrobalan Plum P. cerasifera Ehrh., Peach P. persica (L.) Batsch and Japanese Plum P. salicina Lindl.; it is also used as graft stock for Apricot P. armeniaca L., Sweet Cherry P. avium (L.) L. and Plum P. domestica L. (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

The fruits are eaten by many songbirds and the shrubs are used as nesting cover for some songbird species; it is also browsed by deer (NDSU 2014).
Red List conservation actions:
Prunus besseyi is recorded in three protected areas: Knife River Indian Villages National Historic Site, North Dakota, Pipestone National Monument, Minnesota and Woodland Caribou Provincial Park, Ontario (Information Centre for the Environment (ICE) 2013).

One wild accession is held in the National Plant Germplasm System (NPGS, in the USA) under the synonym Prunus pumila var. besseyi, however this is not duplicated at a second site (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013). Also, according to Botanic Gardens Conservation International (BGCI 2013) this species has 31 living collections, as well as four living collections under the synonym P. pumila var. besseyi, in botanical gardens worldwide. Although the size, state, origin and location of the collections are not detailed in this resource (garden locations are undisclosed to protect rare and valuable plant species), this species is known to be present in several arboretums including Nebraska State Wide Arboretum (University of Nebraska-Lincoln 2011) and Dominion Arboretum (Government of Canada 2009). The EURISCO Catalogue (2013) reports five accessions for this species, however it is not known whether these originated from cultivation.

Red List rationale: Prunus munsoniana is globally assessed as Least Concern as it is reported to be globally secure. However, there is little evidence of active conservation for this species, so the incorporation of population management and monitoring into existing management regimes of protected areas, where this species is known to occur, and the collection of germplasm material for ex situ storage is recommended to ensure that its population remains stable. Additional research into the threats facing this species would also be beneficial.
Red List habitat: Prunus munsoniana occurs on rich soils along the banks of streams, floodplains, pastures, roadsides and edges of woodlands, often forming thickets (Elias 1980, Plants for a Future 2012). This species is also known to grown on hillsides and slopes (Wildflower Centre 2007).
Red List threats: The threats to this species remain unknown.
Red List population: NatureServe (2013) records this species as globally secure, although this was last reviewed in 1988 it can be assumed that the population is stable. In Oklahoma this species is deemed uncommon under the synonym Prunus rivularis Scheele (Oklahoma Biological Survey 1999). It is not included on the list of rare plants of Texas (Poole et al. 2010).
Red List range: Prunus munsoniana is native to the states of Alabama, Arkansas, Georgia, Illinois, Kansas, Kentucky, Louisiana, Mississippi, Missouri, Ohio, Oklahoma, Tennessee and Texas in the United States of America (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).
Red List use trade: Prunus munsoniana has been used in plant breeding as rootstock for the improvement of Myrobalan Plum P. cerasifera Ehrh (Faust and SurÃ¡nyi 1998).
Red List conservation actions:
This species is present in the following protected areas in its native range (Information Center for the Environment (ICE) 2013):
  • Chickasaw National Recreation Area (Oklahoma) where little or no data is present for this species. 
  • Great Smoky Mountains National Park (Tennessee) where its distribution is partially known.
  • Southern Appalachian Biosphere Reserve (Tennessee) where its distribution is partially known. 
  • Wilson's Creek National Battlefield (Missouri) where a reproducing population is present but the species is uncommon. 

Incorporation of population management and monitoring into the existing management regimes of these protected areas is recommended to ensure the long-term survival of the species.

According to Botanical Garden Conservation International (BGCI 2013) this species has living collections in 11 botanical gardens worldwide. Although the size, state, origin and location of the collections are not detailed in this resource (garden locations are undisclosed to protect rare and valuable plant species), this species is known to be present in Asheville Botanical Gardens (2014) in North Carolina. No other evidence of ex situ conservation was found and so collection of germplasm material and duplicated ex situ storage is a priority for this species.

Red List rationale: Prunus serotina is a tree species native to North and Central America. It is found in Canada, the United States, Mexico, Guatemala, Honduras and El Salvador. The species has been introduced to Europe where it is considered an invasive and South America where the it has become broadly naturalised. The species occurs in a variety of habitats, has no major threats and a large population. It is assessed as Least Concern.
Red List habitat: Black Cherry is a large tree that occurs as scattered individuals in numerous forest types. In the US, it is codominant in only one cover type, the black cherry-maple type found in the Allegheny Plateau and Allegheny Mountain sections of New York, Pennsylvania, Maryland, and West Virginia. In this type, Black Cherry is a primary component along with Red Maple (Acer rubrum), Sugar Maple (A. saccharum), and White Ash (Fraxinus americana). Other common associates include American Beech (Fagus grandifolia), Eastern Hemlock (Tsuga canadensis), Sweet Birch (Betula lenta), Yellow Birch (B. alleghaniensis), Yellow-poplar (Liriodendron tulipifera), Cucumber Tree (Magnolia acuminata), oaks (Quercus spp.), and hickories (Carya spp.) (Uchytil 1991). Reproduction is mostly through seeds. There is preference for mesic woods and the species can grow in disturbed secondary sites. The species is shade tolerant and grows late in succession. In Mexico and Guatelmala, Prunus serotina grows in cloud forests.
Red List threats: There are no threats affecting or likely to adversely affect Prunus serotina in the near future (NatureServe 2018).
Red List population: The known population is stable.
Red List range:
This species is widespread in eastern North America. It is found from Canada, and into the US to the states of Minnesota, North Dakota south to Florida and Texas, with outlying subpopulations in New Mexico, and Arizona. The species occurs further south into Mexico, Guatemala (Nesom 2008, VillaseÃ±or 2016), El Salvador and Honduras (E.M. MartÃ­nez Salas pers. comm. 2018). 
The species is introduced to British Columbia, Canada and much of South America (Tropicos 2018) where it has become naturalised (CABI 2017). In Europe the species has been introduced and is considered invasive (CABI 2017).
Red List use trade: Black Cherry wood is a rich reddish-brown colour and is strong, hard, and close-grained making it one of the most valued cabinet and furniture woods in North America. It is also used for panelling, interior trim, veneers, handles, crafts, toys, and scientific instruments. The fruit has been used to flavor rum and brandy (âcherry bounceâ). Pitted fruits are edible and are eaten raw and used in wine, ice and jelly. Black Cherry trees have also been used for reclamation of surface mine spoil (Nesom 2008).
Red List conservation actions: No conservation action is in place to protect this species as the known population is large and stable, and the species is found across an extensive range. Prunus serotina is ranked G5 - secure (NatureServe 2018). This species is found in 155 ex situ collections (BGCI 2018).

NatureServe G RANK REASONS: Entity is frequent across Georgia sandhills; usually overlooked and omitted as a species in most manuals.

Red List rationale: Prunus subcordata is globally assessed as Least Concern as it is thought to be stable across its native range in the US states of California and Oregon. Despite being stable, it does have a relatively restricted range and there is no evidence of any active conservation. As a result, it is recommended that active management and monitoring is established in existing protected areas in which it occurs and complementary ex situ collection is carried out to ensure the full range of genetic diversity found in the wild is represented in genebanks.
Red List habitat: Prunus subcordata occurs in pine-oak and juniper-oak woodlands as well as in shrubland habitats such as chaparral, it is also found on dry rocky slopes and stream banks (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006). This species is known to occur in Yellow Pine Forests (Califlora 2014).
Red List threats: Similarly to many other Prunus species, P. subcordata is susceptible to rust mites Aculus cornutus and A. fockeui (Oldfield 1984). Additional threats to this species remain unknown.
Red List population: NatureServe (2013) reports that this species is globally secure across its native range.
Red List range: Prunus subcordata is native to California and Oregon in the United States of America and is found at elevations between 100 m and 1,900 m a.s.l. (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006, NatureServe 2013, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).
Red List use trade: Prunus subcordata is cultivated as an ornamental and for its fruit; it also belongs to the tertiary Gene Pool of cultivated Plum P. domestica L. and so it has the potential for use as a gene donor for crop improvement (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).
Red List conservation actions:
Prunus subcordata is known to occur in the following protected areas, although there is no evidence that populations in these reserves are actively conserved (Information Center for the Environment (ICE) 2013):
  • Fort Clatsop National Memorial, Oregon
  • Oregon Caves National Monument, Oregon 
  • Golden Gate Biosphere Reserve, California 
  • Mount Tamalpais State Park, California 
  • Sequoia and Kings Canyon Biosphere Reserve, California
  • Whiskey-Shasta-Trinity National Recreation Area, California
  • Yosemite National Park, California


Six accessions are held in the National Plant Germplasm System (NPGS), in the USA, however only one of these is of wild origin (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013). According to Botanical Garden Conservation International (BGCI 2013) this species has living collections in eight botanical gardens worldwide and, although the size, state, origin and location of the collections are not detailed in this resource (garden locations are undisclosed to protect rare and valuable plant species), this species is known to be present in the Santa Barbara Botanic Garden (California) (Wildflower Centre 2007) and Regional Park Botanical Garden (California) (Hansen 2012).

NatureServe G RANK REASONS: Endemic to Texas where it occurs on the Edwards Plateau and the Rio Grande Plains (Correll and Johnston 1970).
NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: TX(S3S4)
Red List rationale: Amygdalus texana is globally assessed as Near Threatened (NT, close to qualifying for listing as threatened under criteria B1b(i,iii)) as it is endemic to Texas and has an estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of 30,000 km2, close to the threshold of 20,000 km2 required to be classified as Vulnerable under criterion B. Furthermore, evidence of continuing habitat loss, degradation and fragmentation infers that this EOO is declining. This species is not thought to be actively conserved in situ and there is little evidence of existing ex situ collections. Therefore, the establishment of population management and monitoring in situ where possible is recommended for this species, alongside the collection of germplasm material for duplicated ex situ conservation in genebanks.
Red List habitat: Where Peachbush is found on Rio Grande Plains and Edwards Plateau, it is found on poor or disturbed soil (Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center 2013) which is of neutral or alkaline pH (Simpson 2013). The soil tends to be well-drained, sand or sandy loam (but not limestone). Peachbush also develops a deep root system and is drought resistant (Van Dersal et al. 1938). This species thrives in direct and partial sunlight, is highly heat tolerant, and blooms in spring with its fruit ripening in June (Simpson 2013). It is also considered important habitat for Texas' native bees (The Xerces Society 2013).
Red List threats:
The Edwards Plateau where Peachbush occurs is threatened by development due to the rapid growth of the urban settlements of San Antonio, San Marcos, Austin, Round Rock, and the suburbanizing areas around them. Further west, many formerly rural areas have become retirement communities or vacation resorts. Outside the urban areas large ranches are being replaced by âranchettesâ of 1â20 acres. As Texas is predominantly privately owned, most land is not protected from development. Fire, as a land management strategy, is used less and less as housing density increases. The increasing population causes more use of recreational areas, which tends to degrade the quality of the habitat for conservation. Invasive species are also a likely threat from resident's gardens (Fowler 2013). Edwards Plateau is highly fragmented due to the overgrazing currently occurring, fire suppression and urbanization (WWF 2013).

The Rio Grande Plains are threatened by several invasive species (Arundo donax, Tamarix ramosissima, Bothriochloa ischaemum var. songarica, Urochloa maxima, Pistia stratiotes, Triadica sebifera, Schinus terebinthifolius, Leucaena leucocephala, Eichhornia crassipes, Pennisetum ciliare, Hydrilla verticillata and Melia azedarach) (Texas Invasives 2013) as well as urbanization and overgrazing.

Peachbush is also a host plant of the invasive species Anoplophora glabripennis (Asian Long-horned Beetle, native to China, Japan and Korea), which can devastate ecosystems as they significantly increase tree mortality by their presence (Cavey and Downing 2000).
Red List population: According to NatureServe (2013), there are less than 30 recorded occurrences of Peachbush in Texas, and it is regionally considered as vulnerable (of medium extinction risk). Evidence of habitat loss, degradation and fragmentation suggest that subpopulations of this species are in decline (Fowler 2013, WWF 2013). Furthermore, the estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) for this species is 30,000 km<sup>2</sup>,<sup> </sup>which suggests this species is Near Threatened according to Red List Criterion B.
Red List range: Peachbush is endemic to the state of Texas in the United States of America (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013) where it is confined to the Rio Grande Plains and Edwards Plateau (Correll and Johnston 1970). The species is found in the following Texan counties:                                      Aransas,                                                                                                                     Bexar,                                                                                                                    Brooks,                                                                                                                     Calhoun,                                                                                                                     Gillespie,                                                                                                                     Goliad,                                                                                                                     Gonzales,                                                                                                                     Jim Hogg,                                                                                                                     Jim Wells,                                                                                                                     Kenedy,                                                                                                                     Live Oak,                                                                                                                     Llano,                                                                                                                    Nueces,                                                                                                                     Refugio,                                                                                                                     San Patricio and Wilson (NatureServe 2013). It occurs at elevations between sea level and 200 m asl (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006).
Red List use trade: Peachbush is a secondary genetic relative of Japanese Plum (Prunus salicina ) (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013) and so it has the potential for use as a gene donor for crop improvement. The species also has potential use in erosion control (Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center 2013) and provides forage for goats and sheep (Van Dersal et al. 1938).
Red List conservation actions:
Conservation targets have been created for the Edwards Plateau ecoregion, taking into account different ecosystems. While these have yet to be put into action (The Nature Conservancy 2004), 30% of the Edwards Plateau is now under conservation management (Cook and Olson 2013). There is also currently legislation being drawn up to legally protect the Rio Grande Plains, which is likely to result in passive conservation of Peachbush (The Wilderness Society 2013). However, there do not seem to be any specific conservation efforts focused on Peachbush itself.

No germplasm accessions are available from the National Plant Germplasm System (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013) and according to Botanic Gardens Conservation International (BGCI 2013) Prunus texana, of which Amygdalus texana is a synonym, has only one living collection in a botanic garden worldwide, although the size, state, origin and location of the collection are not detailed in this resource (garden locations are undisclosed to protect rare and valuable plant species). No other evidence of ex situ conservation was found.

NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: AL(SNR); AR(SNR); CT(SNR); FL(SNR); GA(SNR); LA(SNR); MA(SNR); MD(SNR); MI(S3); MI(S3); MS(SNR); NC(SNR); PA(SNR); SC(SNR); TN(SNR); TX(SNR); VA(SNR); WV(SNR)
Red List rationale: Prunus umbellata is globally assessed as Least Concern as it is relatively widespread across the United States of America and it recorded as secure across its native range. However, survey work is required to confirm the population size, distribution and trend, habitat trends and species specific threats. According to NatureServe (2013), this species is threatened to various degrees in a number US states, and as a result, it is recommended that active in situ conservation with complementary ex situ collection of accessions is implemented.
Red List habitat: Prunus umbellata occurs in sandy pine or oak woodlands, sandy barrens, shale ridges, limestone bluffs and rocky upland woods as well as more disturbed habitats including old fields and roadsides (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006). According to NatureServe (2013), in the disjunct part of the range of P. alleghaniensis, a synonym of P. umbellata, in Michigan, it occurs in jack pine barrens, open woodlands and sandy plains (Voss 1985).
Red List threats: The threats to this species remain unknown.
Red List population:
Prunus umbellata is reported by NatureServe (2013) to be apparently secure across its global native range in the United States of America. However, the same source also reports that it is imperilled in North Carolina.

Under its synonym, P. alleghaniensis Porter, NatureServe (2013) again reports it as apparently secure across its native range, however it is reported as possibly extinct in Connecticut, critically imperilled in North Carolina, imperilled in Pennsylvania and Maryland and vulnerable in Michigan, Virginia and West Virginia. The same sources says it is not thought to be abundant across its range.
Red List range: Prunus umbellata is native to the south and east of the United States of America, occurring at elevations between 10 m and 800 m a.s.l. (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).
Red List use trade: Prunus umbellata belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of Japanese Plum P. salicina and so it has the potential for use as a gene donor for crop improvement (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013). It can also be used ornamentally as a road border plant and it attracts wildlife (Gilman and Watson 1994, Wildflower Centre 2007).
Red List conservation actions:
Prunus umbellata occurs in the following protected areas, however there is no evidence that populations of P. umbellata are actively managed in these reserves (Information Center for the Environment (ICE) 2013):
  • Big Thicket Biosphere Reserve, Texas 
  • Carolinian-South Atlantic Biosphere Reserve, North Carolina, South Carolina, Georgia
  • Central Gulf Coastal Plain Biosphere Reserve, Florida
  • Chattahoochee River National Recreation Area, Georgia
  • Cumberland Island National Seashore, GAFort Caroline National Memorial, Florida 
  • Hobcaw Barony (North Inlet), South Carolina
  • Horseshoe Bend National Military Park, Alabama
  • Oconee National Forest, Georgia
  • South Atlantic Coastal Plain Biosphere Reserve, South Carolina.

Incorporation of targeted population monitoring and management into the existing management plans of these protected areas would be useful for this species.

Five wild germplasm accessions are held in the National Plant Germplasm System (NPGS), in the USA, however none of these are duplicated at a second site (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013). Furthermore, according to Botanical Garden Conservation International (BGCI 2013) this species has living collections in 11 botanical gardens worldwide. Although the size, state, origin and location of the collections are not detailed in this resource (garden locations are undisclosed to protect rare and valuable plant species), it is known to occur in the Texas Wildlife and Parks Department (Wildflower Centre 2007), the Nature Coast Botanical Gardens (Florida Native Plant Society 2013), the Centenary College Arboretum (2014) and the Donald E. Davis Arboretum (Auburn University 2013).

NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: FL(SNA); HI(SNA)
Red List rationale: This species is one of the most important tropical and subtropical fruit trees, widely cultivated throughout most tropical and subtropical countries, even becoming invasive in some. Its exact native range is uncertain but likely originated in Mexico and is natively distributed throughout a range of habitats, mainly disturbed areas, in Central America and western South America. The estimated extent of occurrence (15,000,000 km<sup>2</sup>) and area of occupancy (2,500-850,000 km<sup>2</sup>) exceed the thresholds for a threatened category. Although the overall population size and trend of this species are unknown, it is very frequent throughout its range and thrives in disturbed areas. It is assessed at present as Least Concern.
Red List habitat: This species can be a shrub or a tree growing up to c. 12 m in height (Landrum 2017). It is cultivated worldwide and occurs throughout a large range of habitats, thriving mostly on roadsides with occasional abundant water and disturbed areas, including pastures, probably originated in riparian areas with periodic drought (Landrum 2017). It has been listed as an invasive species in various countries, where it invades mainly disturbed, but also undisturbed, areas and grows in dense thickets (Global Invasive Species Database 2018). Its adaptability might be one of the main reasons to be such a serious weed in some areas (Global Invasive Species Database 2018), as well as its allelopathy (Chapla and Campos 2010). It is pollinated mainly by honeybees and is dispersed by birds, monkeys, rats, feral pigs (Global Invasive Species Database 2018), bats and there is even a record of its fruits being eaten by opossums (Pizo 2000).
Red List threats: There are no documented major threats for this species. Although there  are high deforestation rates in parts of its native distribution range,  this species thrives in disturbed areas and might actually benefit from  deforestation.
Red List population: Although this species is very abundant considering its wide range and the number of specimens collected in the wild and from native countries held in different herbaria, the overall population size and trend are unknown.
Red List range: This species probably originated in Mexico and is native from Central and western South America, from Mexico to Argentina. However, its exact native range is uncertain as it has been introduced in most tropical and subtropical countries for its edible fruits (Landrum 2017), including in Southeast Asia, Australia, central and southern Africa and eastern South America (WCSP 2018). It has become naturalised in many of these countries and it has been listed as invasive in other regions, such as Hawaii, Galapagos, southern Africa, New Zealand (Cronk and Fuller 2001) and many other pacific islands (Global Invasive Species Database 2018). Its extent of occurrence (EOO), based on its native distribution, has been calculated as more than 15,000,000 km<sup>2</sup> and its area of occupancy (AOO) is much larger than 2,000 km<sup>2</sup>.
Red List use trade: This species is one of the most important tropical and subtropical fruit trees widely cultivated for its edible fruits, rich in vitamin C and eaten raw or processed into jams and preserves, beverages and ice creams (Berry et al. 2003). It is also used medicinally for various purposes such as gastroenteritis, dysentery, stomach (GutiÃ©rrez et al. 2008) and dental infections (Agbor and Naidoo 2015). Researched has showed that its leaves have antioxidant, anti-allergic, anti-inflammatory, analgesic and anti-bacterial properties (GutiÃ©rrez et al. 2008). Its wood is also used in carpentry, construction and manufacture of toys and accessories (GutiÃ©rrez et al. 2008).

Red List rationale: The species is widespread and while it is possibly declining in parts of its range, it is not thought that any global population decline is likely to meet (or be close to meeting) the threshold for Vulnerable. Therefore the species is assessed as Least Concern.
Red List habitat: The species grows in alpine or subalpine zones, forest edges, ridges or ledges, swamps, talus and rocky slopes and wetland margins (New England Wild Flower Society 2011-2015).
Red List threats: There are no known widespread threats to the species.
Red List population: The species is classed as globally 'Secure' by NatureServe (2014), however the populations in some states in the USA are classed as 'Vulnerable'. The Canadian Endangered Species Conservation Council (CESCC 2011) also class the species as 'Secure' (for Canada only).
Red List range: The species is native to northern North America, where it is found widespread across Canada and northeastern USA (NatureServe 2014).
Red List use trade: There is no information on the use or trade of this species.
Red List conservation actions: No conservation actions for the species are known, or likely to be needed.

Red List rationale: The species is widespread and while it is possibly declining in parts of its range, it is not thought that any global population decline is likely to meet (or be close to meeting) the threshold for Vulnerable. Therefore the species is assessed as Least Concern.
Red List habitat: This plant grows in moist turfy places in tundra, heathlands, and woodlands, subalpine meadows and alpine herbmats (CYSIP 2015).
Red List threats: There are no known widespread threats to the species.
Red List population: The species is classed as globally 'Secure' by NatureServe (2014). The Canadian Endangered Species Conservation Council (CESCC 2011) also class the species as 'Secure' (for Canada only).
Red List range: The species has a circumpolar range and it is found across northern North America, Northern Europe and East Asia (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 1993+).
Red List use trade: The fruits are very sweet and they have been used in making cakes and jams (Plants for a Future 2015).
Red List conservation actions: No conservation actions for the species are known, or likely to be needed.

NatureServe G RANK REASONS: This species is endemic to the islands of Maui; Lanai; and Hawaii. The species was thought to be possibly extinct until a population of fewer than 10 plants was discovered in 1996 on the Pohakuloa Training Area on the island of Hawaii. The greatest threat
NatureServe US STATES AND S RANKS: HI(S1)
Red List rationale: Solanum incompletum is assessed as Critically Endangered. The taxon is endemic to the island of KauaÊ»i, OÊ»ahu, MolokaÊ»i, Maui and HawaiÊ»i, but is now only known from the island of HawaiÊ»i. It has has an extent of occurrence of 337 kmÂ². It has experienced severe and ongoing decline in habitat and numbers due to the impacts of invasive plants and animals. Its area of occupancy is 8 kmÂ² and declining. Its distribution is severely limited, with the remaining 30 individuals occurring in only two subpopulations (one threat-defined location). This qualifies the taxon for a ranking of Critically Endangered under criteria B2ab(i,ii,iii,iv,v); C2a(i); D.
Red List habitat: The taxon is a shrub found in Hawaiian dry, mesic and subalpine forest.
Red List threats: The major threats to this taxon include direct competition by invasive non-native plant species, and predation and habitat degradation by non-native animals, particularly pigs and goats, which degrade the habitat and harm the plants through predation, trampling, and rooting for food. Alien plants also threaten the species by altering its habitat and competing with it for moisture, nutrients, light, and space. Rats pose a threat to the species through predation of its plant parts and fruits; and introduced slugs and snails threaten the species by feeding on its leaves, stems, and seedlings. In addition, the taxon is threatened by fire and drought.
Red List population: The taxon is extremely rare, with a total known population of 30 individuals in two subpopulations.
Red List range: Endemic to the Hawaiian islands, between 600 and 2,020 m elevation on the islands of KauaÊ»i, MolokaÊ»i, LanaÊ»i, Maui and HawaiÊ»i. It is now only known from the island of HawaiÊ»i.
Red List conservation actions: The taxon is on the U.S. Endangered Species List, and also on the State of HawaiÊ»i Endangered Species List. Neither subpopulation occurs in any protected area, and it is managed and monitored by the U.S. Army Pohakuloa Natural Resources Program. Ex situ cultivation and propagule storage is also ongoing. Outplantings have occurred, but it is unclear whether they have produced viable offspring. Further research is needed on general ecology, life history, population size, distribution, and trends; population genetics, and threats.

Red List rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern as it has a wide distribution spanning several protected areas and is subject to no major threats.
Red List habitat: This species is reported in Pinyon-Juniper and mountain brush communities (Wooton and Standley 1915, Welsh et al. 1987). Additionally, Spooner et al. (2004) mentioned sandy alluvial stream bottoms, gravel along trails or roadways, rich organic soil on alluvial valleys, sandy fallow fields, grassland and pine-oak forest.
Red List threats: There are no major threats to this species.
Red List population: This species is not considered common, but can be abundant where found. The population is thought to be stable.
Red List range: Solanum jamesii is native to arid regions of the USA and Mexico. The population extends from southern Utah and Colorado through Arizona, New Mexico and southwestern Texas (Correll and Johnston 1970, Gleason 1968, USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017) into Mexico at Chihuahua, Sonora, San Luis PotosÃ­ and QuerÃ©taro,(Urbina 1897, USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017, Spooner et al. 2004). It is typically reported between 1,200 m and 2,870 m in elevation.
Red List use trade: This species is a tertiary wild relative of, and potential gene donor to potato (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017). It produces edible tubers that are eaten by the Tewa people of the Rio Grande Valley of New Mexico (Robbins et al. 1916) and was historically used as a famine food for Puebloan groups of New Mexico.
Red List conservation actions:
Subpopulations are reported within several protected areas throughout the range of this species, including Carson National Forest, Mesa Verde National Park, and Apache National Forest in the United States (GBIF 2016), and in Los Marmoles National Park, Mexico.  

There are no accessions reported in Genesys (Genesys 2017).

Red List rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern as it has a very wide distribution, a stable population, and is subject to no major threats.
Red List habitat: It prefers organic moist soils to dry sandy soils in cactus desert, tropical deciduous forest, fir forest, pine forest, piÃ±on-juniper woodland , oak forest, and grasslands It can prosper in wet and temperate climates of the Transmexican Volcanic Belt. Plants can be found growing on steep hillsides, sandy alluvial stream bottoms, along trails, roadways and fence-rows, in thick leaf mulch, and at the edges of cultivated or fallow fields (Nee 1993, Spooner et al. 2004, Luna-Cavazos et al. 2007).
Red List threats: There are no major threats to this species.
Red List population: This is a common and widespread species in Mexico, with numerous subpopulations. The population is stable.
Red List range: Solanum stoloniferum is native to a relatively large area extending from the southwestern USA to southern Mexico, including the southern tip of Baja California,the Sierra Madre Occidental, the Chihuahuan Desert,  the Transmexican Volcanic Belt and the Sierra Madre del Sur,. The species is adapted to elevations from 1,040 to 4,897 m asl (Spooner et al. 2004, Luna-Cabazos et al., 2012, USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017).
Red List use trade: This species is a secondary wild relative of potato and has been used to confer disease resistance and drought tolerance to the crop (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017). It is resistant to the "Y" virus and the Columbia Nematode (RodrÃ­guez 2015). Its tubers are collected and occasionally cultivated for human consumption at the local level (Villa-VÃ¡zquez and RodrÃ­guez 2010).
Red List conservation actions: This species occurs in numerous protected areas, including the Parque Nacional La MontaÃ±a Malinche o MatlalcuÃ©yatl and the Ãrea de ProtecciÃ³n de Flora y Fauna Pico de TancÃ­taro, Area de ProtecciÃ³n de Flora y Fauna La Primavera, Parque Nacional IztaccÃ­huatl-PopocatÃ©petl, Area de ProtecciÃ³n de Flora y Fauna Nevado de Toluca, Reserva de la Biosfera Sierra Gorda, in Mexico (SEMARNAT-CONANP 2013, 2014). About 480 germplasm accessions are conserved in the Potato Germplasm Introduction Station, Sturgeon Bay, Wisconsin (USDA, ARS GRIN 2017). No further conservation actions are recommended.

Red List rationale: This species has a large range in North America but has an area of occupancy (AOO) of 312 km<sup>2</sup> which would qualify it as Endangered. However, the threats to this species are unknown as well as the population size and trend. It is therefore globally assessed as Data Deficient.
Red List habitat: There is no habitat information available for this species.
Red List threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
Red List population: There is no population data available for this species.
Red List range: It is native to North America and the Caribbean, namely to the Bahamas, Cuba, Mexico, USA, and possibly in Hispaniola (USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2018). Extent of occurrence (EOO) is around 2,500,000 km2 and area of occupancy (AOO) is 312 km2 but these are likely to be underestimated as occurrence data from part of the species distribution was unavailable. Occurrence records show it occupies elevations between 10 and 1,100 m asl (GBIF.org 2018).
Red List use trade: It is a tertiary genetic relative of, and a potential gene donor to Maize (Vincent et al. 2013). It has provided genes to this crop which increase its tolerance to Corn Rootworm (Prischmann et al. 2009).
Red List conservation actions: There are no germplasm accessions reported by Genesys (Genesys Global Portal on Plant Genetic Resources 2018) nor are there any living collections in botanic gardens (BGCI 2018). CastaÃ±eda-Ãlvarez et al. (2016) identified that this species is poorly represented in genebank collections and needs to be collected for ex situ conservation.

Red List rationale: Tripsacum lanceolatum is globally assessed as Least Concern as it is a widespread species, and even though the population is fragmented, it is stable. It is well conserved ex situ and it occurs in several protected areas, which is an opportunity to establish active in situ management and monitoring of this species.
Red List habitat: This species is found in pine oak forests. In Mexico is also found in steep slopes or rocky ravines of the mountains of the Sierra Madre Occidental. It is also found in stream banks or moist cliffs (Berthaud et al. 1997, Blakey et al. 2007, GonzÃ¡lez-Ledesma and Vera-Caletti 2011).
Red List threats: This species is threatened by invasive grasses that come from artificial pastureland areas. There is reportedly a low probability of gene transfer from maize to Tripsacum species under natural conditions, due to the high level of cytological incompatibility and sterility of the hybrids (de Wet et al. 1972a,b; de Wet and Harlan 1974; Doelbey 1983; Talbert 1990; Savidan 2001).
Red List population: Populations from Tripsacum lanceolatum are rather fragmented. In Chihuahua it was infrequently scattered, occurring in small groups. In recent explorations some of this populations were also collected (Cutler and Anderson 1941, Berthaud et al. 1997, GonzÃ¡lez-Ledesma and Vera-Caletti 2011).
Red List range: The native distribution of Tripsacum lanceolatum comprises southwestern United States of America, northwestern and western Mexico (Randolph 1970, Zuloaga et al. 2003, USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017). This species occurs at altitudes from 1,000 until around 2,250 m asl (GonzÃ¡lez-Ledesma and Vera-Caletti 2011).
Red List use trade: This species is a tertiary wild relative of, and potential gene donor to maize (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017).
Red List conservation actions: Tripsacum lanceolatum occurs in one protected area in Mexico: Ãrea de ProtecciÃ³n de Flora y Fauna Tutuaca (SEMARNAT-CONANP 2014). Tripsacum species are conserved ex situ. The most important collections are the field and seed collections of the International Maize and Wheat Improvement Center (CIMMYT), Mexico, the USDA-ARS Subtropical Horticulture Research Station, Florida and the USDA-ARS facility at Woodward, Oklahoma. There are also a number of national collections (Goodman and Taba 2007, USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017).

Red List rationale: The species is widespread and while it is possibly declining in parts of its range, it is not thought that any global population decline is likely to meet (or be close to meeting) the threshold for Vulnerable. Therefore the species is assessed as Least Concern.
Red List habitat: The species grows in bogs, fens, marshes, peaty lake shores, abandoned borrow pits and sandy roadsides (New England Wild Flower Society 2011-2015).
Red List threats: There are no known widespread threats to the species.
Red List population: The species is classed as globally 'Secure' by NatureServe (2014), however the populations in some states in the USA are classed as 'Imperiled' or 'Vulnerable'. The Canadian Endangered Species Conservation Council (CESCC 2011) also class the species as 'Secure' (for Canada only).
Red List range: The species is native in northeastern North America from Newfoundland to southern Ontario and central Minnesota south to northern Illinois, northern Ohio, and central Indiana, and in the Appalachian mountains and along the coastal plain south to North Carolina. Occasionally escaped from cultivation in British Columbia, Washington, and northern California. Also adventive along the eastern shore of Maryland and cultivated extensively in Massachusetts, New Jersey, Wisconsin, Washington, and Oregon. It has been introduced in Europe and thrives as an escape in Britain, Germany, Switzerland, and the Netherlands (NatureServe 2014).
Red List use trade: The species is grown commercially for its edible berries. Many of these are grown in artificial ponds called cranberry bogs.There is some evidence suggesting that the berries or their juice is useful in treating certain urinary tract infections (Plants for a Future 2015).
Red List conservation actions: No conservation actions for the species are known, or likely to be needed.

Red List rationale: Vigna luteola is globally assessed as Least Concern given that is common and stable in its extensive range from Northern and Southern America, Africa, Asia and Australia, and that is not known to be affected by any major threats.
Red List habitat: Vigna luteola is found in grasslands, lake edges, riverbanks, swamp edges, sclerophyllous forests and around cultivated fields and other disturbed areas; it is often associated with wet environments (Maxted et al. 2004) and Evenhuis and Eldredge (2003) described it as an inland riparian and marsh species. Associated species include Andropogon, Cyperus, Papyrus, Phragmites, Thelypteris and Typha spp. (Maxted et al. 2004).
Red List threats: There appears to be no major threats, the species is found within and on the edges of woodland, which are not threatened within its distributional range (Maxted et al. 2004). Although seasonal flooding and overgrazing are quoted as a restrictive factor in part of its range, on herbarium specimens (Maxted et al. 2004).
Red List population: Vigna luteola is relatively common and observation within its distributional range is that the population is currently stable (N. Maxted pers. comm. 2017).
Red List range: Vigna luteola is a pantropical species and one of the most widely distributed species in this genus (Maxted et al. 2004). It is native from Southern and south of North America across to Africa and reaching temperate and tropical Asia and Australasia (USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2019). The extent of occurrence (EOO) is more than 200,000,000 km2 and the area of occupancy (AOO) is 2,692 km2. According to available occurrence records its elevation ranges from 1 m asl, for example in South Africa (herbarium specimen Strey 7329) to 3,439 m asl in Argentina (catalogue number 2874676 from Genesys Global Portal on Plant Genetic Resources 2019).
Red List use trade: Reported to be palatable to cattle and elephants on some herbarium specimens from Zambia (Burkill 1995). It is a crop wild relative so has potential use as a gene donor to its related crops, Bambara Groundnut and Cowpea.
Red List conservation actions: The genus Vigna is listed in Annex I of the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture as part of the Cowpea gene pool (FAO 2009). Vigna luteola is assessed as Near Threatened (NT) in Burkina Faso (which is outside the species' native range) (Schmidt et al. 2017), as Least Concern (LC) in Puerto Rico (Miller et al. 2013) and Taiwan (Wang et al. 2012), and as Not Threatened (G5) in the US (NatureServe 2017). There are 176 germplasm accessions of wild origin reported by Genesys of which 123 are backed up at a second genebank, including 73 in the Svalbard Seed Vault. Out of the 176 accessions, 137 were collected within the species' native range (19 in Brazil, 18 in Argentina, 17 in Colombia, 16 in Kenya, 14 in Botswana, eight in Belize, five in Cuba, four in Guyana, Tanzania, the US and Venezuela, three in Australia, Ecuador, Israel, Mexico, Peru and Rwanda, two in Antigua and Barbuda, Cameroon and Honduras). A further 39 from undisclosed country of origin (Genesys Global Portal on Plant Genetic Resources 2019). Maxted et al. (2004) recommends further collection in north-eastern Africa and southern Africa. In addition, the authors highlights that the fact that it is eaten by cattle and elephants justifies more systematic ex situ collection. By overlaying the species' occurrence data with the existing network of protected areas (UNEP-WCMC and IUCN 2019), several occurrences occur within various protected areas throughout the species range (e.g. Freshwater Creek Forest Reserve in Belize, Antisana Reserva EcolÃ³gica in Ecuador, Atlantic Forest Southeast Reserve in Brazil, Okavango Delta System Ramsar Site in Botswana, Parc Nacional des Virunga in the Democratic Republic of  Congo, Iriomote ishigaki National Park in Japan, Blackbraes National Park in Australia). The presence of the species within these areas requires field confirmation but if it does occur, it is unlikely to be actively conserved as it is not monitored. Nevertheless, a management plan could probably be designed to actively protect the species in these areas. Maxted et al. (2004) recommends that subpopulations in areas that are flooded seasonally or overgrazed should be monitored.

Red List rationale: The species is widespread and while it is possibly declining in parts of its range, it is not thought that any global population decline is likely to meet (or be close to meeting) the threshold for Vulnerable. Therefore the species is assessed as Least Concern.
Red List habitat: The species grows in brackish  or salty marshes and flats, fresh tidal marshes, ponds, shores of  rivers or lakes (New England Wild Flower Society 2011-2015).
Red List threats: The threats to the species are unknown.
Red List population: The species is classed as globally 'Secure' by NatureServe (2014), however the populations in some states in the USA and Provinces in Canada are classed as 'Imperiled' or 'Vulnerable'. The Canadian Endangered Species Conservation Council (CESCC +2011) class the species as 'Sensitive' (for Canada only).
Red List range: The species is found in Canada, from British Columbia to New Brunswic, and in disjoint locations across southern, central and eastern USA (NatureServe 2014).
Red List use trade: This species was an important element of the diets of many <span id="gloss1" class="gloss">Native American tribes (New England Wild Flower Society 2011-2015).
Red List conservation actions: No conservation actions for the species are known. More information would be useful on the species population status and threats across its range.

Red List rationale: The species is widespread and while it is possibly declining in parts of its range, it is not thought that any global population decline is likely to meet (or be close to meeting) the threshold for Vulnerable. Therefore the species is assessed as Least Concern.
Red List habitat: This species grows in shallow, still or slow-moving water, fresh tidal marshes, brackish  or salt marshes and flats, ponds, and shores of rivers or lakes (New England Wild Flower Society 2011-2015).
Red List threats: The threats to the species are unknown.
Red List population: The species is classed as globally 'Apparently Secure' by NatureServe (2014), however the populations in some states in the USA and Provinces in Canada are classed as 'Vulnerable'. The Canadian Endangered Species Conservation Council (CESCC 2011+) class the species as 'Secure' (for Canada only).
Red List range: The species is found in Canada, from British Columbia to  Nova Scotia, and in disjoint location in western and eastern USA (NatureServe 2014).
Red List use trade: There is no information on the use or trade of this species.
Red List conservation actions: No conservation actions for the species are known. More information would be useful on the species' population status and threats across its range.
